Posted: April 21, 2016
												Pros+ The game is massive and from my understanding the systems are randomly generated, so you'll never hit the same systems on a different playthrough. It is probably not as large as other space-sims, however.+ There's lots of things to do, which checks off most of the traditional space-sim tropes: Mining, Trading, Bounty Hunting to name a few as well as a good variety of side missions which cover your basic 'go to point A and blow stuff up' runs to things like 'Go to station B and run/break a blockade to deliver goods'. I've played for 30+ hours in a game which cost me a third of the amount a AAA game does.+ The games events and economy, while basic, are a living thing. They'll play out whether you're there or not. If a station is hit by a crime wave, it will remain until someone goes and cleans it up, whether it's you or the AI militia. Trade convoys cross the system and deliver goods, which effects the prices you buy and sell for. If pirates (or you!) happen to cross paths with them on their trip the items will never get there, which may cause their stock to drop and their sell prices to rise.+ The soundtrack is awesome and makes the game very reminiscent of Firefly. It fits the game incredibly well and makes battles against enemy cap-ships all the sweeter+ Broadside combat is excellent, and remarkably fun. No longer do you just point at an enemy and click - your shields and armor are seperated in to quadrants and you constantly have to think about the best maneuvers to maximise damage while protecting your vulnerable sides. You can even direct-control the turrets on your ship, as well as deploying flak, EMP's, Mines or missiles. + Good variety of ships and weapons. Yeah, they're all cap-ships but that's the name of the game. You're not just some no-name rookie making your name running your fighter from a carrier. You captain corvettes, frigates, destroyers, cruisers and even dreadnaughts fitted out with machine guns, missile launchers, pulse lasers, beam lasers, flak cannons and your beastly broadside weapons.+ In almost every regard the game is top-notch: the aesthetics are excellent, the controls are excellent, the sound design is immersive, the world is immense and the gameplay is, most importantly, fun. + The best custom soundtrack integration I've seen in a recent game, you get to pick which tracks play in combat, stations, while cruising... hell - there's even an option to mix your tracks with the original soundtrack.+ Piracy pays in this game - one of my favourite pass-times in this game is responding to merchant distress calls with a few tons of high-price cargo in my posession. Save the merchants, sell the cargo to them at a premium and then threaten them to hand back what I just sold them for free. It's a brilliant way of making some extra cash.+ 1:1 sell ratio on your equipment and ships, so there's never any risk of being stuck with expensive gear you decide you don't like.Cons:- Missions can become a little repetative after a while, although if you begin to feel like this you'll realise it's because you've played the game for a decent stretch of time- Travelling across a system can take a little too long sometimes, even with engine upgrades I'm never feeling like I'm moving fast enough while in warp- Difficulty can spike without warning, usually when you equip your first bit of next-tier tech: there's a reason even the bartenders tell you to upgrade shields and armor before weapons.- Voice acting is 'just' OK. The npc voice pool is shallow and some of the emotional delivery is pretty bland.- The dialogue options really don't serve a purpose. it boils down to 'Option one to be a coward and drop your cargo', 'Option two to politely refuse and lose a faction point', 'Option three to be a badass renegade, 'Option 4 to be a badass renegade and ♥♥♥♥ off this faction' all of which provoke the most pitiful and monotonous responses. If you want to be a badass renegade, be prepared to hear 'I hope you like the cold, Cutter' without an ounce of anger or fear behind it 9/10 times.- This game could have really benefited from a sort of 'infamy system', which, depending on your net-worth, loadout, faction standing or how much ♥♥♥ you tend to kick provided a little more of an emotional response from your attackers. No matter what you do, say or how many of those pirate jack-offs you just disintegrated, they will always give you the same responses - 'drop your cargo or die', 'no? ok, now you will die'. They even say it if you've literally just wiped out all their health and their ship is about to explode.- While the soundtrack is awesome, it's short and the tracks cycle every time the situation changes - it's rare you'll hear one all the way through. I don't think there's more than 10 tracks in total and some of those are instrumental versions of the others. It begins to grate a little around the 9 hour mark - thank god for custom soundtracks. The 'Sons of the North' and 'These Savage Lands' Albums by The Black Spiders fit the game incredibly well IMO and have saved me from getting sick of the original soundtrack.- Once you finish the story, get yourself a dreadnaught and kit it out with 6th Tier tech there isn't really any motivation to continue. The story missions aren't particularly exciting enough to play again so your only goal after that really is to make money that you can't spend on anything. It's unlikely you'll feel motivated enough to commit to a second playthrough due to the 1:1 sell ratio on your equipment. If you have a Blackgate with Mark 6 Beam Turrets, Beam Broadsides and Defense tech then you can literally sell it 1:1, which lets you switch to any other ship you may have missed. The only way to screw yourself out of money late-game is either by trading like an idiot, fighting like an idiot or recruiting mercs who are idiots.Unsure:+/- Yes, it's been said countless times: there's no Y axis of movement. However with broadside combat I believe the game is better off for it. This game would be frustrating levels of fiddly control-wise trying to move up and down, while trying to maintain target lock with your broadsides/control lateral movement while aiming your turrets, while trying to line up your secondaries and maneuvre your ship to keep your target on your strongest side.Summary:There's a lot more they could have done with the "Negotiate" part of the game (they put that part of the tagline in quotations? has no-one else mentioned that?), it can get a little bit same-y and repetative after long stretches and it could do with more ship and loadout options but in the end the game is pure space-cowbow fun. My interest only began to waver at the end when I suddenly realised I had enough money to cover buying everything in the game and completing station missions, trading, mining or pirating were not only no-longer a challenge in my mile-long Dreadnaught, but also no longer pushing me towards any kind of goal. This is, however, over 30 hours in while most AAA titles struggle to hold my interest for more than 8 hours.If you love Firefly and the space-sim genre but are put off by the overly-complex nature of some of them then give this a shot, it's the one you've been waiting for. Even if games like X and ED are your bread and butter, buy this as a sort 'tune out and have mindless fun' kind of game to sink a few hours in to. Despite it's lackluster story and character performances as well as a few missed opportunities in gameplay design, primarily it's a game where you're expected to have fun blowing ♥♥♥♥ up and besides Jahovas Witnesses, who doesn't like that?

												Imagine you're playing Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag.  Now, imagine that instead of being stuck with that one, tiny, but somehow infinitely upgradable little ship, you can actually buy new ships as your fortunes improve.  Now, imagine you're in space.  Finally, imagine you don't have to get out of the ship to follow some British ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ around the island for 20 minutes in an area that is suddenly, inexplicably teeming with soldiers.I think I got sidetracked.  Anyway.  This is an excellent quasi-3D ship combat game.  Not a full 3D sim like Freelancer... all player-piloted ships, and those of similar size, seem to occupy the same plane of space.  Rolls, climbs, and dives are not valid maneuvers.  Shields go fore, aft, port, starboard, with no concern for doral or ventral.  Despite this, you don't feel particularly limited in your play.  It's just streamlining something that can overly complicate some other games.There is some downside.  There isn't a lot of variety to your available weaponry.  The targeting AI that controls your turrets most of the time is kinda stupid, and works in exclusive terms, rather that allowing prioritization.  There are, inevitably, escort missions, some of which you will lose for no good reason.  The in-game economy is a little capricious, which makes moving goods profitably as a trader a bit of a long game.  But I still find it enjoyable to spend a few hours making pretty explosions in space, set to a soundtrack that you might find playing in Jim Raynor's house back on Mar Sara- forgettable, upbeat, twangy rock.

												I finished the game, and it's time to write a love letter to Travis and Erich and all the people they contracted out for ship modeling / designs / voiceovers, etc.THANK YOU.From the bottom of my brown coat pocket, this is a game that immediately put me in what I could only imagine before ... something resembling the Firefly universe. So many cartels to see which one's you'll join / fight. The emergent game play - the distress signals (and ability to trade with the merchants was again a wise design choice as it reinforces saving their butts ;-), the un-identified signals, getting popped out in a junk or ice field, you made what should be a very empty space interesting while travelling around. Posted: February 11
												Having now played 60 hours into my first Rebel Galaxy playthrough, I feel i can give this game a solid review.Pros:- Awesome graphics (on max settings) that somehow find the right balance between cartoon-ish and realistic.- The ships are very customizable and they all look amazing, with pros and cons to each of them.- Custom music for any area of the game. (if you want to have shopping mall music in your space stations more power to you)- Simple yet effective combat system that relies heavily on shield management and ship positioning. (unless you want to repair at every station you dock at)- Accessible trading system. (buy when red, sell when green)- Good replayability due to the procedurally generated star systems.Cons:- WARP INHIBITED BY STELLAR MASS (this will be burned into your psyche) Literally everything kicks your ship out of warp once you are within 3.0 sm (solar mile??) of it. At least give me the option to smash my ship into an asteroid at warp if i'm that dumb.. this would be equivalent to getting demounted in an MMO every time you were within a few meters of a large rock or a tree... or another player.- While vast, the galaxy, and the solar systems feel lifeless. You will realize very quickly that you are playing a single player game in the cold loneliness of space.- Mining, is borderline pointless once you're at the point in the game where a single upgrade is well over $1,000,000. This is because the average mining drop is either obtanium or meteoric diamonds which sell for $1,000~, and $20,000~ respectively.- I found the default music to be irritating after listening to it for over 5 hours, though some people like it, at least there is the option to play without music or use your own.- The combat is mostly automated and based on whether your ship is stronger than the other one or not... not much outmaneuvering is possible in Rebel Galaxy, so you don't get rewarded for being a better pilot than your opponent.. that and the enemy AI is pretty terrible.- The economy and commerce of the game is completely random, so it makes trading at times very frustrating. Also, some comodoties becomes obsolete due to the limited storage space you have because of how little they sell for. There is also no way to sort or filter the viewing of the comodoties at stations, which you'd think would just be common sense. Any game in this day and age that has an auction house type system has the ability to sort and filter it. What i found to be the best way of making money was to just amass a ton of expensive comodoties and fly around the galaxy and rescue merchants. After resucing them, they will buy your stuff for the max market value, and you also get the cargo of whatever ship they were under fire from.- The story is very simplistic with some unique enemies generated from the missions, but overall it lacks any sort of emotional attachment to the characters or development of said characters. I will say however that The final mission with Trell's goodbye left me a bit dissatisfied, not sad mind you, just annoyed that there was no CGI end sequence like there was at the start of the game. Or even mid-game when she was telling you about how countless past civilizations used her for war etc. Would it have broken the budget to make a cutscene like that while she's explaining her origins? Probably.Overall, the game was fun to play, and advance with the new ships that i upgraded to, but i'm skeptical that i'll be coming back for round 2 anytime soon. Maybe if the weapons were more varied or the trading and economy was more flushed out the game would feel warmer and more dynamic, but i guess this is what you get for a budget title.Rating - 7/10

												I have always been leery of space sims, hearing of the \'horror\' stories of EVE online and the sorts. That is, until my friend introduced me to this. It literally took me five minutes of listening to the soundtrack and watching him play the game for me to get hooked. It was one of the few games on Steam I purchased at full price, and I was not disappointed. Despite its Indie tag, it doesn\'t feel like an indie game. The visuals are spectacular, the campaign is entirely voice-acted (even the alien species), and the combat is great.I don\'t think I need to explain the plot or setting in detail. You\'re in space. You\'re finding ancient♥♥♥♥♥♥ Uhh... Untrustworthy aliens/Australians. That\'s all you need to know.This game does the RPG-style building-up of your equipment very well. You start with a dinky little ship with a laser. After you\'ve completed a few missions and/or saved/looted some traders, you can buy better lasers. But wait! Your ship\'s too small for any more lasers, and you\'re finding it difficult to deal with pirates/police! Well, now you\'ve got to get a bigger ship that can withstand more damage and wield more lasers. You complete a few missions and save/loot some more traders...The game gets progressively difficult in a way that takes you out of your comfort zone. You can continue to do missions in your current system where enemies aren\'t hard to beat, but the reward is significantly smaller than that in more difficult systems. Additionally, you can only get better upgrades to your ship in harder systems. Frequently, you\'ll find yourself battling against a superior opponent, only to either destroy them or escape at the skin of your teeth. The difficulty does peak at some point though. Enemies don\'t seem to get much harder or meatier just as you\'re able to get MK6 weaponry (last tier), while you can still acquire better ships and better equipment. Once you\'ve got the money to afford a Blackgate ship, the game is practically over.The trading system is not as powerful as simply completing missions, but I overheard that the trading system used to be busted, allowing players to make millions within an hour by only trading. Either way, you can still make a hefty sum from researching how each \'event\' changes commodity prices (such as when a planet/station\'s at \'War\', the price of Ammunition goes up). If you\'re looking for a great singleplayer game that\'ll most likely last your 10-20 hours, this is the perfect game, ESPECIALLY for an Indie game. It\'s not confusing, combat\'s satisfying, the soundtrack is rockin\', and... just, everything is there.

Posted: October 23, 2015
												Rebel Galaxy is a fantastic throwback to games like privateer from my early child hood. Something happens your given a rust bucket from a family member and kicked out into space to do whatever you like. There is a story there if you'd like to explore it, but theres also a very large set of systems for you to get lost in. These systems start easy and quickly ramp up into fleets of doom that look like something out of babylon 5 or a borg invasion.Graphically the game is very pretty. Each weapon type has its own effects and its easy to tell what your oppents are using once you get familiarized with the types. You'll know when your enemy is shielding himself from your attacks and able to plan accordingly.Combat is a blast. Its a traditional "sailing" broadside system with a bit of a twist. There seems to be 2 types of ships. Broadside focused ships and turret focused ships. Turret ships have weaker broadsides so slightly less punch but they can hit in 360 degrees around their ship. Broadside ships usually have nasty blind spots at the front or back of their ships but if you end up on their sides your going to be sucking vacuum very quickly.Gameplay is very open. You can do simply the main storyline and just enough side quests to up your combat effectiveness for the next mission or you can join one of the guilds. Partake in trading, Mercenary work, Pirating, and evening mining to pay the bills. All of these have their own supporting play styles, missions, and equipment.Keep in mind that there are also factions in the game, so if you choose to start popping merchant ships for their yummy goodies expect to have to deal with that militia destroyer next time you hit a station.Alternatively there are TONS of randomized seemingly procedurally generated encounters as you fly along towards your missions or stations. Merchentmen calling for help under attack by pirates, pirates trying to lure you in with distress calls, communication beacons you can hack to get some secret info for trading, mining spots, or loot caches, and of course the occasionally massive fleet battle from one of the many factions who's decided to take a crack at each other.All of these features lead to making Rebel Galaxy on of my favorite games for the year and at a price point that is simply mind blowing.If you'd like a bit more info and see how the game plays before hand check out my lets play below.

												Though it has its shortcomings in the story arena, it's really an excuse to join the upgrade treadmill in buying the biggest, nastiest, blow-things-up-est ship you can manage. Obtain them by going to the Commodity Market and looking at which station supplies them. Go to that station, buy their stock, and exit the game. When you continue, they'll have restocked. Keep doing that until you have the necessary units, then deliver to the target station. About 30sm from the location, you'll get pulled out of warp. Just engage your boosters and tap deflectors when rockets are about to hit you or you need to recharge the booster. The first time I did this, I made $250k when missions in the area were only $20-30k, and I wish I knew about it way earlier.

												Rebel Galaxy, a game developed by two guys in an apartment somewhere.  It has you, the protagonist/antagonist, piloting a myriad of ships on a 2D plane while searing holes through smaller ships buzzing around you.  It's a simple game with beautiful visuals and a non-complex playstyle.  It takes a few minutes to get the controls down, but once that's done, it becomes second nature.It's the choose your own adventure book of the space World.  Want to be a militia-supporting pilot that tries to do the right thing?  Ok.  Prefer to be a pirate that melts the armor of miners and traders?  Ok.  Want to be a miner or trader?  Ok.  Bounty hunter?  Done.It has capital ships to fight/pilot, an array of modules/weapons to upgrade and many missions to accept and complete.  There is a propensity for the missions to get shallow, but the combat is fun enough to continue.  The desire for me to have the biggest, baddest ship in the Galaxy continues to drive me.  If I find myself getting a little weary from the missions, I go mine, or trade.  I find myself thinking about how I want to build my next ship.  Do I want an array of beam lasers?  Or do I want to build a missile boat?The game does have a storyline arc, but I'm not fully through it yet, so it's difficult for me to comment on it.  I am intrigued though, because I want to see where it goes.  Since that's the case, it has sufficiently pulled me in enough for me to continue.The music is terrific, and the game offers the ability to point toward your own local set of music based on triggers.  Want your collection of dubstep to play during a battle, but have a desire to have your atmospheric collection to drone on when you're just flying around?  Totally doable.For the price, even at full cost, it's my opinion that the game is worth it.  It's a fun time sink that allows me to drop the "why so serious?" facade and just play a fun game involving lasers and explosions while making my own choices.

												You can see that I've given this a thumbs up well okay but let's get the bad parts out of the way first. Right off the bat this game is overrated by people new to the genre, who have had bad experiences with other games in the genre, are impressed by dev team responses in threads, are amazed that it's made by a two-man dev team, and love the soundtrack. New to the genre is self explanatory - it's a great and under used genre that has been a niche for far too long. Bad experiences..well a lot of the games of this ilk are either out dated like the greats Freelancer, DarkStar One, and the whole Privateer series, whilst the X series is notorious for being released in terrible condition and aren't patched to a high standard until usually the 3rd major patch. This doesnt make them any less worthy examples of the genre when they ARE finished but the initial buggyness and headaches tend to make people react so badly that the games are crucified before they even get to that stage. As for dev responses..I've not had one to my queries and even had one deleted from the threads altogether so no brownie points there fanboys. Whilst Double Damage are a two man team it is very rare for small or solo teams to do all the work themselves..they hire part-time fillers for artwork, coding..whatever is needed..I'm sure that's the case here - When was the last time you saw a credits list to ANY game that showed one or two names? The soundtrack IS great with its modern outlaw theme (very similar to some of the music in the Sons of Anarchy T.V. show) but great music alone does not make a game.All this said, it's an accomplished entry FOR THOSE NEW TO THE GENRE who may be put off by something a lot more wide ranging and complex like Elite Dangerous; others may be put off by what can seem dumbed down and simplistic by comparison leaving a somewhat arcadey feel to combat. Regardless of how you feel in that respect it's a decent game that is certainly worth the asking price.

Posted: October 28, 2015
												Classic space game formula done right. Summary: If you don't hate naval style combat / movement you need to get this one. You don't need a lengthy review on this one, trust me. Chances are you've already played other space games and on paper you'll get exactly what you expect: A short story, fighting, trading, smuggling, mining, rescuing, escorting, ship upgrading, new ships to buy, some factions, some solar systems, jumpgates and .. well .. you get the drift.Originality is not why eventually you'll decide to buy this. Polish and charm is. Very enjoyable naval-style 2d combat. Easy to get into, few keybindings to remember, requires the correct amount of strategy (aka it never gets boring and it never makes your brain melt).Opportunistictrading and mining. No need for spreadsheets or noting something down. You'll instantly recognize red prices, stations with famine, mining rushes, market gluts, under siege etc and you'll know when to buy or sell. You'll stop to help traders being attacked by enemies and then sell them high some of your cargo. Addictive progression system. There's always a new ship, weapon or component to aim for and it will always be addictively close to your budget.  Short, classic, cool story. It won't win an oscar, but the voice acting and general style is pleasing and keeps you mildly hooked. It never limits your sandbox experience though and you'll probably be alternating between sandbox and story. Style. Lots of it. Very enjoyable and unique slide-guitar firefly-like rock soundtrack and you also get to use your own music for fighting, idle and in-station situations. Very colorful galaxy with cool gameplay-changing nebulas and asteroid fields.Make no mistake though, this game won't replace elite dangerous or star citizen in your library. You'll probably be alternating between them. One's for the serious long-term thinking space pilot that grinds money and faction influence with his multiplayer buddies and the other one's for the colorful opportunist lone-wolf / firefly / Han Solo experience.EDIT: Almost a year after having finished my first playthrough i find myself again drawn to this game and going for a second playthrough. In the meantime i've been playing (or re-playing) elite dangerous, x rebirth, ring runner, pixxelfrazer, endless sky, galak-z, beyond sol, cosmonautica and other space games - and i have to say i'm having the most fun with Rebel Galaxy (Beyond Sol and ring runner shared the 2nd place).

												UPDATE:  This review is out of date, so take what I say about the mechanics with a grain of salt.  I will not be playing this to see what has been fixed any time soon.  Seriously, I spent a lot of time and got no real reward for the MASSIVE grind.  I doubt I will ever beat this game.  Like I say below, the reward does not justify the time it takes.Like some others, I really like a lot about this game but it has some problems.  The kind of problems that caused me to just set the game down, and walk away.  I will start with what I liked. I liked the: GraphicsShip designCombatCustomizing of ship loadoutsChance to buy items low in one system and sell high in anotherAtmosphere\EnvironmentsAbility to add a custom soundtrack  (I used tracks from the Endless Space and Dungeon of The Endless Soundtracks and I liked it better than the normal soundtrack.) What I did not like:The grind! and lack of variety in objectives - This is the biggest problem for me.  You have to grind a lot to progress, with no real change between the different star systems aside from harder enemies/missions + higher tier gear/ships.  This would not be so bad if there were more to do than the same basic missions repeatedly.(IMO: I think having some unique things to find around in space could make flying from port to port a bit more fun.  You know, things that add life and history to the universe you have created.  )Difficulty Spikes - As others have pointed out, there are delivery missions where upon near-arrival to your destination, a ring of fighter ships appear around you.  These ships are quickly reinforced by more ships.  Even with the threat level low, these fighters annihilate your shields and you get picked off pretty quick.  I have had to quit almost every one of these mission due to an absolute inability to get past these ships. (even after upgrading) Merchants Guild Missions - I had originally planned on focusing my time with the Merchants Guild.  On top of the painful delivery quests, I found the others tedious and boring.  Some require you to purchase a large amount of relatively uncommon items and then deliver them to a certain station.  The amount of time and cargo space required for those missions make them a total waste of time.This is too bad because I much prefer the idea of playing a merchant/smuggler, and I like the ships they offer as well.  So I switched to the Mercenaries Guild because the missions are more fun and make more sense.Except rescue missions.Does anyone else have a huge problem with the rescue missions as well?  Maybe I just suck at those.TL;DR - You might like this for a while if you love space games.  But, there is a good chance that you will hit a wall where your time spent isn't worth the fun gained.  I really want to recommend this game, but cannot. In one word: Plateau.

Posted: April 8
												This pseudo-3d combat sim actually had some potential to be good. Like a lot. And it still has some features that are exemplary. However, it has some awful things in it too.The good:The music. Like the series called Firefly? It will bloody catapult you right into the feeling. It's absolutely fantastic, and you can set your custom music, separated into 'combat', 'ambient' and other categories, and you can even tell the game to mix the originals and your own. This is actually my favourite feature of the game, it is so simple yet so effective.Controls (with gamepad mind you). Intuitive, however, you pretty quickly end up "HOLD DA BUTTONZ, ALL OF 'EM". You need to hold X for flak coverage, left stick inclick to use the afterburner, left trigger to aim, right trigger to fire broadsides, right stick to aim your broadsides, so yeah. But still, the controls work smoothly and comparatively easily.The combat in the beginning. While the game still attempts to be fair, it is pretty fun. Small craft can be taken out by your flak and turrets, larger ones get the broadside.The bad"Hey, you go for an Average difficulty mission? How about you get 3 random encounters in the mission area, so you not only have to destroy the 2 light frigates we've sent you to kill, but also 3 destroyers, 9 heavy frigates, about 20 corvettes, and about a 100 fighters, bombers?" And once the random encounters locations are generated, they cannot be changed. So I have a practically impossible main mission in front of me, ♥♥♥♥ you very much."Trade system". Components cost about 100k+ once you hit tier 3 (in the first system, there are already 2 tiers, so tier 3 is fairly early, but you have a good understanding of the mechanics by that time) and your cargo can be about 50 units at best. However, you cannot check the prices of other stations in real time, and you can certainly simply buy everything a station can offer in trade goods, and have half the cargo empty still. An extremely lucky trading run can net even 50k, however, you can earn literal millions with single missions by that time.Pseudo 3d ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. The problem comes, is that some stuff is in 2d, some is in 3d. Asteroid belts are in 3d, but your radar is in 2d, which means if you warp travel, you have no freakin' idea wether you'll get stuck in that asteroid field by the annoying "WARP INHIBITED BY X/Y" (X=stellar mass, Y=hostile forces) every five second, because some asteroids are on your level, some below, some above, some while you could easily fit under/above it, still inhibits warp because ♥♥♥♥you, Enemy fighters, bombers, gunboats move in 3d, you move in 2d, enemy corvettes and above move in 2d. Your flaks only cover your port and starboard, however, if a bomber is shooting at you from your keel, or from the mast (the bottom and the top of the ship respectively) you can only pray that your turrets deal with him in time. Even better, if it shoots you from your poop, where usually no or few turrets face, and your engines exhaust is harmless (however, you can at least turn and face them with your flaks and broadsides then).Overall, the difficulty spike inbetween tiers is too big (your tier 2 turrets are BB guns against a tier 3 shield), forcing you to farm in the previous system for cash before you can afford proper equipment for the new system. Way, waaay too much farming, and even then, the random events are simply unfair.

												TL;DR below.This game should be called 'Grind Galaxy'.That's because grinding is basically what you will do for 90% (or more) of your game time. Except you're only going to play it for it's main (and only) story. There are no story side quests. Only missions like: destroy some captial ships, rescue a trader by destroying more capital ships, escorting another ship to it's destination while destroying even more capital ships or deliver goods to a certain base which will be hindered by - you guessed right - capital ships which you will have to destroy or run away from.If you want any challenge out of this game, don't upgrade your ship too much. Do as little grinding as possible, so your missions will stay at least at normal difficulty. The game tells you the difficulty for every mission going from 'extreme' to 'low'. I did the mistake of grinding for a dreadnaught ship with level 6 equipment and the game became childs play.The story of this game is very lackluster and demotivating. There was much more potential in it to work with, but the devs didn't build on that. It also ends very abruptly. Even the mediocre story of Freelancer looks like a masterpiece compared to Rebel Galaxy's. I was very disappointed by the story. Especially after the ending.Trading is a waste of time in this game. It has no real simulated economy and the profit margins are so small that it's just not rewarding. The fastest way to make money is to do side missions which, in basically all cases, come down to combat. And after them you can sell the loot you've got from your fallen foes and still make more money than having bought and traded them.Mining is even more useless than trading except for the one achievement you can get.The visuals of the game are okay. They don't make you go 'wow', but at least they're not ugly. But even the old Freelancer can hold up with it. And Freelancer has a greater variety of areas you can visit. In Rebel Galaxy every solar system basically looks the same.The sound of the game and the appraised soundtrack are okay. The soundtrack might annoy you after some time since it's not very diversified. Too few songs are in the game. At least you can set your own music for the various instances of gameplay.TL;DRIf you're looking for a space action game and haven't played Freelancer then definitely go for that. Or if you want even more quality check out the Descent: Freespace games. Google for Open Freepace for a improved version of them.If you've played Freelancer already and are looking for something similar, even if not as good, you could give Rebel Galaxy a try. But better buy it on sale. It's not worth it's full price in my opinion.If you're looking for a space sim where you can do more than just continuous fighting - like trading, mining, building an empire - you should avoid this game and rather check out the games from the X universe or Elite Dangerous.

Teal DeerDevelopers: Double Damage GamesPublishers: Double Damage Games Initial release: Oct 2015Genre: Action, Strategy, Economy Simulator, Space #Worth/NotWorth: #Worth Exposition, Concurrence and SummationBuy red, sell green. “Economic prosperity and quality education for our children are inexorably linked.” - Jon HuntsmanRebel Galaxy is a indie developed game best summarized by calling it a space trucking simulator. Think of Elite Dangerous in the ocean. The games combat takes place on more of or less of a two dimensional plane. In the the way that Assassins Creed IV Black Flag naval combat has become a bit of a standard. However fighter ships can go a bit above or below the playing field. Of course there are contingencies that allow you to deal with these inconveniences such as automated scatter turrets that can have a tactical assignments selected while you are trying to focus aiming your broadside hardpoints. The game has faction warfare that evokes a feeling of Mercenaries. Some factions are needlessly hostile to you to begin with while others can be swayed through favors or pushed away by other actions. There is no ship customization other than changing hardpoints, shields and deflectors. Or strait up buying a new ship. The game, despite its open nature, has a very linear progression. I see only 2 ways to go. You either become better at killing other ships or pick a frigate that is better at not dying whilst transporting cargo. Essentially be a bounty hunter bent on protecting the citizenry of the known universe. Be a space trucker and keep your nose clean at least in areas controlled by the militia or become space pirate. This is not necessarily a bad thing but in all honesty it feels very shallow and has a feeling (the entire experience) of being a tutorial to Elite Dangerous. Which again is fine, so long as you expect that going in. There are commodities at each station. In essence you could just play the market to progress and get ahead. There are often events going on like a tech boom or famine where buying low and selling high should be a strait forward affair. The game features a custom soundtrack option. And no, I don't mean like putting on a playlist from spotify. You actually set up custom pathing. As in, choose from list A for battles, List B for Exploration etc etc.. However the game features an OST that I consider quite superb. Its consists of some amalgam of slide guitar space cowboy jams and 90's grunge. Which feels not to far to removed from the serious/satire ratio that Borderlands possesses. THE GISTThe game is basically a more friendly version of Elite Dangerous and that's not a bad thing. So long as your expectations are not higher than that it is a very enjoyable game indeed.Follow my curation for more

												People keep saying this little gem is 'the spiritual successor to "Freelancer"'...well, I feel it's more of 'the more faithful sequel to "Privateer" than "Freelancer" was'.  This is not to say that Digital Anvil's last(?) release was *bad*, but it's more like this later game manage to recapture the first game's core 'feel' than the sequel.  Make no mistake, it does fit in that same grove as both of Chris Roberts' titles, but it lacks the 'glitz' of a AAA-game like Freelancer; it's got more of a 'rough gem' feel like that Wing Commander spin-off was.And tangible things bear me out: the 'meta-game' is very similar: you have stations/bases that allow you to buy and configure ships, commodity markets to buy and sell goods, a mission computer to take various jobs, a bar to meet storyline people, chat with the bartender for rumors and info and hire wingmen...and two 'guilds' - Merchant and Mercenary - who offer better jobs than the mish compy...with membership.Rogue Galaxy adheres to this system, but adds a little to it; the guilds supply unique gear and ships, for example, and your standing can grow over requirement levels to make same available to you (there was little point in 'grinding favor' with factions in Privateer once you were 'friendly').Now the core gameplay (combat and station-to-station travel) is different; you're captaining a large ship that operates like a blue-water vessel, rather than a glorified 'space plane', and combat is 'raking him with your broadsides' rather than 'curling in on his six and shooting him down', but even that difference doesn't weaken the bond.Even the story premise - you speak with this person and that person, and are given an 'artifact' to hold on to momentarily for someone, and it proves to be very desirous for just about everyone else, painting a giant bullseye on the beam of your frigate.But again, this seems to be loving and faithful emulation of a great older title, and it helps the new game.If you liked Privateer (or even its 'big show' successor Freelancer) you WILL like Rebel Galaxy...even if you prefer dogfighting to battleship steerage.  It will 'scratch that itch' while you're waiting to see how Star Citizen will evolve into something that likely won't be able to....oh, and as I'm sure many others have said: the soundtrack is AMAZINGLY good; catchy tunes that you'll find yourself humming on the commute after a while playing. :)

												So much potential! The game made a good first impression, and has quickly gone downhill from there. It seems really padded, with tons of watching your ship warp and a lot of repetition in not only the missions but how the battles play out. It just gets... boring. There's all this seemingly cool economy stuff going on, and NPC ships going places - but they all lack personality and I just can't be bothered. It also lacks gravity - in a tough fight? Just run, warp out, dock at a station repair and reload, and the enemy will just wait there for you to come back and finish it off. I have never seen an enemy ship run once I start wooping them (and therefore I never feel any urgency to chase it). I've also never failed a mission so far - they don't seem to expire, they don't move, they don't get effected if you go dock or go do a bunch of other missions.I WAS super excited to finally try this game. SO MUCH potential. BUT it looks like the devs put all their time into making it look good and forgot to make it IMMERSIVE and FUN. I just don't have any reason to open it up again.HERE'S WHAT WOULD MAKE IT AWESOME - - NPCs that reward you with more than just credits... how about loyalty? How about some good cargo? How about doing a han solo and swooping in to help if I'm in a pinch and they're nearby?- Feel like your actions ACTUALLY MAKE A DIFFERENCE. How about after you blow up 200 cartel ships, I dunno, the Cartel gets weaker? Or puts a price on your head? OR SOMETHING??- Ability to attempt to take over ships would be cool- Ability to build your own small fleet, dominate or take over stations, actually look forward to more than a bigger ship after a crazy amount of grinding- A lot less padding would go a long way to make this fun!!

												This game reminds me of Freelancer. In my opinion Freelancer was one of the best space games ever! This game is very easy on computer requirements. I can run it at max settings with no issues and I have a much older system. Pros: Feels like Freelancer style of play but a bit more dynamic. Space combat, tradeing with stations and vessels in space, real piracy including gangs to join, differnt factions that interact based off your standing and more. A variety of ship combat styles to your likeing. Much to explore like Freelancer. There is a cool story that you aren't require to follow but keeps things interesting.Cons: The galaxy isnt known for its extreme beauty but I think thats just a minor. If the game was 60$ then I would complain.I think the ships are all rather ugly. Usually space crafts are designed to look very alien and beautiful. All the ships in the game have this rustic western look and fee. Also the music is filled with that style. So no beautiful space music. (It clearly gives you the option to put your own sound tracks on opening the game)Even conversing with the differnt people at stations they have this western voice style and attitude. Still these are all very minor cons for a 20$ game that WILL give you many many hours of game play easily paying for itself in gameplay time.If you do the same thing over and over while it may start to feel like a grind to get a more powerful ship and upgradeing it. I recommend doing a little of everything so stays fresh for many hours.This game does feel like a AAA game but at a 20$ price which is very worth it. Hell if you can get it on discount even more so.TLDR: If you like Freelancer and space games this is a gem. Cheap in cost, runs very very well graphics are very good. Lots of fun to be had for a cheap cost $ .

												I am very sad and a bit conflicted about giving this game a negative review.  In truth I consider it "meh".  Its only real contribution to gaming as a whole is the broadside, Assassin's Creed 4 style ship to ship combat, which is a lot of fun.  The rest of the game is a pretty stripped down and bare bones space sim.  Almost all missions involve combat, even the trade runs.  Being knocked out of warp is commonplace and makes just getting from point A to point B needlessly tedious.  The universe has no depth, there are several factions with friend/neutral/foe ratings you can adjust, but none of them have any substance or even an explanation as to who or what they are.  Trading and mining profits scale poorly as such that they're not a real way to make money as the game progresses.All of these things being said I did put 50+ hours into the game and earned all the achievements.  I enjoyed myself through at least some of that or I wouldn't have done it.  The real problem comes down to the fact that its just a bare bones game that does one thing well: combat.  This is a space game to get if you want to get in quick shoot stuff and get out.  Its also good for fans of the show Firefly who like that type of universe and that type of "space-western" soundtrack.  Personally its not my cup of tea but that's just a subjective opinion.  While I don't necessarily regret buyint ir or playing it, I don't think I would have missed out anything had I never bought it.

												So. Rebel Galaxy.If you're wondering if Rebel Galaxy is a fun game to get, well, here's three stories to help convince you.Scenario One: Laughing at Bandits.I took a mission to pick up a dead drop, pretty simple stuff. Fly to the location, use my tractor beam to pick up a box from the middle of nowhere, and then return it to the station I left from. Simple stuff.Well, apparently some folks didn't take too kindly to it. I come under attack from a wave of pirate fighters, but due to their.. ahh.. 'Lack of tactical prowess' they all come in at different points across the ice field. I start burning away, because there's no need for a fight, am I right guys? Besides, I have a small network of flak cannons (Secondary Weapon System), so these fighters can't do crap anyways. Well, one fighter (let's call him Jim-Bob) decides to go for it anyways.One fighter against a Corvette. Bad choice Jim-Bob. About 10 seconds later, Jim-Bob is a frozen corpse in space, and seconds before my warp drive fully kicks in, all the bandits can hear is a "suck it, nerds!" across the comms.Scenario 2: I'm a Big D*** HeroNot too long after that, I take a job to protect some miners. Might come under attack from some more bandits, maybe the same crew I ran into on the last job, no big deal, easy pickings. I head on out, enjoy the sights for a few seconds, before my ship tells me some unfriendly locals show up. Alright, no big deal, some fighters and a pair of gunships. Still in my old Corvette, with the flak system installed, so no big deal, they all get wiped out, I get paid, everyone's happy, the miners all lived, I got paid, played the hero, good stuff. I do my usual heading on out, accelerate to sublight, and hit the warp engine, all cool-like.I feel the kick-back of the warp engine, and am ready to sail off towards my next job...Except I forgot to keep an eye on the asteroid off my port side, and make it about ten feet before dropping out of warp, where I embarrasingly have to boost past the asteroid, re-accelerate, and then hit the warp drive again.I can still hear the miners laughing...Scenario 3: Lightning in Space. Not so PrettySo, easy job. Eliminate this particularly nasty bandit who's been pillaging and marauding his way across the system. Easy-peasy according to my mission log, thanks to some recent upgrades after a few.. less-than-stellar performances on my next story mission. Head on out there, and as I come out of warp, I notice this beautiful blue nebula, with a bit of lightning. I think it's some really nice decoration for a pirate base, kinda fits the motif.About three seconds later, my computer's lovely voice tells me that my port shield is down, and as a I look at the display, not only is my port shield down, so are my fore and starboard shields. Right as the enemy enters weapons range. Beautiful, simply beautiful. That easy mission turned out to be not so easy. A wave of pirate strike craft, and a Corvette greet my in my old Corvette. I've been looking to upgrade to a nice frigate, but that doesn't exactly help me right now, I'm still in this now-battered heap after fending off most of the wave as the enemy Corvette, my target, starts speeding away. Thankfully, sublight boosters help me catch up to weapons range, which, thanks to my shiny new Proton Cannons, is about three to four times longer than my old standard probably-shooting-a-space-potato broadsides. Well, apparently he notices how my guns are about to fire on him, and he turns towards me, not that far off my starboard side, when my helpful computer notifies me of another problem"Starboard shields down"Well, that's just perfect. the shields I NEED to be up are down, thanks to the space-lightning the pirates conveniently chose to hide in. I'm still kind of battered, a few scorch marks and maybe a piece or two of my hull missing, but this is the one guy I positively, absolutely, have to destroy. I open up with a salvo of Proton fire, and close range to get my Scatter Turrets (run of the mill space-laser "machine gun" turrets) to fire on him, hopefully preventing a bit of shield recharge. The gambit works, and despite a few more scorch marks to my starboard side, the enemy Corvette explodes, and the people of the system are safe once more!And I don't get caught on an asteroid this time, letting me feel like an actual good guy. Until I explode next, that istl;dr: Buy the thing. Seriously. I would've paid 40$ for this, and they're selling it for a sale price of 18, and a regular price of 20.

												( Als je Nederlands bent is hier een review van het spel: 


YouTube™ Video: Rebel Galaxy review ( Nederlands ) 

			Views: 183		

			Review van Rebel Galaxy http://store.steampowered.com/app/290300/ Rebel Galaxy is een roekeloos ruimte avontuur, vol met actie, ontdekking, handel en onderhandeling met de bewoners aan de rand van...		

 )Double Damage was kind enough to sent us a review copy of this game. We're very impressed with it. It's old school fun in a modern setting. The ships designs remind me very much of the Terran Trade Authority Handbook SPACECRAFT 2000 to 2100AD By Stewart Cowley.The game is an open world sandbox with 14 galaxies. You fly around in big capital ships, which you can upgrade or trade in for a better/larger one. The ships can mine, collect, transport and fight. Mining is done in astroid fields scattered all over the galaxies. Each galaxy is full of spacestations, belonging to one of the 4 or 5 factions (sorry don't know for sure if it's 4 or 5). At the spacestations you can sell your mined items, but also buy and sell a lot of other commodeties. You can also upgrade and buy ships there, hire mercenaries to support you and select missions you want to play. Factions offer missions there and by doing them you will grow in popularity with them, while loosing popularity with others. The less popular you are with a faction, the more likely they will attack you when you encounter them in space. When you are really unpopular with a faction, they will not allow you to dock at their spacestations. Throughout the game you can gain or loose popularity however you see fit. Missions can be focussed on trading, mining, defending or helping others, smuggling and battling.The ships are quite cool, all of them have a bit of an 70's - 80's scifi game to them. You can upgrade their strength, equipment, cargo space, weapons and much more. Quite some options available. To make things easy, the ships more one a 2D plane, in a 3D world. This works very well for this game. The act more like a ship then a plain. They have a main engine, sub warp enigne (booster), warp engine and a interstellar warp engine. Weapons consist of turrets and broadside cannons. You can let them fire pretty much automatic, or take control of indivual turrets. Fighting is done like sail ships do, facing sideways and firing away :DYou can fly around anywhere you like and while doing so you will encounter loot, pirates, astroid fields, others in need of assistance and more. This is all aside from the missions you can do. There are also guilds in the game, joining one or more will give you access to special equipment and ships. The ships you can fly in the game range from firefly size ships to battlestart galactica capital ships and beyond.On top of all this, there's a full story with all kinds of missions and mystery going on. You can focus on the story, do it once in a while or even neglect it completely. Besides the main story, there are a few smaller subplots as well.The best thing about all of this is the freedom you have. Go anywhere you like, play the way you like. Be a pirate, trader, merchant and so on. Follow a story, neglects, do side mission, explore and so on. Mix it all together. The game is really easy to get into, easy to play and offers all kinds of levels of mission, with a very low risk to a high risk. The further you fly into the universe to more hostile it gets and the more advanced upgrades and ships you discover. Easy to play and to pick, yet offering a good challenge as well. Flying is easy, just like driving a car. Battling is really done awesome, you get the whole star trek, battlestar galactica, star wars feel when doing so. No puny little fighter..... no massive firepower :DI guess that pretty much covers it, sure I forgot a thing or two. Is it worth it? Yes, without a doubt. The whole concept is done innovative and very well. Everything blends in and just works well together. It's a very welcome break from all the massive space mmo's and all the small spaceship focussed game.

Rebel Galaxy is a story driven space exploration and battle game with a unque style and a firefly-esque feel. Above is a short video of me running through th first half hour or so of the game, below are my thoughts on Rebel Galaxy. TheHiddenLevels.com was provided a review copy by Double Damage Games and for that we thank them.The opening soundtrack and just the music in general really gave that space junker, firefly, out in the verse where there is little law and less integrity vibe.. The following gameplay did not let this notion slip away. This is a fantastic western style space traveler and battle game. I was hooked pretty quickly by amazing music and voice acting, the graphics are impressive as well.I engaged my first enemy and honestly thought I was about to lose my ship when I shot them down just in time, the battles feel tense and while manuvering isn't the focus, you've still got to be crafty. The only thing that was a slight turn off was that other ships I was fighting were able to move on a 3D axis, but of course our ship is not capable of 3D flight. It is a game mechanic so that is the last I'll mention it, becuase the game is supremely fun even without that facet involved. The ship building and upgrade possibilities are relatively deep, and offer a real variance in experience and gameplay. I really enjoyed the feeling of landing on new planets, talking to folks in smoky dive bars, and running errand / bounties for unsavory space characters. It's a great adventure game and I'll likely be coming back to it often to see what's next in the story.I'd reccomend this one to any fans of space games, especially those where players can outfit ships and fly around a massive galaxy. Thanks for wathcing and reading, check out www.thehiddenlevels.com for news and reviews!

												I came in to this game with the idea that "If you liked freelancer, you'll like this".  I liked Freelancer, I didn't like Rebel Galaxy.I felt like the camera was always way zoomed in and at a weird angle, and during combat it's pretty much always facing at a right angle to the direction you're moving (because of broadside combat) so I run in to asteroids a lot.  My second time out in a combat zone I ran into an asteroid that had something else next to it, and my ship got stuck such that it couldn't turn, and you can't go backwards, so I had to reload to get my ship free.It feels like you're flying through something far more viscous than water.  I can forgive constant thrust = constant velocity in space games if they at least let you cruise along for a while without slowing down super fast when you disable thrusters.  This game feels like a naval combat engine with space combat art resources.  I think the ship in assassin's creed black flag has less resistance from the water than your spaceship does in the vacuum of space in this game.I also didn't like the weapons.  They auto aim at stuff, and you do broadside combat where you don't really have to lead or even aim close, your weapons all just kind of pick stuff and shoot at it.  The combat is very non engaging and easy, and if it were hard I'm not sure it would be anything but frustrating since there doesn't seem to be any strategy or skill involved.The UI and the controls on keyboard and mouse are also not too great.  It seems like it might feel better on a console, but that's not much of a "consolation" on PC.

REBEL GALAXYDamn! This is such a nice discovery that I made with this little gem of a game. I had bought it, uh, long ago but finally managed to find the time and see what the hell is up with Rebel Galaxy. Oh boy, why have I waited so long? Close to 47 Hours in playtime, I think this is the longest I've played an Indie game!So what is Rebel Galaxy?If you're familiar with FREELANCER, STAR LANCER, FREESPACE, then you will feel right at home in Rebel Galaxy! The main difference is in RG, you pilot a "BIG" Capital ship... well, not the starter Corvette ship but there are many ships to choose from as you progress further till the untouchable ENORMOUS Dreadnought BLACKGATE! Took me forever to get it but once I did, game is just too easy...  Anyhoo... let's see the pros and cons!PROS:+SOUNDTRACK! That Dark Country musical genre is so damn good from the composers known as Blue Saraceno, The Dirty Diary and others!+Simple yet really fun and addicting gameplay.+Controlling a HUGE ship is quite satisfying! You ain't a tiny fighter here but a Capital Ship!+The progress system is taxing but rewarding each time you buy a new ship!+Freedom of progress. Want to farm/grind some more credits to have better gear/ship, do so!+Randomly generated "universe" so the solar systems aren't the same in each playthrough. Doesn't really matter I'd say as trading is rather pointless in RG!+21:9 UltraWide Monitor support! Visuals are pretty simple which makes RG not a demanding game!+CHEAP! For a 20$ game, I got more than my money's worth out of RG!CONS:-Average story. Hopefully Double Damage Games can improve upon that in a sequel!-Highly repetitive: Lots... LOTS of grinding. You are warned! To make it easier, focus on the "DEAD DROPS" side missions, they don't take long to complete and you can repeat them at will.-Ally/Enemy factions doesn't have any territories. You see them everywhere in all Solar Systems... would love a fixed territory setting like in Freelancer!-Would love more variety of missions, mostly all "dead drops, escorting, go kill Mr X".OVERALL:For the first game developed by Double Damage Games, I'd say they started amazingly! Sure there's some irks and quirks to work around so hopefully on an RG2, things would be polished and more meat be added too!RECOMMENDATION:Love space games? You'll love this! I just want to warn you that if grinding in a game annoys the sh!t out of you, play RG in quick daily sessions, that way you won't feel it too badly! At first, I felt the annoying grind but as you progress and get a better ship, the grind is less significant as the rewards are much bigger... so is the drops from killed enemies!I truly recommend this game especially at this low price of 20$, you'll get your money's worth!

content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												IntroductionRebel Galaxy is the space swashbuckling brainchild of Double Damage, reminiscing of arcade space games like Freelancer, and is supported by an excellent Firefly-like soundtrack. Unlike most space arcade shooters, the game has no pitch movement, instead opting for travel along a single plane. The main game is set inside a galaxy, although it does feature multiple maps, relatively large in size. Despite its similarities, it does a whole lot of thing in a slightly different manner, from combat style all the way down to the way you travel. What you see is basically a new breed of space arcade gameplay, and very much feels like its own brand of shiny new original IP. Prepare yourself for broadside battles and inter-faction negotiations, along with a whole lot of lighting effects to blind you mid-mining.StorylineThis game actually has a rather interesting story line, which is something I didn’t expect. Basically I was expecting it to be like Freelancer in most ways, but be lacking in some department or other. Despite my previous disposition, Rebel Galaxy follows a decent storyline. Basically you’ve been sent a message from your old crazy Aunt, who actually turns out to be a swashbuckling badass space-pirate at the age of late 50’s early 60’s. You’re trying to find out where she is, and make some sense of this weird AI you’ve gotten a hold of. Needless to say you get backstabbed and used like no tomorrow, and very often end up murdering the people you started out helping. It’s all a bit up and down, but heavily broken up by side quests and random world events. It’s similar to Freelancer in that you really need to do side quests and random events in order to upgrade your ship between main missions.GameplayLearning Rebel Galaxy initially can be a bit odd. I went in expecting one thing, and discovered it was something different. The key problem is I was expecting something akin to most space arcade titles. I wasn’t far off, but I was enough for the game’s management to throw me a bit. From scanning areas to turrets with AI, that and the fact that despite manual aim there’s still an aim assist – don’t walk into this expecting Freelancer/Freespace/X-Wing. Take portions of a number of space arcade games, and you’ll eventually have a recipe for Rebel Galaxy. The mystification lasted only a short while in fairness, it’s just something new you have to get used to, but once you do it becomes second nature. To clarify, this is a good thing. What we have in Rebel Galaxy is something that feels at least a little bit unique, unique enough for us to be learning something new, while enjoying ourselves at the same time.I’d like to go on about how much I love this game, so let’s first get the crap out of the way. Two things disappointed me most. First and foremost is the aiming system. AI turrets are awesome, configurable, and there’s a whole bunch of them and they do their job. Manual aim however, felt consistently interrupted. When engaging in broadside battles the game is constantly doing what it thinks is best. I aim the broadsides at a ship, but there’s another smaller ship closer which the game’s AI thinks is a more important target. The catch is my broadside weapons are slow velocity projectiles, and quite frankly I don’t give a damn about that tiny piece of crap. My lasers will take care of it. Instead of simply aiming at the ship I want to kill (which is usually fine in most cases I might add), the auto-aim kicks in and starts shooting broadsides in a direction that is not where you’re pointing. I hate it when a game thinks it knows better than me, and is flat out causing issues for me in intense combat situations. This doesn’t happen all that often, but it’s enough to annoy me a bit. Freelancer had it right. Allow full manual aim, but add aim assist circles to shoot for to shoot ahead of an enemy’s flight path. Auto-aim is just plain interference, because if you want to adjust the game’s target, you have to go into scan mode and switch targets.This auto-assist comes in a second form, with the game’s speed and travel system. I cannot abide it. I’m sorry, but throttling my sublight speeds and dropping me out of warp at the hint of a sparrow’s fart gets extremely irritating throughout the game. Basically warp can only be engaged when the game says so. Sublight can only be sped up to cruise speeds when the game says so. Give me control of my damn ship’s navigation, and stop farting about like my mother. Nothing has been more infuriating so far than travelling 6000 game-lengths and getting stopped three times between A and B because you skirted around an asteroid field. Freelancer solved it, but adding AI auto-avoidance around objects. You’d occasionally hit stuff and lose some shield, but no problem. Slowing me down, and then further slowing me down to the lowest sublight speeds, forcing me to turn ninety degrees and boost out of an asteroid field is immersion breaking.Rant over. The rest of the game rocks. This game is not Freelancer. Stop right there. Take all those predispositions out of your head, and prepare to play an all new type of game. Movement is entirely on one plane, but that’s cool. It means you can focus more on your tactical (or woefully haphazard) combat with those big♥♥♥♥♥broadsides. Turrets have varying types of AI that can be programmed to fire at certain types of targets, and there’s so much variation in weapons it tickles me in all the right places. Combat feels punchy, it looks pretty, and quite frankly simulating space-pirates is an excellent idea. The easiest way to make money is to pick a mission and then do all the randomised events that happen on the way there. There’s tonnes to do, and an enormous solar system to do it in. You might think to yourself that after the first solar system you’re halfway done, but you’re wrong, there’s a tonne more, and each map is as big as the next. Quite simply put there’s an awful lot of content and a lot of sights to see.Unfortunately I can't fit my entire review in this section.To read the full review, go to: http://www.nextpowerup.com/articles/rebel-galaxy-review/To read the performance analysis, go to: http://www.nextpowerup.com/articles/rebel-galaxy-performance-analysis/

Posted: October 28, 2015
												SUMMARY: A simple to play, but surprisingly deep space adventure sim with a lot of personality and style that gives you a solid "Space Western" adventure where you can carve your own path.It took me awhile to get into Rebel Galaxy as, early on, the directions weren't that clear and the difficulty was erratic.  That's when I realized Rebel Galaxy, for all its great graphics and soundtrack, really is a throwback to the old "drop 'em in space and good luck" games of the past.  Once you realize you are on your own in just about every way, it all comes together.In Rebel Galaxy you come to a distant set of stars to find out what happened to your Aunt Juno.  And from there you can do anything you want, from following her legacy, to trading, to piracy, to naming your ship "Cosmic Bannanahammer" and doing donuts in space.  It's pretty much up to you.Basic gameplay involves piloting your ship to different locations and pursuing different tasks - trading goods, fighting enemies, raiding ships, mining asteroids.  From firing broadsides to talking to people everything can be done with a standard game controller, which makes it extremely easy to play.  Though controls can get complex, the layout and design makes it very easy to get into the game.So let's break down the usual parts of these games:PILOTING: Space is 2D here.  Sorry, 3D is just for display.  This may seem limiting, but it fits the easy-to-control method and keeps the game from getting insanely complex.  See, battles are done by . . .NAVAL BATTLE TACTICS: This may take a bit of getting used to, but the game emphasizes a mix of broadside weapons, turrets, and specailized items.  Learning to juggle when to attack, maneuver, and fire takes a bit of work, but is rewarding to get right.  Also some of your weapons are AI controlled, making life much easier.  Speaking of ship components . . .PLENTY OF SHIP OPTIONS: Equipment really matters in Rebel Galaxy and has tradeoffs.   Once you get your playstyle down you can buy and customize ships that fit you.  Little changes mean a lot, which is good because . . .PLENTY OF MISSIONS: Sure they're often find, kill, or trade, but they're fun and more importantly they have impact with your standing of various groups.  Pirates, Militia, Citizens, and more will come to regard you differentlly depending on what you do.  This gives you quite a few ways to play the game.LOTS OF LITTLE BITS: There's also a delightful amount of extras.  Trade advice and data that appears to help you trade.  Guilds to join. Bits of humor.  Random events that pop up to keep the game rich, from ambushes to data transponders.  The more you play the more you find.A STORY THAT SEEMS INTERESTING: At first I wasn't sure about the story, but a few missions in it actually got my attention.  You don't have to play the story, but still.A SENSE OF ATMOPSHERE: Finally the game really manages to create a great "Space Western" atmosphere, somewhere between Firefly, Cowboy Bebop, and its own thing.  This is helped by . . .A COWBOY BUTTROCK SOUNDTRACK: Really, the soundtrack is the icing on the cake, a bunch of country-rock hard-edged western type songs that complete the experience.  The details in this game really make it.Is the game perfect?  No.  Some of it's very standard game-play, if well-implemented.  The combat can be a bit twitchy and confusing.  Some of the data and info layouts could have been better done.  The thing is with Rebel Galaxy, most issues are really minor.  The game is fun, obviously made by people who love games, and has a clear, well-defined identity.  It delivers.So if you like a good space adventure game, want one that's challenging but you can pick up with realtive ease, then buy the game, get on board the Cosmic Bannanahammer, and head on out to find Aunt Juno.

												Basically AssCreed Black flag in Space, including the grindy and repetative nature that BF had.It has a great charm and flare and perfectly nails the space western vibe that it wants to set up. All the ships are dinged up and rusty buckets, your warp drive sounds like it needs a crank start half the time, everyone including the aliens sound like rednecks while vibrant nebulas full of warm yellows and purples makes the dreary backwater system you're in look cozy despite the absolute zero conditions. Combat is fine if pretty shallow, it emulates Black flag almost completely. Combat is mainly through the use of broadside cannons of which there are three main types for your preffered engagement range as well as a slew of secondary weapons that can either be AI or manually controlled. The main unique spin in all ships have shields as their main defesne and these are set up in quadrents with their own independant health pools giving a bit more importance to positioning than Ubisoft's pirate game. Ultimately that is the crux of the entire game, what is has works well but there is very little variety. You'll find one or two setups that are effective and then proceed to grind away doing randomly generated missions or trades to generate the cash needed to buy the next tier of upgrades to survive the later systems and missions, progression is purely numerical. The story itself while not offensively bad won't offer any suprises but gives a good enough incentive to have you roam around the game world.

This is a review discussing specific points about the game as a comparison for veterans of the genre.An excellent free roaming space game. Very much a Freelancer for the new generation, featuring Capital class vessels!THIS GAME IS JUST FINE WITH A KEYBOARD AND MOUSE, DONT LET OTHER REVIEWERS TURN YOU OFF OF IT BECAUSE YOU DONT HAVE A GAMEPAD!So, in Rebel Galaxy, the value of ALL of the parts you buy for your ship is fully refundable. Including ship chassis. You're free to experiment with new types of loadout at will. No charge for resale at all.There's a stat in the pause menu that shows your Net Worth, including your ship and all of the parts you have on it, what's in your cargo hold, etc. It's a great way to do a single-player space exploration game.People complain a LOT about warping taking too long, but I don't find it a problem at all. You can get upgrades to your warp drive that increase the speed dramatically. As for hitting asteroid belts during a warp, you can and SHOULD watch for oncoming nebulae and asteroid fields. You can literally see them coming from a million miles away, and just steer out of the way. Snake around space for a better paralax view, so you can tell whether you're coming up on something big.Combat is on a 2d plane for capital class vessels, and a 3d plane for fighters and bombers. So, your turrets can hit stuff above and below you depending on their placement, and your side-guns are primarily for hitting the bigger stuff.There is a surprisingly large number of ships in the game, I'd put my currently seen number at about 20. Each faction has their own set of ships on offer. I particularly like the trade faction's GIGANTIC verticall wall of shipping containers, bristling with turrets and cannons.When considering your loadout, you spend a lot of time trying to strike a good balance between equipping anti-fighter, anti-cap, anti-shield, or anti-armor. Each turret and cannon has it's own set of attributes, and the jack-of-all-trades stuff is lacking a little in the numbers department. Over all, weapons feel good and balanced between types, with a slight leaning toward Mining Lasers at the start. I found them good for the first system, and switched out to specialized guns later.The cowboy music aesthetic is nice, very firefly. I ended up turning it off after a few hours of hearing the same four or five tracks, and loaded up a playlist with all the Star Wars music from the original trilogy. Definitely a good choice.Bounties are very easy to get in to. You can find them at random when flying about by using your PULSE scanner, and waiting for the "Bounty Detected!" notice, then flying to the nearest enemy group. You can get map icons and waypoints to them by paying a small fee to bartenders at any station. While flying about, you'll come across lots of other stuff too. Message terminals that you can hack with a simple timed button-puzzle put waypoints on your map marking weapons caches and asteroid belts uncommonly rich in minerals. You can find distress beacons, traders or military who are fighting a losing battle and pay you VERY well to save them! You can also find "Pirate Lords" floating around out there. They are elusive and unusually powerful enemies with huge bounties on them.Missions are the same old cookie cutter, go here, kill stuff, gather items, come back. But! You can take three at a time, and bang them out really quick. Every station has missions, you can see the relative difficulty of each one as a color-coded mission title, green being easy, red being hard. It's actually quite accurate so far, hard missions definitely require some interesting strategies. The missions pay out as SOON as you complete the objective, so if it's just a kill order, you don't need to return for the reward. Super handy!Some of the later trade-faction missions are super lucrative, but require you to actually go find minerals on your own time. I got a mission to gather Pure Water that took me an hour or so due to NONE of the local stations having any, but that could be why I got the mission in the first place! I ended up mining out a few ice asteroids for the loot, and the reward was over $300,000.Trade itself in the game is very simple. Go to station, find merchandise that is selling low, travel around until you find a place to sell high. Each station you visit will book the sale price of each item FOR YOU, and then map them on a really clever line graph showing maximum price, minimum price, and the average price. This means you can do everything at a glance, and don't need to worry about note keeping on paper. Cargo upgrades are pretty cheap, so most any ship can do some hauling. Obviously, gigantic hauling ships do have a lot more to offer that way though.Some ships concentrate much more heavily on rotating turrets, too. So if you don't like the whole "Broadside" dynamic, you really don't have to do it at all. I had a little cruiser with 7 turret slots and only 3 side guns, it was just perfect! The downside to a turret-ship is primarily cost. Turrets cost as much as the entire battery of your broadside guns. They lack a little in pure DPS as well, but you can easily make up for it with proper tactical positioning. Broadsiding is hard to line up against faster enemies, and makes you extremely vulerable to flanking by other enemy ships. It does have a pretty devestating hit if you nail another ship with the whole volley, though!You can blast fighters to smithereens with a well-placed cannon volley, too. That's a little tough, but super satisfying.Over all, I rate this game very highly. Each of it's features feel polished to a mirror sheen. It's very, VERY well thought out, and plays like a dream. I've run the gamut of space-freedom games from EVE to Freelancer to EV-Nova, and I feel like this game is a shining star in the genre!

												Think Elite Dangerous, but with naval combat and a good story.The naval-style combat deters a lot of people, but it actually works quite nicely with the single-plane orbit everything has in every solar system.  That means you can't fly up or down, only left or right.  However, smaller fighter planes and asteroids can fly beneath or above you, requiring your ship's turret placements to be more strategic.You can trade, mine, steal, join factions, make factions hate you, help people in distress, escort ships, fight every time, flee every time (depending on ship speed).  You can play as good, neutral, or evil, or jump around and do whatever pays the most.The game allows you to easily put your own music into it. You can resell every ship or item for 100% retail value.  This means you can test out ships, weapons, defenses, etc. without fear of wasting money.  This is a nice way of getting around the fact that you can only own one ship at a time.I think this game is definitely worth the price.  As of writing this I have played 32 hours.  I'm not done with the main story line, and I don't think I will be for a while.  There is too much money to be made, and too many ships and ship upgrades to buy.
