content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												If this was being marketed as some $50 triple-A title, it would be disappointing, but as they say in the ad, it's 20 friggin' dollars (and that's when it's not on sale). Rebel Galaxy is a very simple game, and that is its strength and its weakness. If you're looking for a game with a deep story, complex controls, or a fully realized universe with a vibrant dynamic economy, then this ain't it.  Rebel Galaxy is just a fun way to pass the time. It's a nice looking space game with simple controls and a good cowboy rock soundtrack. Incidentally, if you don't like the soundtrack, or you just want a little more variety there is a way to replace or add to the playlist in the game's launcher. I like that it lets you add different folders for different parts of the game. You want honky-tonk piano in the stations, smooth jazz while exploring and speed metal during combat? You can do that.The game is easy to learn and easy to play so long as you understand that running is often a better option than fighting. A fast ship lets you choose your battles and outrun those nasty pirate ambushes that some players seem to have trouble with. It's also a fun way to play. I especially enjoyed the dead drop missions in which I warped into the middle of an enemy formation, grabbed the loot, and hightailed it out of there before they could say, "Prepare to die!"Are there better games in this genre? Of course. But sometimes I don't feel like firing up an Egosoft title and micro-managing a fleet of traders. Sometimes I just want to have a little fun. Rebel Galaxy was made for those times.

Posted: June 5, 2016
												After reading reviews about this game being successor to the freelancer classic, I bought the game. The first few hours of game was quite disappointing as the 2D flight mode and the lukeworm story can hardly convince me that this game is even comparable to freelancer. After 5 hours, however, the game became a little more interesting as weapons and ships are unlocked and some of the missions are quite interesting. I have to admit the graphics are good, not superb, but comparable to the freelance --- a shame on its own as the freelancer was a game almost two decades old. The combat system was not inspiring but acceptable and admittedly quite fun to play. Just as I thought the game is getting better, it quickly revealed to me that this is no more than a freelancer game in its core repacked with better graphics and a toned down 2D flight mode. The game soon degenerates into a struggling effort to complete repetitive missions to gain enough money to upgrade ships and components that are ridiculously expensive and are so for no other apparent reasons than to compel the player to complete those stupid missions. So far I think it is unrealistic to make enough money to buy any of those higher level weapons and ships with trade alone. The difficulty associated with some of these missions are also questionable as some missions would see you quickly swarmed by a horde of overpowered enemies ships while other missions give ridiculously high reward for the simpler tasks.In conclusions, I believe this is a game suitable, in fact I would use the word ideal, for killing your excessive pastime at a moderate price. However, to comment that this game may even aspire to be of the equal to freelancer is a severe overstatement.

Posted: January 18, 2016
												I had been looking for a single player space based game that included missions, mining, exploration and ship to ship combat for a long time before I came across Rebel Galaxy. I picked this game up on sale hoping it would provide me with what I had been looking for and was happily satisfied. You start Rebel Galaxy off in a tiny ship and are quickly thrown into this massive galaxy head first with no real direction and plentiful choices on what to do first, an amazing first impression. After a few hours I found that some of the missions were kind of repetitive so I moved on to a different sector to try a new guild. While the missions did vary there are a lot of fetch quest style side missions that unfortunately did not change as the game progressed. Rebel Galaxy shows you straight from the start these giant dreadnaught class ships worth $15m+ while you are making a measly $10k a mission. This while great, also lead to a desire to acquire better ships and gear as quickly as possible. The problem with this choice is due to the games difficulty system, which  is never explained. Rebel Galaxy seems to use four mechanics to set difficulty; system rating, mission difficulty and the last two are based on what hull class and gear type you are using. The game only considers your highest individual type of gear to set the difficulty which can lead to some annoying situations where you are severely outclassed by the enemy ships . These two points should not dissuade you from this game, however. Almost every other aspect was fantastic. The music, while I found not suited to space exploration, was great and has been well received by the community . The ship types and styles all were unique and looked great while offering a variety of build possibilities and attack styles. The weight and feel of the ships during combat and the combat itself. The battles at the core of the game can be amazingly chaotic, the large varieties of ships / builds with different amounts of each in a fleet can lead to some of the biggest fights you have ever been in. I went into a great number of battles ridiculously outnumbered and when surviving in the final moments after a tense and carefully executed fight,  let out a profanity or cheer due to the satisfaction of these sometimes epic encounters. Overall this game scratched an itch that I've had for years that nothing has come close to. For the price and the amount of time you can get out of this game I couldn't recommend it enough.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												From the first riffs of the soundtrack, to the thundering broadsides in your first battle, Rebel Galaxy grabs hold of your inner "space cowboy" and never lets go.Honestly, not many games give you the full experience of being an outlaw like Rebel Galaxy. Sure, other games has the long arm of the law chase you around, have you be loathed by the locals, and generally make life less than pleasant as it should be. So, what was missing? The soundtrack. This is hands down one in the top 20 game soundtracks I have had the pleasure of listening to while I played a game.As for the game itself, it is pretty straightforward. Take missions, get credits, earn/lose reputation, and along the way solve the mystery of what happened to your Aunt. While it can get grindy, especially for those wanting to be outlaws and getting that initial "bad reputation" you need, there is a fair amount of variety to the missions, as well as stuff to find, kill, mine, trade, etc. You can also customize your ship in a plethora of ways, from weapons and armor, to ship class itself. From gunship to dreadnought, there's a ship for just about everyone.Combat is pretty straightforward, you use devastating broadsides on larger ships to tear them apart, while using your turrets to add to the carnage, or use them to pop pesky fighters. With the customized loadouts, you can make your ship a straight up brawler, or make it a long range ship that deals damage from afar without having to worry about heavy plating. There are also support abilities that can further refine your battle plan, or round out a particular weakness.The map is pretty expansive, and the economy reacts to events, so raiding a convoy or breaking a siege will also affect prices of goods that can be traded. This affords you the player lots of ways to play, from being a miner to a no guts no glory pirate.My only gripes are that it can get grindy, but I really don't mind. The soundtrack and visuals clearly make the downtime less unpleasant, and the long warps around the map have given me lots of places to visit along the way. For someone that enjoys being a space privateer, Rebel Galaxy is a game I am glad that I did not miss out on.

												So... Rebel Galaxy...Rebel Galaxy is a game with a space setting that locks you in a 2D plane. You can steer right, you can steer left and that's it. No up, no down, in a game with a space setting, one of the only settings in which you expect full freedom of movement and you're stuck in a 2D plane. 												I bought Rebel Galaxy on a whim, and thus far it has been the best impulse buy I've ever made on Steam.  You control a space cruiser flying around the galaxy trading and fighting.  Make money from trading at space stations buying low, selling high, and use the money to upgrade your ship with new weaons, armor, and equipment.  This will allow you to take on pirates (or become a pirate) and loot your fallen enemies.  Trade, fight, loot, upgrade, repeat until you have enough for a bigger ship and repeat the process.  This is much what I imagine Han Solo and Chewbacca did before running into Luke and Ben in Mos Eisley.  Do you want a Han Solo simulator or a Firefly simulator?  This is pretty much it.  I also enjoy the amount of choices the devs chose to throw at the player.  For almost every mission you have multiple options of how to proceed, be it violently or non-violently.  I have yet to see how many of these choices play out, but Rebel Galaxy has made a very good impression in my first few hours of gameplay.

I like it, but...As a fan of Firefly, I like this game for both the whole living-on-the-edge vibe, and for the slide-guitar soundtrack. It's cool.But as an astronomer and lover of science fiction, I'm disappointed.First, in space a real spaceship does NOT slow down just because you kill the engines. There is this thing in physics called "momentum". You know, the whole thing about an object in motion tending to stay in motion unless acted upon by an outside force? In space there are very few outside forces that would cause a spaceship to slow to a stop just because the engines are off. At the bottom of a gravity well, like, say, on the surface of the Earth, a vehicle like a car will slow when you take your foot off the gas because of friction. Silly programmers... If you're gonna make a game set in space, at least pay attention to how things BEHAVE in space.Second, even though the POV can be moved around in 3 dimensions the actual game play is 2-dimensional. You can go right & left (port & starboard), but not up or down. Remember Star Trek II, the Wrath of Khan? How did Kirk beat Kahn? Because Khan was operating in only 2 dimensions, whereas space is 3-dimensional.I mean, c'mon, guys! If you're gonna go to all the trouble of programming a game that is smart enough to have you colliding with ice chunks, asteroids and planetary objects, can't you figure out how to deal with 3 dimensions?The last item is that, like so many other games, once you’ve got the basics down it’s “lather, rinse, repeat.” It would be nice to have more different kinds of missions - medical rescues, something that involves landing on some of the worlds instead of just flying by, I dunno. Something other than just blasting things to smithereens.Ah, well. Given the limitations, I'm gonna have to give this game 3.5 stars on a 1-5 scale.

												Rebel Galaxy....Probably the most fun I've ever had with a space game like this ever. The soundtrack alone attracted me to this wonderful game, only because it's such a perfect match. Though I must say, at the time of writing this, I have roughly 60 hours set in right now into Rebel Galaxy, but it does not match the potential amount of hours I COULD be spending playing this game. With it's randomly generated "Systems" or whatnot, it provides a relatively fresh experience with every new playthrough. The only downside with this model, is there is a general process that is the same, and it goes with the advancement in tech vs. the contracts price in every system. Right out of the start cutscene, I could spend maaaybe 2-5 hours building up enough money for a new drive that allows for Solar System Gate use, and start working easy contracts in the furthest system. Run into no conflict, and in the matter of hours attempting at getting high tier gear relatively early on in the story breaks the immersion a little bit. Even if you were to stay true to the story aspect, you can get to a specific point and still go do side quests and contracts for money. There are many directions that you could take with every playthrough, and thats what I'm getting at exactly. No matter how hard or easy you make it for yourself, it's still amazing what one could do in this game.I will have to say, it does break a little bit of realism/immersion at times, when Juno talks  about "your small ship and how it may be time for an upgrade", and you already maxed everything out. It just seems weird to me. Little prompts like that. Another thing that concerns me is the difficulty overall, it goes from baby steps to smacks in the face pretty quick, and the overall progression seems a little awkward when moving up in tech. I found that the only way I could survive going up in difficulty for the next system was to earn a ridiculous amount of money, go over there, and buy the highest tech because that would be the only way I could even survive there. The whole concept of Mining or Trading seems a bit awkward to me, because if you want to mine, you have to go at it for a long time to make any real profit. It feels almost useless to me (Mining), unless you find that golden nugget in a desert, the Antimatter Specks, which I have yet to find. The only way you can even make trading profitable is if you attack convoys or traders due to the large amount of items they have that are super profitable OR fighting Pirate lords with high end ship systems, though, they are insanely hard sometimes.PROS:1. The whole badass atmosphere (with music) gives the player confidence and has a really good feeling while flying through space in my awesome ship with big weapons2. Optimization and level of content allow the highest graphics even on lower end machines3. Ship designs seem really well thought out and allow for a multitude of playing stylesNEUTRAL:1. Combat feels tasteful and well done, though lack of ways to end your enemies in your travels feels saddening at times. When I'm flying past, I feel the only way to really do damage is broadsides or lots and lots of turrets. If only there were more ways, it would feel just perfect.CONS:1. Mining is tacky and has a useless feeling. One could be mining for hours, but unless they are mining the right materials that usually scarce in most astroid fields, so it doesn't feel fulfilling2. Solar Systems never really feel unique, a few system is a new system. It may have labels that some places are better for trade or mining, but I haven't really noticed a difference anywhere.3. Factions seem pointless sometimes - because I could be super friends with the militia and citizens, but NOBODY else would like me, and it wouldn't matter because I wouldnt gain anything from them anyways. The only other faction that matters to some degree is the Red Devil Raiders, but they offer mid-game gear from my current understanding. If the other factions had more purpose and personality, I'd be more inclined to try improving relations with them, IF there was a way besides surrendering all of my cargo whenever they see me.Rebel Galaxy is definitely a fun game and I highly suggest you give it a try!---NOTE---The game is not far from its release date, so I expect a lot of changes in the games further history, but for now, this is what I see :)

												I've only gotten a few hours into this game, but I'm already loving it. It appears to have the full range of activities in the Freelancer tradition: exploration, trading, mining, and loads of combat. You have faction relations that can go up or down depending on who you do missions for, and there seem to be space ports all over the place to dock at for missions and equipment. I've only barely scratched the surface of the main story, but it's intriguing so far.Combat seems to be the focal point of the game, and it's really well done. I'm not sure how much more layered it can get, but it's nicely varied so far. You control a capital ship rather than just a fighter, and you seem to have two primary classes of weapons: broadsides and turrets. Broadsides do massive damage, but are slow and can't track fast moving ships. They're great against other capital ships though. Turrets can lock onto targets and tear up small fighters, but they can overheat if you don't give them a break from firing. And the cool thing is, they will automatically fire while you're controlling the broadsides. In addition, you have a thruster boost mechanism that can increase you speed, but which can also be depleted from over use, such that it needs a rest to recharge. On top of that, you can get a deflector add-on which is something like an extra shield that absorbs essentially all incoming damage. When it's up, you can't fire your weapons, and it has limited energy which drains over time or rapidly when it's taking hits.What all this means in practice is that you've got a lot of systems and energy bars to keep track of, which keeps combat really engaging. It was a tiny bit overwhelming or frustrating initially, but I felt like I got the hang of the essentials within maybe half an hour. At that point, combat was a blast.I can't say much about the main story, since I've only gotten a couple missions into it, but it seems to revolve around some form of advanced technology and finding a lost relative. Interesting enough that I want to see where it goes. The world feels large and full of activity. Visually, the game is gorgeous, with great effects for all the weaponry, and the music is awesome, a dustry, countrified rock soundtrack that really adds a lot of character to the experience. I love me some electronic music, but this is a nice change of pace that gives the game a distinct personality. In summary, if you ever played the old Wing Commander games, or Freelancer, or anything similar, you will love this game. It even more closely resembles another game call Nexus: The Jupiter Incident that came out about a decade ago, which had an equally interesting story. I'd say the primary difference with that game is that combat is much more refined and well done here. If you're like me and aren't sure, but crave space adventures, get this game.

												The soundtrack makes this probably the best Firefly game we'll ever get, but if - after a dozen hours have you memorized every note of the included tracks - you throw in the right custom soundtrack it pretty much covers Cowboy Bebop as well. Mechanics-wise this is basically Freelancer 2, except with far better 2D naval combat, randomized systems and sectors, far less "loadscreen" traveling (instead you free-form warp and dodge obstacles and it usually takes 40-60 seconds) and the endgame is you piloting gigantic behemoths with dozens of automated turrets in gigantic battles with up to a hundred ships.The variety of mission types for the generated missions is reasonable but limited, so it's up to yourself to pick the type you enjoy (pro-tip: escort missions usually pay that much for a reason) and to get the insane(ly expensive) gear you'll need need to either batch a few dozen missions or - much more exciting - pick the contracts that the game deems far too hard for you and play smart (and hope for the best). So that's both difficulty selection and clever risk-reward choice to let you pick the pace you enjoy.There are definitely a number of systems that feel functional yet rudimentary that i'd like to see expanded for a sequel, but this delivered everything i always thought i wanted from the larger space games like Elite or EVE (ha) or that other sad joke in a much more condensed and enjoyable package.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												This game has the understanding that many of the more recent space sims do not, namely that a living world creates immersion and that the major component for creating a living world consists of real voices, simulating communication with the player, and a vibrant AI system. Add to it some hearty music and Rebel Galaxy feels warm and alive, unlike its much more expensive predecessors.The main gameplay feature that sets this space sim apart from all others is that the battle happens with Black Flag type naval combat, where the ship stays on a flat plain and fires cannons from the sides. Pro's: Good flow: you complete missions, scavenge ships, buy upgrades, move to more dangerous areas, buy better ships, help out allies, do more missions, etc. It gets addicting.Dynamic unbalanced world: I once came across an enemy capital ship in a low-difficulty space that annihilated two militia capital ships and was clearly overpowered for the area. Another time, I came across a giant pirate armada next to a planet. Yet another time, the mission was labeled hard but turns out to be super easy if you are fast enough. Maybe these are all bugs, but they make the game feel more dynamic and realistic.Music: slide guitar rock is great. I bought the songs before the game even came out.Combat is fun. Lots of ships flying all over in the colourful chaos of battle.Customizable fighting styles: Buy a fast ship or a slow mammoth; long range torpedo boat or point-blank cannon. You decide.Good value for your money.Cons:Saving behavior. At the time of this review, the game saves whenever you quit the game or at a station and there is only one save. This means: 1. you cannot load a previous game if you mess up and 2. if anything happens to your save, you are screwed. This means you have less freedom to experiment. I have yet to find a game where the checkpoint system did not annoy me.Flat space: While the naval combat system does work, part of what I love about space sims so much is the freedom to fly anywhere and by restricting the movement to a plain you are cutting at the core of what is interesting about space sims.Trading system is mediocre: You can buy low by paying attention to the news and then sell high but it is nowhere near as profitable as doing even the easiest of the combat missions and just does not work very well.In time, a few annoying bugs did reveal themselves, though nothing gamebreaking.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												Yet again, the fact that Steam reviews don't have a "Meh" button, is really unfortunate.At first, I didn't like the game - death was frequent and random and the camera was terrible. I even got a Steam refund, thinking that the game was horribly ported, but I found myself missing the combat and feel of the game, so I bought it again... on sale mind you.Having a lot more time in the game now, I can give a clearer opinion on the good, the bad and the plain outright moronic.You control a capital ship and you shoot at other capital ships with a combination of turrets and broadside guns. While there are also smaller ships in the way of fighters, gunships and bombers, you can't control them or even deploy them. If you want an idea of how ship combat works and have played SPAZ2, then you pretty much know. I'm not sure who plagiarised who, but someone did. I can't seem to find anyone else who has raised this point, which is strange, as the similarities are uncanny. Anyway, the good points and the bad.First the good stuff. The graphics on the ships are nice - very nice. Everything else? Not so much. I'm not sure why space is so bright in video games, but I don't like it. The planets look pretty bad in particular, but luckily they are just obstacles to go around and the level of interaction with them stops right there. Another good point is the feel of the ships.Another good thing is how the combat feels. At least most of the time anyway. Flying around in a big ship with turrets and lining up broadsides is pretty neat, though I tend to stick with turret heavy ships and let the game do the aiming, as broadsides don't seem particularly useful most of the time with the speed of combat as it is.So the bad stuff. This is tough, as I don't know where to start. Ah wait, I know."Space" is kind of a strange word to be using in this game. You are on a 2D plane. There is no up and there is no down. This might as well have been a boat game rather than a spaceship game - it would have made more sense. It's not too much of a bad thing, I guess, as full 360 movement isn't always done well, but then come the obstacles. Flying through asteroid or junk fields is a huge pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ especially when you graduate to the bigger ships. Squeezing in between spaces can be awkward. Even worse is when you are "warping". See, when you aren't in combat, you will, after a time, automatically start going at "sublight" speed, in which your ship will go faster than it normally can. Any ship, or rock, or piece of space junk and this faster speed will cut out. Let me tell you: "space" is full of crap in this game. I dare you to fly any sort of straight line in this game without running into a junk field, asteroid field, ice field or random pirates who happen to be sitting in your flight path. It's so bad that it feels cramped and clunky. It's really bizarre.Another issue that I find annoying is to do with the fighters. Remember I told you that the game is on a 2D plane, right? Well that doesn't apply to fighters. They have full 3D movement, so targetting them can be really hard, especially with the broadsides. Turrets can handle them but they seem infinately more powerful than capital ships when even in small groups, which I find pointless. Also, you'd better pray that you don't encounter fighters of a higher rank than you because they can outrun and outgun you. When the only thing to do is to cut your ship's engines and wait for your inevitable death as you can't fight and can't run, then you know something is seriously wrong.The largest issue, however, is unibutton. If you've played any game ported from a console, you'll know what I'm talking about. Some games call it a context button while others call it an action button. I call it a lazy porting button: used for control pads with limited buttons and annoys us PC gamers with keyboards. This button is responsible for your warp and will automatically light up when you can warp... it's also your tractor beam, your speed increase button and hailing button. When you are near cargo, have hails going off and simply just want to go to warp, you might aswell just blow your brains out instead of waiting for the inevitable frustration triggered aneurysm. Devs: this is the PC. I have dozens of buttons which I'm not using, is it really so much to ask that I be able to map different actions to them?The game can feel good though it does get repetitive after a time and the issues are just mind bogglingly dumb. A minor issue (in terms of the game not my hearing) is that the menu sound and music is so much louder than the actualy game that I have to keep turning the volume down when I exit.This game is ok if it's on a sale, you will get some gameplay out of it and I do feel that it's better value for money than Space Pirates and Lego 2. Don't expect it to last, though.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												I recommend Rebel Galaxy, but you've got to know what you're getting into.Rebel Galaxy initially has far more personality than many of its peers in the "randomly generated open world space game" genre.  Unfortunately, the space cowboy facade wears off pretty quickly and the game still boils down to being the same sort of soulless mechanical grind as every other open world space game. The only thing compelling you to play the game is getting the next bigger ship, until you finally get the biggest one, and then you're left only a bit of a hollow feeling at having wasted so much time doing the same things over, and over...and over.So why the thumbs up in spite of these gripes?  Because it's priced right and I knew that's what I was getting going in.  For what it is, it's quite fun to play; it strips away some of the unnecessary complexity of similar games and lends itself to being played in short bouts - which makes it far more palatable to me than some of these games which require an hour just to make one profitable cargo run (you know which ones I'm talking about...). It scratches an itch for space shootin' without being particularly cumbersome to play. I've had enough fun with it for the price that even if I had stopped playing before getting the biggest ship, I would have been satisfied.Just go in knowing that there's a "honeymoon" period with this game that eventually wears away before the raw mechanical nature of it is laid bare and if you start getting bored.  After that, I recommend treating it as a "filler game" you play in short bouts between doing other things and you'll enjoy it.I do have a couple specific nitpicks that I will list only in the event that they could be taken into account for future improvement:The soundtrack is great...but it makes me realize why some other space games have "ambient" orchestral soundtracks.  The game can easily sustain many, many more hours of gameplay than there's soundtrack to cover and the 10th time you hear the same song, it will start to drive you nuts.  There are simply not enough songs in the game.  You can import your own custom soundtrack and that's good, but requiring a player to go to the effort of cultivating his own soundtrack just to avoid being driven insane by the hearing same steel guitar alt-country song for the 65th time is a problem.Regarding the ship models, it became a little too apparent that some were done via contract work or perhaps even just bought off a content store.  The first few ships were very clearly designed to fit the game.  However, some of the later model ships have designs that don't really gel with the visual design of other ships in the game (even accounting for them coming from different alien races). Some have turrets in spots that don't really make sense for the game's mechanics (which ends up in the turret being fairly useless because it's often blocked by the ship's own geometry), or the broadside fire coming out of parts of the model that don't look like they were designed for that purpose.  I wish every ship in the game was as carefully designed as the starter ships.

A boy has the right to dream......there are endless possibilities stretched out before him.Rebel Galaxy takes the classic free-form, open-world space sim a la Darkstar One, gives it amazing, brutal, fast, exciting combat, adds a strategic economy with stock market-esque line graphs, a bunch of well designed, fun-to-fly ships, pumps in some grungy western blues rock, and then throws you into the middle of your favorite outlaw studded sci-fi show. We're talking Outlaw Star, Firefly, Dark Matter, Battlestar Galactica, etc.I was initially sold on the soundtrack alone (seriously, just watch the first trailer and you'll know what I mean). I thought I would lament the loss of a Z axis in flight/combat, but because of playing on a flat plane, it plays very similar to Assassin's Creed Black Flag's ship-to-ship combat, and as such it's very smooth, easy to grasp, and fun.Pros:+ Excellent Soundtrack+ If you don't like the soundtrack, or want to add your own flair, the soundtrack can easily be replaced with your own music, separated by category (idle spacefaring, combat, space station), and your own music can be played along with the included soundtrack+ Smooth combat+ Lots of spacecraft+ Well made stock market style economy+ Planetary events add strategic value to trading+ Feels like you're right inside the Outlaw Star or Firefly universe+ Later fights are challenging, but fun+ Warping between planets is very relaxing+ Space is big. Each solar system is pretty massive, so expect to warp a lot+ Inside jokes and references to other sci-fi media is plentifulCons:- A bit grindy, especially early on- Missions are fairly repetetive- Some later fights can be brutal- Losing a big battle means going back to the last station you docked at. Dock often- No piloting small fighter craft8/10 Would soar like a leaf on the wind

												REVIEW – REBEL GALAXYIf you’ve ever prayed that Firefly would be turned into an action-packed space sim, just pour yourself a tall glass of bourbon and strap in, pardner. With the crunchiest roadhouse-cowboy soundtrack this side of the ‘verse and a visual feast that can only be described as f---ing majestic, Rebel Galaxy has been lovingly hand-crafted to appease the most deeply rooted spacelust in us all. Gods. Be. Praised.Here’s the story: Your aunt Juno, a semi notorious ne’er-do-well, has vanished under mysterious and potentially dangerous circumstances, leaving you with a junkheap of a ship and a cryptic message. You’re then set loose in the Xanthe star system (the beginner zone) to carve your own path, choose your side(s), and blast through the near and far reaches of space trying to save the old gal from her fate. And that's just the start of it.The solar systems are randomly generated but feel fully realized, with fluctuating economies, random events, and an endless torrent of side quests. The factions are pretty clear – there are “good” guys and “bad” guys, and it’s rare to help someone without♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off someone else, and you’re definitely going to be doing that. You’ll make heaps of money, buy bigger ships and WAY bigger guns, and doing lots and lots of killin’ folk, often in self defense.A majority of your time will be spent fighting nasty people and blasting around the systems for your quests, and it can feel grindy sometimes. That said, I managed to spend WAY more time than I expected doing just that without it feeling tiresome. Hell, it took me 13 hours of gameplay before I felt like finishing the story quests in the very first system, and there are 14 systems. The physics are just delicious, the visuals are head-shakingly grand, and the sound design is so good it hurts. It’s all more than enough to make you forget you had a life outside which, frankly, is kinda the point. Rebel Galaxy is heroin wrapped in crack and drowning in whiskey. So, giddyup.How I’d describe it: EVE for introverts.Score: 4 out of 5Why: Gameplay is unbelievably good. Character interactions feel a bit railroaded, but let’s be honest – that’s not why you’re playing.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Have you ever wanted to sit in the captain’s chair of an all-powerful dreadnought with enough firepower to evaporate a fleet of foes? Then this might just be the game for you.In Rebel Galaxy you take reigns of a huge ship and carve your own path through a randomly generated quadrant of space. You can choose the path of a hero and save those you meet from a vast array of pirates and rogues. Or you can fall prey to greed and debauchery, siding with the Red Devil Cartel and carve your way through every enemy that stands before you.But that being said you could choose to do neither. There is always the option to be a humble miner and strike it rich in one of the vast amounts of asteroid belts and nebulae that litter the universe. Or perhaps the life of a trader is more up your alley, with a huge amount of commodities and a living breathing market place that varies from station to station and can be influenced by every day events the choice is yours.The game looks great, it may not be the most stunning graphics available today but I loved how it looked. The ships have super details models, the stars and planets were a joy to look at. The battle effects were bombastic and colourful. Every shot from my huge broad side barrage lit up the night sky as it ripped through the hull of my enemies. The audio is fantastic too. The music chosen for the sound track really adds to the title; each song filled with a defiance that really gets the heart racing and only adds to the reminiscence of Firefly or so many spaghetti westerns that said screw you to the man. The sounds were great as well, the whirring up to using your warp drive or the blasting sounds of laser-fire as it rips through shields and hull alike. The only let down is some of the voice acting was not stellar, but what’s there is good enough to convey the story.Speaking of which the story serves only one purpose, to convey your ship from one star system to the next. Most of the adventure in this title is not from the main plot but from the tales you form yourself. Taking on a trade mission and getting ambushed in a system that is far beyond your ships abilities, warping in to help a trader being pirated by xeno scum or the joy of stumbling upon a fleet of pirates and having them throw your offer of surrender back in your face and blasting them to dust as punishment. The main plot is not bad by any means but the game is so much more.Now gameplay, there are so many facets that it would be impossible to go through them all. The main game is either menu-based, exploration or combat. The menus are as expected. But the meat of the game is its exploration, so much to see and do and the ship controls fantastically. The one drawback is turning speed; the manoeuvrability of the larger ships is very slow and can make tight turns laborious. Combat on the other hand is snappy and fast and only hindered by turning speed. But since a lot of your turrets autofire you feel like a god when your ship can decimate everything in its path on its own and when finally you bring the broadsides to bear its goodnight to whomever you are aiming at.The ships themselves are fully customizable. From engines to weapons, turrets to warp drives, even the size of your cargo hold, everything can be modified, changed and improved. Starting with the most basic of equipment you soon build a ship Mal Reynolds would be proud to call his own. From the tiniest corvette all the way to the mightiest of destroyers each has its own quirks and I enjoyed playing all of them.This game is phenomenal and will have you enraptured for hours. Some people may feel it’s a little slow to begin with or the combat is a little tricky with slow aiming, but if you can get past all that it’s a real gem and I had a whale of a time with it. Plus at full price it is still cheap I would recommend buying this all day any day sale or no.Have Fun ^_^

content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
												Takes the fun/addictive elements of freeform space sims while avoiding the over-complexity of some of these titles (such as the X-series). As usual you start with an underequipped ship and earn money for better weapons/systems, new ships, and even mercenary support if you want it. You can earn money via missions (randomly generated and storyline), trading, mining, piracy or bounty hunting; it's up to you if you want to stay the right side of the law or if you aim to misbehave. It's worth noting that your starting ship is a corvette and the ship classes only get bigger from there on (right up to massive dreadnoughts). Because you're always commanding a large ship, combat is very different from a fighter-focused space sim and as others have pointed out it the 2D movement gives a 'naval battle in space' feel to it (though faster paced); it actually works pretty well, making the battles very fun to play - which is a good thing, because there is a lot of combat in this game.Visually this has a beautiful-looking universe, some spectular space battles and a wide variety of nice ship designs (from Serenity-style rustbuckets to more conventional-looking starships). I like the fact that the different ships cater to different playstyles -  bigger isn't necessarily better as there are other factors like speed, manouverabilty and weapon placement, so instead of a linear progression to the 'best' ship, people will find their own favorite ships along the way.There are some aspects of the game that could do with some improvement such as the scaling of encounters and missions - the actual difficulty of missions doesn't always seem to match the stated risk level. Also it's quite possible to get into fights where the only chance of survival is to run, especially at the beginning of the game; though this is not a bad thing in itself, the fact that the game pops up a combat tutorial note on your first fight (even if you're totally outmatched) could confuse new players into thinking they should always be able to win their first battle. I can see why the single checkpoint-type save is controversial, but personally I'm fine with a single save AS LONG AS there is some backup in case of corrupt saves - fortunately haven't had a corrupted save yet, but would be pretty peeved if this happened after hours of play.The hillbilly rock soundtrack does help create that 'wild frontier' Firefly vibe, but it also starts to get a bit old after about 10 hours - fortunately there is an option to stream your own music - this is a great feature that allows you to select different music sources for different situations (ambient, combat, idle, station etc).Overall this is probably the most enjoyable space game I've played since Freelancer.

												This game nails that slide-guitar Firefly vibe dead-on and I cannot fully articulate just how happy this makes me!  The ship-upgrading, trading and mission-running conventions are comforting and welcome, though the plane-locked flight model is not what I'd wish for -- I miss being able to fly freely in all directions AND I DEEPLY RESENT THE NPCS WHO CAN FLY ABOVE OR BELOW MY SHIP AT WILL -- but I'm getting used to it.  Same with the  mock-capital-ship "broadsides" pew-pew combat: not my preference, but it is at least unique and interesting to figure out.  What Rebel Galaxy lacks, though, it makes up with an overall style that goes surprisingly far to make this game a lot of fun.  The character design (THOSE ALIENS!) & engine graphics are beautiful and the music is SO damn good.  I do not regret getting this game in a $7 Humble Bundle after waiting to get it for a year and a half because I am cheap.  Cool game and I hope there's a sequel because there needs to be more space-cowboy games out there, full stop.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
TL;DR: A solid, arcade space privateer game that'll scratch the itch of many a space cowboy out there, complete with excellent music to fit the theme. Fans of space games (or Firefly) may find a charmer right here for a price that wont break your wallet too hard.+ Solid gameplay mechanics and progression that'll keep you busy for hours, having fun being your own space captain. Solid combat (deflector shield = timed block, broadside ship combat), calming (if flashy) mining, and cutthroat trading are all here. Be a Han Solo, or a Boba Fett, or more.+ Quirky singleplayer storyline, but as with an open-space game like this, you can easily ignore it and go your own way. Think Skyrim + Space Cowboy and you're not far off.+ Colorful and unique art direction for environments, ships, and characters that you meet. Ships and weapons have clear design lines they follow. Enemies are color-coded for easy identification. Space is colorful and interesting to look at. Damage on ships is well-rendered, complete with breaches in the hull, burning, and metal skeletal remains in impact holes. Weapons are visually impactful, and can be clearly discerned in the heat of combat.+ Characters you meet have a lot to say, voice-acted too, complete wtih unique alien languages to boot!+ Excellent "cowboy" music that sets the mood perfectly, firing at the perfect time. Crescendos with the right track for high-intensity combat. Drops it down to a mellow tule when in station. A forlorn tune for when travelling. Its perfect, and when you dont like it, there's support for inserting your own!~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~- Camera is too zoomed in. Its difficult to keep situational awareness when the camera zooms so far in you cant see your entire ship anymore, let alone whats immediately around it.- Game's graphical fidelity with texture quality is a bit lackluster in places. Character fidelity is serviceable, whilst lip syncing is a bit off.- Space travel and combat is exclusively 2D in nature.- Minor problems here and there (the odd V/O line thats not volume-balanced, odd UI design choices, etc) detract from the game little by little. Take for example the UI display for shields and hull plating. They fade as they take more damage, when it would make more sense for them to work like bars taht decrease in size the more damaged they are to make the information more clear to the player. The default E key is used for far too many things. Default bindings may be a bit off-putting for some folk, like mistaking Secondary Fire (Shift) for Deflectors (Space) in the heat of battle. Very distinct (if not difficulty-spiking) power gaps between upgrades on equipment and ships and enemies in general. Things of that nature.- Default music may not be to the taste of some.- No multiplayer support.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												I have loved the space game genre since I was 8 years old. The fact that I am recommending this means that out of the 95% of released space sim titles I have played to death, Rebel Galaxy manages to stand out a cut above many of them. I am not even a quarterway finished with the main storyline, yet 10 hours in, the amount of content is quite impressive, and makes gameplay enjoyable to say the least. First and foremost, this is a third person spaceship simulator. There is no empire building or 4X gameplay involved. You primarily fight, trade and explore in Rebel Galaxy, and start off doing the main campaign which you can deviate from at anytime. Of course the campaign has you flying around a little bit to do other things, but fighting is usually involved. Wonderful thing here is though, interactions with NPCs in the campaign and in general allow for non-violent alternatives to do a mission, or, for instance, to handle a pirating attempt or an illegal cargo inspection by system militia. There are about a dozen solar systems in Rebel Galaxy, so you are given some wiggle room to move around. Content such as missions, NPC spawns, and solar system events are randomly generated. There is enough variety to keep things from going stale, and as you get farther away from your starting solar system, more content (ships, equipment, guild allegiances) is available to you.Combat is a bit different in Rebel Galaxy. And your ship's motion is limited to 2D movement only (while fightercraft and the environment objects can have 3D motions and positions). I will seperate this into two parts. Offensive capabilities and Defensive capabilities.Offensive capabilitiesIncludes 1) A primary weapon 2) A secondary weapon 3) Turret systems 4) Mercenaries 5) Deflectors. Primary weapons can be either pulse laser types or beam laser types. You fire broadsides (i.e from the side) at the enemies on either side. Very powerful, and include a small charging time for an auto-aim accuracy bonus. Secondary weapons are either mines or missiles (point & shoot or seeking). Good damage. Turret systems can be either pulse or laser types. You can take control of your turret groups (1 at a time only) and fire at enemies in a 360 degree arc. Critical against fightercraft and provide good sustaining damage against larger craft. Mercenaries are fightercraft/gunships that follow you around for a 1 time fee. They are very durable, are good fodder, and you can only have 1 with you at any time. Deflectors are a sort of temporary shield you can activate which absorb damage. You can also ram enemy ships with them to inflict damage.Defensive capabilities Include 1) Deflectors 2) Shields 3) Armor 4) Hull 5) Engine boosters As mentioned, Deflectors are temporary shields that asborb damage until you run out of charge, in which case you must wait for them to have charge in order to use them. Shields are divided into 4 sections that protect your ship (front, port, starboard, aft) from all damage and collisions. Armor protects your ship's hull. Damage to armor can damage to ship systems. Hull is your powercore. If it goes to 0, you die. Engine boosters can be used to maneuver weapons fire, outrun missiles, outrun foes, and kite enemies.Combat aside, the graphics are very nice and well optimized. Also, the soundtrack is wonderful, it reminds me of Firefly.As with any game, there is a bit of a grind involved to gain credits in order to unlock higher tiered ships and equipment. Best way to go about this is doing a bunch of high paying missions (mission payouts generally increase as your overall strength increases) alongside a storyline mission once in a while. Or however you want. Imo the grind doesn't feel like a grind sometimes. It's pretty fun to blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up. All in all, I dig it. Combat is different, not shallow. Plenty of content. Good soundtrack. Solid mechanics.  Decent plot. Way to go Double Damage Games. I hope you keep making titles in this genre!

Posted: March 20, 2016
												For people too wimpy for Elite Dangerous, and too suspicious of Chris RobertsGreat rock/punk-blues soundtrack that suits the "wahoo space cowboy firin' mah layzers" style.Two caveats.There's no up or down (which will be weird at first to anyone who's ever flown anything in any game), you navigate your ship across a flat plane. You can aim your guns up and down, but your ship will only steer left and right; you're flying what amount to capital ships in this game, so its not completely ridiculous logic I suppose, if nothing else it makes aiming your main broadside cannons easier. You can give the AI control over all the rest of your armaments, or you can swap to them manually at any point.  I prefer to let the AI eat away at the small fighters and crap while I focus my roflstomper on the big armored ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s with giant guns. Because it needs roflstomped. Repeatedly.Second, random asteroids and space debris knock you out of warp.  That's really annyoing because then you have to realign for warp which means moving around the random object you got hung on which is time consuming and it happens frequently; it should be more like Eve, where you do have to align and accelerate into warp speed proper but once your ship begins warp, it passes through solid objects from asteroids to planets. Its a small thing but it gets old really, really fast. There are upgrades for the warp drive but they increase warpspeed rather than improve your align time or reduce the amount of time needed to align; I would much have preferred the latter and just have maximum warp speed determined by ship class, again like in Eve.I beat the story, unlocked all the achievements (legitimately) and still find myself doing stuff in it for short stretches of time, I really enjoyed it.Probably not what you're looking for if you're a fan of either of the games referenced in the beginning though, at the very least if you come into this game looking for one of those games you'll be disappointed; I didn't know what to expect, and I like it!

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												WowThis game has blown me away. Everything from the theme down to the actual gameplay. I love the music and the look and feel of the game. Really captures that same theme that things like Firefly managed to capture.My main concern when going into this game was knowing that it didnt have full free range 3d movement. You are basically a boat, on a 2d ocean that spans in all directions. (ie: you cant go up or down like in most space sims). Shortly after playing though I realized something. You arent a space pilot in some action game. You are more like a bridge commander. Piloting and combat are more akin to something from the startrek films than being seating in the pilot seat of an X-wing.  Does this work? Yes, it does. Quite well in fact. I quickly stopped caring that I didnt have full 3d range of movement, and found myself just enjoying the "flow" of the game. The music is great btw, really helps bring the game to life.Combat is quick, and very "Edge of your seat" once you get past the first couple of tutorial battles. Sometimes you have to run. The game doesnt scale stuff to your level, and you often find yourself in over your head. Escape is a viable tactic and meant to be part of the gameplay. Dont worry though, you wont find yourself running often unless you go charging head first into some space pirate zone.The game actually has a LOT more depth to it than I expected it to. The further I played, the more features I discovered. Its so much more than just a funky space combat simulation game. I personally cant wait to play more, and really start diving in to what the game has to offer. Its got me hooked.My only real gripe is how there isnt an option to pull the camera back some during broadside combat. I feel a bit "boxed in", which really hinders my combat awareness of things around me. You can find youself crashing head first into things during broadside combat because your field of view is so limited due to how close you are zoomed in to your ship. They really need to add an option to configure the distance you want the camera to be at, or add a toggle that works similar to the camera view distance in a car racing game.The other nice feature that easily goes over looked, is how well this game performs. No performance issues, no GPU or CPU load issues. Overall its a well optomized game. (it could use a few higher quality textures here and there though)So... overall...Do you like space games?Do you like star trek style combat between big ships?Do you enjoy the backwater, wasteland themed style of Firefly?If so, I highly recommend this game.

												tl;dr: If you loved Freelancer, Starpoint Gemini 2, or any of the 2D/top-down "open world" space combat/mining/trading games, buy this immediately.I never write reviews, but man, this game. This game hits way out of its weight class. Watch the trailers, listen to the music - the whole soundtrack is that awesome, and they match tracks to gameplay so darn well. The characters, the music, the ships - the whole vibe fits right alongside Firefly or Cowboy Bebop.But how about gameplay?This game is darn near everything that I loved about Freelancer - open choices about alignment, how you wish to accumulate wealth (with net worth being the best equivalent to RPG "level"), and so many over-the-top, very expensive upgrades available beyond what's needed to "finish" the game that's any space grinder's paradise.It only deviates from that mold on three critical points, by order of significance:1) Combat is dramatically different.  This is not, and does not pretend to be, a dogfighting/piloting simulation. There is nothing that approaches "real" inertia. You have two axes of freedom (yaw and velocity front-to-back), not six. In that respect, think of it like SPAZ or other 2D space games, but with phenomenal graphics. This game is 2.5D, not 3D.But it works. Combat is less adrenaline-fueled flips and rolls, and more stately dance of large ships, where positioning far outstrips reflexes - half way between something twitchy like Elite: Dangerous and point-and-click orders of EVE Online. Everything you fly is a "capital ship" and mostly behaves like one. (That's not to say there aren't plenty of size class upgrades - you could double-park your starting ship in the exhaust ports of some of the larger ones.) This plays more like AC: Black Flag's naval battles, in that your biggest (and manually controlled) weapons are mounted broadside, so this is big ships barrelling up side-by-side to blast the hell out of each other.  In an interesting conceit, fighters are given 3D flight capabilities and can fly over and under you, while capital ships (you and AI) are stuck on a 2D field - 3D flight is there, just for the annoying gnats that you don't fly.So combat can take a while, and it'll feel dull to the adrenaline junkies, but it's just the right mellow level of exciting for the person who finds RPG combat exciting and laments their survival skills in FPS deathmatches against all the coked-up squirrels who make your reflexes look like dial-up latency. (So... me.)2) The world is just plain smaller. Systems are bigger, but there's only about a dozen of them. There aren't a whole lot of factions or terribly interesting power dynamics between factions. But you know what? This wasn't a $50 or $60 game. I felt like there was a totally reasonable, if not Freelancer-scale, level of world available to be for the price tag. Should they ever decide to DLC in more content, I'll be first in line: it would be a better game for it, and completely reasonable to come with an additional price tag, given what the base game sells for.3) No multiplayer (or the accompanying dedicated server). This one's a bummer, as the only thing I like more than this genre is this genre with friends, but that's a big jump in development complexity for a budget title. So it doesn't feel like a glaring omission or a developer shortcoming (and indeed, leaving it out of scope is better than a broken implementation), but I would love to see a Rebel Galaxy 2 with full multiplayer support Freelancer style.Otherwise, this thing is dreamy. Every time I find an annoyance in this game, it's because the level of graphical polish, voice acting, and audio design fool me into thinking I'm playing a big-budget AAA title. Then I remember the price tag, and I'm again floored how hard this game hits for its budget.

												It's what the first Starpoint Gemini would have been if it wasn't developed by slav♥♥♥♥♥, but with a spaghetti-western twang to it.This is NOTHING AT ALL LIKE FREELANCER.This game is NOTHING AT ALL LIKE ANYTHING IN ASASSIN\'S CREED.This game is NOTHING LIKE COWBOY BEBOP OR FIREFLY... it just has a couple tracks featuring a guitar --- ooooooooooh that's firefly! ooooooooooooh ride my hype-stick ooooooooooooh space cowboys - no... just no... it's Starpoint Gemini with a country track in the mix.Do not ride people's hype trains, because actual flavors of what people hype up like that simply don't exist.Which all-in-all is very very sad because this game has a lot of good things going for it that stand out on it's own without being lumped into incredibly vauge and generalized references... just don't expect as much as people are claiming is there, because again, it simply isn't. GAMEPLAY:Quick. Don't expect tonnes of hours unless you force yourself to drag the game out.Fun. Really fun - I couldn't put it down for the first few days (then I beat the story and stopped caring because I had the best ship and gear, period)Equally proffitable to trade or fight your way up (I got lucky abnd kept finding clouds of things called "face of gozu" so my fight-intended gameplay did turn to occasional crude mining to leap forward in the game FAST)All of the exact flippin' same mechanics from Starpoint Gemini, meaning the whole game takes place on a two-dimensional plane... in space...CONS:Well I honestly hate how much like the first Starpoint Gemini it is. It's often distracting, and I had PTSD-like flashbacks of the most horrible russian voice acting you could possibly imagine...The story is... terribad. I didn't care... I just COULD NOT care about anything that was happening and everyone and their dog all looked like either targets or speed-bumps in my pursuit to become the biggest, baddest mo-fo in space.Only need one possible conversation choice ever: "Get behind me, meat-pop, and watch how it's done."I didn't even get interested until, I kid you not, the very very end where the AI you are hauling around starts to actually BE a flippin CHARACTER present in the nearly non-existant plot line. Not enough ships.After the storyine ends, if you have the biggest and best like I did by that time, the game becomes quite literally - pointless. When you DO reach that point, you are so OP, no fleet generated to fight you can take you down unless you get jumped while taking an afk dump.Comparing this to Freelancer is a huge insult to Freelancer and Chris Roberts - whoever does that owes Mr. Roberts an apology. Freelancer is a benchmark standard in space-traders/space-sandboxes... and this DOES NOT meet par with Freelancer on any grounds of reasoning.WHY YOU SHOULD BUY: Because when you get rid of the slimy hype that would otherwise leave you dissappointed in not getting what was so highly promised in praise - it's a kick♥♥♥♥♥space trader that lets you roam around in a rather large sandbox and blow the crap out of nearly everything in sight.It's very simplistic and very easy to learn and master, and is also controller compatable - though KBM is best for this game.Overall I give it 7/10 - best to wait and get it when it's on sale. Cheap.

												It has a firefly theme to it (the music especially). Which is awesome.Game plays on a 2D plane. You basically fly around doing missions (basically kill missions, or fly into a bunch of guys and take something and leave while they try to kill you missions). As you fly around you get blockaded by enemies who you have to fly through/around to get back to warp. As you fly around you also run into distress beacons you can go to and either fall into a trap or come to someone's aid while they are getting killed.Basically killing is the only real solution to anything in this game. I think that's it's major weakness.The commodities market is pretty lame. You can only put a few things in your holds and most stores never sell enough of anything to fill your holds to do proper buy/sell trading. And even if they did, it's almost never going to be all of the good stuff with a good price. Otherwise this system could be pretty fun if it was balanced and actually changed with supply/demand. All in all it's fun for a while. Then it gets grindy. Then it gets really grindy. Then you use cheats and give yourself all the money you want. Then you go out and realize there's nothing else to the game and you quit. If you can get this for $5, I'd buy it for some over simplified naval combat in space with the firefly theme to it. But while this game engine is good enough for some pretty awesome gameplay....sadly, it is pretty void of good content.Almost great.

content:
Posted: February 12
												THE GOOD:This is a game that is visually beautiful, with great graphics and sound.  For instance, the details on damage your hull takes is, for lack of a better word, gorgeous.  High production values all around.THE BAD:Wow, I just can't get into the gameplay at ALL.  Take all the parts that aren't fun about World of Warcraft, and combine them with all the parts that aren't fun about X3: Reunion.  -Shallow RPG elements.  Shallow dialogue choices.  Shallow, linear plotline buried in a sandbox game.-An "open world sandbox" that is mostly empty, and is in TWO dimensions.  (This is a space game.)  -Grinding the same bounty quests over and over for money for upgrades.   -Combat is similar to space battles in Star Trek Online, but shallower, with less strategy and fewer options.  I kept wishing for the officer abilities of STO to give it some variance.-3/4th of the enemy you face are starfighters, which you have to bat away with your turrets. Fighters move in three dimensions; you do not.  To help you hit them, your reticule locks onto them and follows them around.  So you're pretty much just flying in a circle and holding down the fire button.  Against 3/4 of the enemies you face.-Oh, and by the way, you know that cool "Evil Ways" song in the preview movie on the store page?  Well, you'll think it's alot less cool when you start playing because that song (in rotation with perhaps two others) is your constant companion as you amble around the universe looking for mobs to grind. THE VERDICT:Dull.  There isn't much more to this game than the combat, and I can tell the combat is supposed to feel a lot more exciting than it does.  When you streamline something to a certain degree, it moves past "stream-lined" and ventures into the dangerous realm of "dumbed-down."  The combat feels dumbed-down, the trading feels dumbed-down, and the RPG elements feel dumbed-down. After playing for about an hour and a half, all I want to do is reinstall X3 so I can play a game that does all of these elements correctly.  Glad I got this at a discount, but I still wish I could take this purchase back.

Take cover behind asteroids to avoid incoming fire from enemy, Take cover behind enemy ships to avoid fire. Maybe features like cloaking (you can detect every ship with a simples can, th game needs a system like world of warships), sideway boosts or big space battles with way more ships but a tactical feature to command and order friendly ships to win battles. (stop the game like the scannermode give us a overview and command features)- Market system is to simple after a while and it should add new goods if you get to new systems or have individual goods that you can sell in different systems and more economical possibilitys.- Random events like distress calls or bountys are great but two features get boring pretty fast- Events on planets have a good impact on the econemy features but some events don't effect the prices as much as they should in my opinion. - Rewards for e.x. destroying big battleships or pirate kings are inconsistent and don't scale properly- And last but not least my most important complain:The missions are too similar and there are only a handful of Story missions. So for now, as regrettable as it is, I can't wholeheartly recommend for you to buy this game.

												This is yet another game where I wish I could give a middle rank, neither a yes or a no, but a "meh" rating too, however since the game is cheap, and has very good production values, and is fun for a little while, Ill give it the up vote.Anyway, you can watch some videos to see what kind of game this is about, however, Ill just get into some of my gripes with the game design.Some minor issues that annoy me:1.  Missions are over scripted and in a way are not realistic.  For example, every time you have do a trade-guild mission to ship some specific cagro from point A to B, you will ALWAYS be intercepted.  There is ALWAYs trouble.   Now if this were the only problem, I could overlook this.  The actual problem is that the REAL trade mission is to actually destroy the guys who intercept you.  Case and point, I took a very lucrative delivery mission that took place in  the same system.  It was rated as HIGH risk.   I figued I could run away.  My mission is to deliver something, not kill things?  RIght?  Oh no, quite wrong.   So I am getting close to the station I need to make my delivery to, and as usual, the trap is sprung and a bunch of ships appear from all directions and they pull you out of "warp".    So what do I do? I escape, I use my after burners and get enough distance and jump back into warp.  I make it like 5 clicks and the same trap happens again.  I do this 2 more times and each time the trap is reset and sprung again which is just terrible game design.  The only solution is to kill the ambush.  All mission types that are not supposed to be directly about combat workout the same way.2.  You can have missles as weapons, the problem with them is that you do not have a lot of ammo, which makes sense.  However, if you are an NPC, then you have infinite ammo.  I once had a ship that shot waves of missiles the killed my engines.  The didn't do any damage to my ship or shields, but I couldn't move.  It just sat there for like 10 minutes keeping me pinned.  I had to Alt-F4 to recover because if you exit normally, it would save your game and I would have been stuck forever.3.  No quick save.Ok, enough of the small sutff.  Why did I stop playing this game without finishing the main story?  What is the big thing that is wrong with the game design?Basically it is repetivie and boring.  Combat is boring.  Flying around in space warping everwhere is boring.  Each star system is randomly generated, but they are all very generic and you can't really tell the difference other than this sone might have a yellow sun and the other one has a blue sun.   There is nothing to explore or find.  Its all the same, everywhere.Now maybe if you LOVE space games you may get a lot more milage out of it then I did, but after about 20 hours the game felt more like work then fun.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												Well, just finished my first game of this, so I figured it was time for a review. So, where to start?Well, I'll start basic. This game is basically what it looks like: a space trucker sim with combat that is similar to the ship-to-ship combat in Assassins Creed: Black Flag, with the primary weapons being broadside cannons and turrets. If you've heard that this game starts out kinda crappy, you heard right. The starting ship (a Hammerhead called the "Rasputin") is exactly what the intro cinematic says it is: a near-derelict ship with lousy hull & shielding, and the cannons are more akin to pop guns than actual weapons.But that's the whole point, isn't it? You build yourself up by killing baddies, taking quests, maybe mining some, although I personally avoided mining as much as I could in this game. (Too boring.) The idea is to earn enough cash so you can spend it on upgrading your ship's weapons, shields and armor to the point that enemies that once gave you a mountain of trouble will now regret ever♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥you off... right before their ships explode and you suck up whatever cargo they dropped.[As an extra note, some games may think it's cool to have increased prices for purchases, lowered prices for sales. Not this one! Here, if you purchase a turret for 5,000 credits and then decide to sell it later (possibly because you'd just picked up a better version), you'll still receive 5,000 credits back. Same goes for hull, shield, and engine upgrades.]And of course you'll want to swap out your starting ship for a better one as quickly as possible. One with more turret slots, more broadside cannons, more cargo space, and a better hull. You'll also want to purchase some special components for your ship, like Heat Management which reduces the amount of heat your turrets generate when firing, allowing them to fire more often.Which brings me to weapon setups. When it comes to setting up your strategy, your first perrogative will be to find a setup which works for you. Personally, I ran with Tachyon broadsides for their fast rate of fire, Heatseekers for secondary weapons, and my turret of choice was the Pulse variant for their range & damage per shot, although I do recommend equipping a Korian Viridian laser cannon if you happen to find one. (I managed to find two, one a Mrk 2, the other a Mrk 5 late in the game.)Your second concern will be learning how best to maneuver in a high-tension battle. This is a 2D arena, so you won't have to worry about capital ships hitting you from above or below. But fighters will swarm around you, attempting to knock out your shields so their bigger cousins can finish you off. And by the way, your shields deplete based on which side gets hit, meaning that if you take too many hits to starboard, your starboard hull will be exposed and vulnerable; take too many hits to starboard after that, you're a goner. Oh yeah, I've had a couple of deaths where the shields were still strong on everywhere except where the enemy was currently hitting me en masse.Here's my pro strategy though: when engaged in a pitched battle, move out to the sidelines to draw the fighters away and have your turrets take those out first. After which, you'll want to position yourself so the capital ships will be on only one side at a time. Then throttle down so that you can turn faster as needed. Just keep fire broadsides at them while your turrets provide backup, and when your shields on that side start to lose their charge, turn around so the other side will be facing them and then repeat the procedure.However, there is something I should mention: up until the third star system, your main obstacle is pirates who fire nothing but regular rounds and missiles at you. Once you get to the third system, however, you'll meet the Greel. These guys (both their fighters and their capital ships) feature Leech weapons which fire EMP missiles at you. And these things  not only do a good amount of damage to your shields, but they do a number on your engines as well. So your best bet is to get the EMP Ablation component (what the hell kind of word is that?) so that EMP weapons won't cause quite as much trouble.Nevertheless, a well-upgraded ship can handle just about anything. Just find the style and setup that works best for you and get out there. Just remember if things start to go♥♥♥♥♥♥up, there ain't no shame in making a run for it. All the money in the galaxy won't comfort you if you're dead.As the game itself, it's single player only and can be played offline if you please. Although you won't be able to make progress on achievements without being online, I found out. Also, the musical tracks they used in this game, while good, can get really repetitive; I ended up muting it. And if there's one gameplay feature I'm iffy about, it's that the best lasers in the game (the Korian Viridians) are random drops, no way to purchase them in a spaceport.There's also the issue with communications with the npcs in the game: they're pretty limited. Not to mention that the pirates seem to have trouble realizing when they're outmatched and that surrender would be in their best interest. Like I'll be flying an Arcturus-class Destroyer (which is strongly reminiscent of the Imperial Star Destroyer from Star Wars) armed to the teeth with top-notch weapons and they'll still be talking♥♥♥♥♥♥.. right up until I blow them to smithereens.And speaking of the AI, there's the escort missions. Now, the way it works is that you fly to a location, approach the client, and hold down E to Pair Warp. What that does is that the AI takes full control of your ship, keeping it alongside the ship even as you two go into warp. Noble in itself but it can lead to some annoying results. For one, when two ships are alongside each other, a human would say that the best course of action is to throttle down and turn right to line up with the client; the AI meanwhile turns your ship left, causing your back section to collide with the client's. And why is it that every escort mission has to start in an asteroid field or a ice field? Because just now I had a mission start in an ice field, I was flying a dreadnaught and it took 5-10 minutes just to get started! The AI kept maneuvering us around the ice field, taking me one direction him another. And just when I thought we were getting out of this mess, it had the client move back into the field, prolonging this mess. I had to break warp pairing, and move my ship out of the ice field myself just to get us going.Was I annoyed by all of this? Yeah, I'd say it goes without saying that I was.Then there are the missions where you fly in and save someone from enroaching hostiles. There's a good chance they'll get themselves blown up because they decided to fly into the middle of a pack of hostiles. And as Harrison Ford said in The Last Crusade "Are you crazy?!? Don't go between 'em!!"All in all though, it's a good game, well-worth the asking price. Combat can get a little challenging at times (especially with the Greel I mentioned above) but it's easy to learn & of moderate difficulty to master, just the way I like it. And if all that wasn't enough, the developers also made sure to include a risk analysis for each mission that adjusts based upon anticipated enemy strength against that of your own. And while not all the ship designs are prize-winners, there are some really good ones.So yes, I definitely recommend this game. It's cheap, it's challenging, and it'll last a long time. Hell, there're some triple-A titles that won't last as long as this game will! [cough, cough... Star Wars Battlefront: EA... cough, cough]

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												This is yet another game where I wish I could give a middle rank, neither a yes or a no, but a "meh" rating too, however since the game is cheap, and has very good production values, and is fun for a little while, Ill give it the up vote.Anyway, you can watch some videos to see what kind of game this is about, however, Ill just get into some of my gripes with the game design.Some minor issues that annoy me:1.  Missions are over scripted and in a way are not realistic.  For example, every time you have do a trade-guild mission to ship some specific cagro from point A to B, you will ALWAYS be intercepted.  There is ALWAYs trouble.   Now if this were the only problem, I could overlook this.  The actual problem is that the REAL trade mission is to actually destroy the guys who intercept you.  Case and point, I took a very lucrative delivery mission that took place in  the same system.  It was rated as HIGH risk.   I figued I could run away.  My mission is to deliver something, not kill things?  RIght?  Oh no, quite wrong.   So I am getting close to the station I need to make my delivery to, and as usual, the trap is sprung and a bunch of ships appear from all directions and they pull you out of "warp".    So what do I do? I escape, I use my after burners and get enough distance and jump back into warp.  I make it like 5 clicks and the same trap happens again.  I do this 2 more times and each time the trap is reset and sprung again which is just terrible game design.  The only solution is to kill the ambush.  All mission types that are not supposed to be directly about combat workout the same way.2.  You can have missles as weapons, the problem with them is that you do not have a lot of ammo, which makes sense.  However, if you are an NPC, then you have infinite ammo.  I once had a ship that shot waves of missiles the killed my engines.  The didn't do any damage to my ship or shields, but I couldn't move.  It just sat there for like 10 minutes keeping me pinned.  I had to Alt-F4 to recover because if you exit normally, it would save your game and I would have been stuck forever.3.  No quick save.Ok, enough of the small sutff.  Why did I stop playing this game without finishing the main story?  What is the big thing that is wrong with the game design?Basically it is repetivie and boring.  Combat is boring.  Flying around in space warping everwhere is boring.  Each star system is randomly generated, but they are all very generic and you can't really tell the difference other than this sone might have a yellow sun and the other one has a blue sun.   There is nothing to explore or find.  Its all the same, everywhere.Now maybe if you LOVE space games you may get a lot more milage out of it then I did, but after about 20 hours the game felt more like work then fun.
