content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy is a thoroughly enjoyable space RPG-style game.  The game page and other reviews do a good job of providing more detail on the gameplay, so I won't waste too much time covering that.  Basically, it's a naval combat game in space (movement is in 2D only).  That being said, this style in no way detracts from the game's value.  You spend your time doing missions, mining, trading, and/or hunting bounties to make money which goes toward upgrading your ship.  There is also a "main campaign" that takes you through a simple yet adequately interesting story.  On the downside, the factions are a bit bland (as is mentioned in several other reviews) and there really doesn't seem to be much replayability (at least I personally have no desire to replay now that I've beaten the game).If you want to pew-pew other spaceships in a beautifully rendered, decent sized "universe" while listening to an admittedly catchy soundtrack (seemingly ranging in influence from CCR to Pearl Jam at times) then this game is worth looking into.  It runs smoothly with no bugs or glitches (for me, anyway).  Ultimately, I found the game experience to be well worth the cost.8.5/10

												Rebel Galaxy is a light hearted space sim, borrowing ideas from games such as Sid Mier's Pirates! and others. Graphically styled like Galaxy on Fire and Torchlight, it's a pretty game that runs smoothly other than when using the warp gate (no big issue really, they're used infrequently). Controls work nicely with both mouse/KB or controller. The game offers plenty of ship customisation, do you want to be a ship of the line with massive broadsides? Or perhaps a gunboat bristling with turrets? Maybe you want to long-haul goods across the system? Heaps of options for you to try out.My only real negatives so far;1) Not enough music, the music in the game is AMAZING, but the sound track needs to be a little longer I think2) Stop dropping me out of super-cruise etc when near asteroids etc, if I can visually plot a safe way through a field, then let me. :DSeriously though, this game is amazing value for $18, if you like space sim-lite, this is your game, or just want to blow up ships across the galaxy, look no futher.9/10, definately recomend.

												After playing several hours of this game I can say without a doubt, Rebel Galaxy is AMAZING. *It's the perfect blend of action packed navel combat with dynamic trade economy. If you thought X was an interesting concept, but though that the gameplay felt like doing spread sheets in a 3D shooting gallery, then look no further, Rebel Galaxy is your game. *The combat is fun and easy to pick up, with its Black Flag style broadside combat, but has alot of depth and strategy aswell. I found that a fast frigate could out do a powerful, lumbering dreadknoght with speed and manuverability, or that using your ship's suppior broadside's range could keep you out of harms way. *The economy is dynamic and interesting but not overly complicated "cough cough X!" and scoping out trade roughts in the games massive, proceduraly generated universe was alot of fun.*The style was another big draw with it's awesome southern rock/blues/country soundtrack and it's wild west, bad-side of town vibe. Not to mention, the ship models are fantastic!*The game also has alot of choice for missions and encounters. Do you help the pirates take down the merchant for a haul of loot, or do you take a stand and protect the merchant to increase your reputation with the citizens?*And finnaly, the devs are great. They're helpful and dedicated and constantly patching the game and listening to the communityIn the end, Rebel Galaxy is a terrific, deep space, swashbuckling adventure sure to keep you flyin' for along time.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy looks like an odd game to start with. How many games are there that have you flying around space, buying, selling, mining or stealing? I have played quite a few over the years. Most of them have you moving around in 3 dimensions; after all, space is not flat plane is it? So, why does Rebel Galaxy use two dimensions for you as the player but 3 for many of your opponents? Surely this is silly?Surprisingly I have to say no, it actually works really well. I am around 4 hours into the game now and I must say that I like the battle mechanics and the flight from one part of the system to another is pretty smooth. (Could be a bit quicker possibly but that is just me.So, what is it that I enjoy? Raking your opponent from stem to stern using broadsides in space is cool. This is why the game is on a flat plane. By using your main weapons as broadsides it would not work if you had to roll to bring your guns to bear.The ecomomic system seems to work well, I like the way that when buying or selling you can see the average price in the sector. This will reduce the need for notes or trying to remember how much you paid for nuts and bolts, yes this is a real cargo. I like the idea of cola being illegal btw :-)I think that this is one that I will be playing for some time. It has been on my wish list since its release and in the sale I thought I would go for it. Now, the big question is would I have still enjoyed it at full price? So far I have to say yes I would have. There are loads of missions to do, a storyline to follow or if you just want to blow up asteroids for ore you can. There are loads floating round.You can configure your weaponry easily, with plenty of ships to fly , I haven't seen any dodgy models yet, all looking rather swish.So, go and buy the game if you like flying in space, blowing things up, mining or finding lost relatives. You won't regret it.Should have said about the music. Cant think of ANY game that has more fitting music!

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												I knew I was making a good choice when I decided to put this game on my watch list before release to buy it upon release day and man I was not dissapointed, this game is a great and beautiful alternative to Elite: Dangerous, X: Rebirth, easy to use, straightforward controls, if all you want to do is go about blowing stuff up without grinding through trades for hours on end before you can do so then this is the game to buy! The soundtrack for the game is very relaxing on long journeys, not that the journeys are long to begin with, at least not by the last games mentioned standards and there's no going back and forth to take and complete missions, all you need to do is simply go to a station, pick up a mission and complete it and the money will be automatically rewarded to you without the need for travelling all the way back to the place you picked the mission up from.Here's a pros and cons list for those who want a more straightforward run down.Please note that I haven't ventured further than the beginning system at the time of this review, these are based on what I've experianced so far.PROS:-Great soundtrack.-I can run the game on max settings without lag on a low grade 1GB GPU and a 2.8 dual core CPU-Easy to use controls.-No back and forth missions (aside from the story missions)-Beautiful scenery-AI behaviour for turrets and your wingman (should you choose to hire)-Accurate mission ratings from very low to very high (go into high and very high ranked missions carefully)-Nice balance of strengths and weaknesses between ships and equipmentCONS:-Price jump in higher grade ships and equipment is quite large-high risk missions (which often involves killing multiple ships) rewards the same amount of credits as some bounties which are much easier.-Faction relations don't give much benefit asides from that faction deciding to shoot you or not and allow you to dock at stations.-It's hard to manually target anything that you have to pan the camera to target with turrets (or maybe that's just lack of skill on my part)-While I do like the intention of the mechanic it can get somewhat annoying when you are pulled out of warp drive by an asteroid field on a regular basis because you couldn't see it coming and are suddenly smack in the middle of it after managing to avoid some asterdoids by pure luck and end up having to manually fly through it before you can go into hyper again.

Posted: October 28, 2015
												I am going to make this as simple as possible:PROS* Awesome soundtrack!* It's like Firefly, with aliens...* Lots of ships, lots of gear!* There is a story, but it's not required to enjoy the game!* Combat is fast and furious.* Lots of potential for future content.* Random galaxy with each new character.CONS* It's space, but it's not a 3D experience... wut?* No multiplayer... here's a suggestion: Rebel Galaxy: Empires (MMO)* Travel is very time consuming which means a long grind for good gear.* While the soundtrack is awesome, the limited number of tracks becomes repetitive.* Ship customization/personalization is unavailable (paintjobs)* Combat can be a bit chaotic at times. I find, by the time I get to precise targeting, the battle is over.* No crew or ship boarding. No hijacking of other ships.* It feels empty at times... I have a HUGE ship. Where are my crew? Better crew, better performance?All in all, I am 8 hours into the game and JUST traveled to the second system. It's very easy to get lost in just existing in the galaxy without ever chasing the storyline. RG has incredible potential to be one of those games that I just play when I have nothing else to do. I can jump on, do a few missions, and jump off. I can play one character as a law abiding merchant that helps others and keeps their nose clean, and then start another character to join up with pirates and be a menace to the galaxy. There are many missed opportunities (3D galaxy, multiplayer, crews, explorable stations, actual character creation, etc) but there is a lot of room for them to expand on the game in the future. As it stands currently, it is a game I will use as a time filler when I just want to kick back, relax, and enjoy a stress-free gaming experience.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												This is yet another game where I wish I could give a middle rank, neither a yes or a no, but a "meh" rating too, however since the game is cheap, and has very good production values, and is fun for a little while, Ill give it the up vote.Anyway, you can watch some videos to see what kind of game this is about, however, Ill just get into some of my gripes with the game design.Some minor issues that annoy me:1.  Missions are over scripted and in a way are not realistic.  For example, every time you have do a trade-guild mission to ship some specific cagro from point A to B, you will ALWAYS be intercepted.  There is ALWAYs trouble.   Now if this were the only problem, I could overlook this.  The actual problem is that the REAL trade mission is to actually destroy the guys who intercept you.  Case and point, I took a very lucrative delivery mission that took place in  the same system.  It was rated as HIGH risk.   I figued I could run away.  My mission is to deliver something, not kill things?  RIght?  Oh no, quite wrong.   So I am getting close to the station I need to make my delivery to, and as usual, the trap is sprung and a bunch of ships appear from all directions and they pull you out of "warp".    So what do I do? I escape, I use my after burners and get enough distance and jump back into warp.  I make it like 5 clicks and the same trap happens again.  I do this 2 more times and each time the trap is reset and sprung again which is just terrible game design.  The only solution is to kill the ambush.  All mission types that are not supposed to be directly about combat workout the same way.2.  You can have missles as weapons, the problem with them is that you do not have a lot of ammo, which makes sense.  However, if you are an NPC, then you have infinite ammo.  I once had a ship that shot waves of missiles the killed my engines.  The didn't do any damage to my ship or shields, but I couldn't move.  It just sat there for like 10 minutes keeping me pinned.  I had to Alt-F4 to recover because if you exit normally, it would save your game and I would have been stuck forever.3.  No quick save.Ok, enough of the small sutff.  Why did I stop playing this game without finishing the main story?  What is the big thing that is wrong with the game design?Basically it is repetivie and boring.  Combat is boring.  Flying around in space warping everwhere is boring.  Each star system is randomly generated, but they are all very generic and you can't really tell the difference other than this sone might have a yellow sun and the other one has a blue sun.   There is nothing to explore or find.  Its all the same, everywhere.Now maybe if you LOVE space games you may get a lot more milage out of it then I did, but after about 20 hours the game felt more like work then fun.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												Love being a space cowboy in Rebel Galaxy, it just feels good to fly around and fight other ships! Graphics are amazing even on my mid-level system, my jaw dropped when I first loaded up the game. My laptop has a hard time running it though.Great pacing, lots of things to do; explore the solar systems, smuggle cargo between space stations, start fights with space pirates and steal their cargo, sell loot and upgrade your weapons...buy a new ship once you've saved up enough.I also like how you can customize your ship to fit different playstyles, there's no wrong answer, combat always feels intense and rewarding. Outfit long range cannons and missles to snipe opponents from afar, for medium range fightfights use blaster turrets and rockets, or cover your ship in lasers to cut ships apart up close! You also get to pick whether you prefer a huge tank-like ship or a sleek corvette, customize your speed and durability based on your play style. There are no levels, the more money you make the better ships and equipment you can afford, so buy trade items low, stock your hold with valuables, and sell to the buyers offering the most at the commodity markets at the space stations.One other thing I love is the music. Not only does it come with great music by default, you can use your own MP3 collection, and it will change songs for Ambient, Combat, Idle, Menu, and Space Station. So I made folders for each music type, copied songs that fit the mood into the folders, and added those folders to the game's music library. So when I'm cruising through space I can enjoy some low key Beck and Radiohead, but when a fight breaks out the game will start blasting Green Day or the Klaxons!Buy it! Don't even hesitate, don't even worry, don't even give it a second thought.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy is a thoroughly enjoyable space RPG-style game.  The game page and other reviews do a good job of providing more detail on the gameplay, so I won't waste too much time covering that.  Basically, it's a naval combat game in space (movement is in 2D only).  That being said, this style in no way detracts from the game's value.  You spend your time doing missions, mining, trading, and/or hunting bounties to make money which goes toward upgrading your ship.  There is also a "main campaign" that takes you through a simple yet adequately interesting story.  On the downside, the factions are a bit bland (as is mentioned in several other reviews) and there really doesn't seem to be much replayability (at least I personally have no desire to replay now that I've beaten the game).If you want to pew-pew other spaceships in a beautifully rendered, decent sized "universe" while listening to an admittedly catchy soundtrack (seemingly ranging in influence from CCR to Pearl Jam at times) then this game is worth looking into.  It runs smoothly with no bugs or glitches (for me, anyway).  Ultimately, I found the game experience to be well worth the cost.8.5/10

content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												I never write reviews, and I only do so for games that I think are that much fun, that I need to tell everyone!Rebel Galaxy is a weird thing, it combines "naval" combat with space ships and quite some options to (role) play the game.The combat, is in one word, different. You fly in 2D space, as the rest of the capital ships do, and only the lighter fighters are able to fly everywhere, but you only fly capital ships.If you want someone to explain on how you should tackle the combat in this game, then dont read this, I think you should totally find that out yourself. There are some really powerfull combinations but almost everything works together if you set it up logically.In ways how to play the game, there are different factions. the Citizens are what the name says, these people just want to live and inhabit most of the stations.The Militia are a military 'police' faction, taking down pirates but also stopping illegal trading.The Merchant Guild and Mercenaries Guild are a thing of their own. The Merchants are traders and specialize in getting cargo through the system. You can join them if you want to focus on trading with stations, because the trading and goods system in this game is quite fleshed out!The Mercenaries supply contracts to you if you join them, also giving you access to better equipment, like most factions do in the game when you join them. content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												I've only put a few hours into this game so far, and I'm enjoying it immensely. Broadly, Rebel Galaxy reminds me of a mashup of the Assassin's Creed series, World of Warships, and good old Freelancer. The former because the way that the map and locations work (markers and missions within the system map), the second because of the similar broadside naval combat mechanic (which, given the lack of a traversable Z axis [for simplicity's sake] in the game, works surprisingly well), and the latter because...well, you fly around in space and do whatever you want for a career.Rebel Galaxy is very smooth. Everything looks wonderful, the theme music and some of the game's feel are obvious homages to Firefly and Serenity, but the overall experience is pretty fresh. While the exploration and side mission elements of gameplay can get redundant (see Assassin's Creed), the constantly evolving state of your own ship keep things fairly interesting. The difficulty curve can be a little intense. Like AC, this is forgiven somewhat because the game autosaves every time you leave dock, but there are a number of bloody lessons to be learned early on while you learn how to poke around the galaxy without dying with some frequency.Combat mechanics are very nifty. In addition to hired help and the already highlighted broadside combat system, turrets, auxiliary weapons, and various modules help keep combat pretty fresh and interesting. Plus it all looks very pretty, and blowing up pirate capital ships is viscerally satisfying in a way that Eve never accomplished.Very, very recommendable to fans of any of the above listed titles (disparate though they may seem), as long as you dig things in space. A great, sandboxy capital ship combat game that really WORKS, unlike so many halfhearted efforts.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												Well, just finished my first game of this, so I figured it was time for a review. So, where to start?Well, I'll start basic. This game is basically what it looks like: a space trucker sim with combat that is similar to the ship-to-ship combat in Assassins Creed: Black Flag, with the primary weapons being broadside cannons and turrets. If you've heard that this game starts out kinda crappy, you heard right. The starting ship (a Hammerhead called the "Rasputin") is exactly what the intro cinematic says it is: a near-derelict ship with lousy hull & shielding, and the cannons are more akin to pop guns than actual weapons.But that's the whole point, isn't it? You build yourself up by killing baddies, taking quests, maybe mining some, although I personally avoided mining as much as I could in this game. (Too boring.) The idea is to earn enough cash so you can spend it on upgrading your ship's weapons, shields and armor to the point that enemies that once gave you a mountain of trouble will now regret ever♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥you off... right before their ships explode and you suck up whatever cargo they dropped.[As an extra note, some games may think it's cool to have increased prices for purchases, lowered prices for sales. Not this one! Here, if you purchase a turret for 5,000 credits and then decide to sell it later (possibly because you'd just picked up a better version), you'll still receive 5,000 credits back. Same goes for hull, shield, and engine upgrades.]And of course you'll want to swap out your starting ship for a better one as quickly as possible. One with more turret slots, more broadside cannons, more cargo space, and a better hull. You'll also want to purchase some special components for your ship, like Heat Management which reduces the amount of heat your turrets generate when firing, allowing them to fire more often.Which brings me to weapon setups. When it comes to setting up your strategy, your first perrogative will be to find a setup which works for you. Personally, I ran with Tachyon broadsides for their fast rate of fire, Heatseekers for secondary weapons, and my turret of choice was the Pulse variant for their range & damage per shot, although I do recommend equipping a Korian Viridian laser cannon if you happen to find one. (I managed to find two, one a Mrk 2, the other a Mrk 5 late in the game.)Your second concern will be learning how best to maneuver in a high-tension battle. This is a 2D arena, so you won't have to worry about capital ships hitting you from above or below. But fighters will swarm around you, attempting to knock out your shields so their bigger cousins can finish you off. And by the way, your shields deplete based on which side gets hit, meaning that if you take too many hits to starboard, your starboard hull will be exposed and vulnerable; take too many hits to starboard after that, you're a goner. Oh yeah, I've had a couple of deaths where the shields were still strong on everywhere except where the enemy was currently hitting me en masse.Here's my pro strategy though: when engaged in a pitched battle, move out to the sidelines to draw the fighters away and have your turrets take those out first. After which, you'll want to position yourself so the capital ships will be on only one side at a time. Then throttle down so that you can turn faster as needed. Just keep fire broadsides at them while your turrets provide backup, and when your shields on that side start to lose their charge, turn around so the other side will be facing them and then repeat the procedure.However, there is something I should mention: up until the third star system, your main obstacle is pirates who fire nothing but regular rounds and missiles at you. Once you get to the third system, however, you'll meet the Greel. These guys (both their fighters and their capital ships) feature Leech weapons which fire EMP missiles at you. And these things  not only do a good amount of damage to your shields, but they do a number on your engines as well. So your best bet is to get the EMP Ablation component (what the hell kind of word is that?) so that EMP weapons won't cause quite as much trouble.Nevertheless, a well-upgraded ship can handle just about anything. Just find the style and setup that works best for you and get out there. Just remember if things start to go♥♥♥♥♥♥up, there ain't no shame in making a run for it. All the money in the galaxy won't comfort you if you're dead.As the game itself, it's single player only and can be played offline if you please. Although you won't be able to make progress on achievements without being online, I found out. Also, the musical tracks they used in this game, while good, can get really repetitive; I ended up muting it. And if there's one gameplay feature I'm iffy about, it's that the best lasers in the game (the Korian Viridians) are random drops, no way to purchase them in a spaceport.There's also the issue with communications with the npcs in the game: they're pretty limited. Not to mention that the pirates seem to have trouble realizing when they're outmatched and that surrender would be in their best interest. Like I'll be flying an Arcturus-class Destroyer (which is strongly reminiscent of the Imperial Star Destroyer from Star Wars) armed to the teeth with top-notch weapons and they'll still be talking♥♥♥♥♥♥.. right up until I blow them to smithereens.And speaking of the AI, there's the escort missions. Now, the way it works is that you fly to a location, approach the client, and hold down E to Pair Warp. What that does is that the AI takes full control of your ship, keeping it alongside the ship even as you two go into warp. Noble in itself but it can lead to some annoying results. For one, when two ships are alongside each other, a human would say that the best course of action is to throttle down and turn right to line up with the client; the AI meanwhile turns your ship left, causing your back section to collide with the client's. And why is it that every escort mission has to start in an asteroid field or a ice field? Because just now I had a mission start in an ice field, I was flying a dreadnaught and it took 5-10 minutes just to get started! The AI kept maneuvering us around the ice field, taking me one direction him another. And just when I thought we were getting out of this mess, it had the client move back into the field, prolonging this mess. I had to break warp pairing, and move my ship out of the ice field myself just to get us going.Was I annoyed by all of this? Yeah, I'd say it goes without saying that I was.Then there are the missions where you fly in and save someone from enroaching hostiles. There's a good chance they'll get themselves blown up because they decided to fly into the middle of a pack of hostiles. And as Harrison Ford said in The Last Crusade "Are you crazy?!? Don't go between 'em!!"All in all though, it's a good game, well-worth the asking price. Combat can get a little challenging at times (especially with the Greel I mentioned above) but it's easy to learn & of moderate difficulty to master, just the way I like it. And if all that wasn't enough, the developers also made sure to include a risk analysis for each mission that adjusts based upon anticipated enemy strength against that of your own. And while not all the ship designs are prize-winners, there are some really good ones.So yes, I definitely recommend this game. It's cheap, it's challenging, and it'll last a long time. Hell, there're some triple-A titles that won't last as long as this game will! [cough, cough... Star Wars Battlefront: EA... cough, cough]

												Love being a space cowboy in Rebel Galaxy, it just feels good to fly around and fight other ships! Graphics are amazing even on my mid-level system, my jaw dropped when I first loaded up the game. My laptop has a hard time running it though.Great pacing, lots of things to do; explore the solar systems, smuggle cargo between space stations, start fights with space pirates and steal their cargo, sell loot and upgrade your weapons...buy a new ship once you've saved up enough.I also like how you can customize your ship to fit different playstyles, there's no wrong answer, combat always feels intense and rewarding. Outfit long range cannons and missles to snipe opponents from afar, for medium range fightfights use blaster turrets and rockets, or cover your ship in lasers to cut ships apart up close! You also get to pick whether you prefer a huge tank-like ship or a sleek corvette, customize your speed and durability based on your play style. There are no levels, the more money you make the better ships and equipment you can afford, so buy trade items low, stock your hold with valuables, and sell to the buyers offering the most at the commodity markets at the space stations.One other thing I love is the music. Not only does it come with great music by default, you can use your own MP3 collection, and it will change songs for Ambient, Combat, Idle, Menu, and Space Station. So I made folders for each music type, copied songs that fit the mood into the folders, and added those folders to the game's music library. So when I'm cruising through space I can enjoy some low key Beck and Radiohead, but when a fight breaks out the game will start blasting Green Day or the Klaxons!Buy it! Don't even hesitate, don't even worry, don't even give it a second thought.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy is a thoroughly enjoyable space RPG-style game.  The game page and other reviews do a good job of providing more detail on the gameplay, so I won't waste too much time covering that.  Basically, it's a naval combat game in space (movement is in 2D only).  That being said, this style in no way detracts from the game's value.  You spend your time doing missions, mining, trading, and/or hunting bounties to make money which goes toward upgrading your ship.  There is also a "main campaign" that takes you through a simple yet adequately interesting story.  On the downside, the factions are a bit bland (as is mentioned in several other reviews) and there really doesn't seem to be much replayability (at least I personally have no desire to replay now that I've beaten the game).If you want to pew-pew other spaceships in a beautifully rendered, decent sized "universe" while listening to an admittedly catchy soundtrack (seemingly ranging in influence from CCR to Pearl Jam at times) then this game is worth looking into.  It runs smoothly with no bugs or glitches (for me, anyway).  Ultimately, I found the game experience to be well worth the cost.8.5/10

Hitting your deflectors you absorb a few torpedo hits as your shields try their best to recharge with the brief respite you have given them.Best shields in the sytem you had thought to yourself as you happily pressed the buy button after trading all that juicy ore you mined. This situation probably wouldn't have been a big deal, if you hadn't of been ambushed on the way here. Apparently when the mission board said 'deadly ore delivery' they had meant it. That fight with two massive heavy frigates had ripped most of the armor off of your hull. Then your hull had been beaten something fierce. Emerging from that fight with a mere 20% hull integrity had been rough.That was before the distress call. Sure, you could have ignored it, after all in your experience sometimes it was a trap. Yet sometimes it was a trader in need of help. You had come out of warp with all of your weapons singing. The friendly trader barely expressed his grattitude before handing over a handful of credits and jumping to warp. Sure, you could have ignored them and kept on trucking, but that aint you, is it outlaw? Frontier folks gotta stick together.You sigh as you realize you just fired on a militia ship. It was gonna be a while before you could build that rep up. Luckily, the station was in full view, and you hit your boosters and your deflectors to make up the remaining distance.As you dock, you smile as 31,900c goes into your account, and the repair costs of your ship are covered by those alien artifacts you scooped up coming in.You have heard rumors of other galaxies. Starpoint Gemini 2, X3 Terran Conflict, Evochron Mercenary, Freelancer, but word in the space bars is that all of those where missing something. As you replace your flak cannon arrays with EMP grids, you can't help but smile once more.Yeah, you got problems captain, but that's the way you like it.

Posted: October 24, 2015
												If you remember games like Freelancer and Freespace 2 and wish there was a modern game like them, then this is the game for you. It's a single player space adventure with naval style combat, complete with broadside attacks. Upgrade your weapons, shields and more or save up to buy a whole new ship - anything from a nippy little corvette to a huge and powerful dreadnought.[PROS]* The soundtrack is immense. It's sort of bluesy and grungy, with a definite western feel (think Firefly). The heavy guitar riffs brought a smile to my face more than once during a pitched battle.* The story. Engaging and fun, with just the right amount of grinding side-quests in between.* Active developers. The game is post-launch, but they're still working on it and perfecting things, which is always nice to see.* The graphics. The ships are very detailed in perticular, with artistic and individual designs for each one. None of the 'stock blocky ship 1a' nonsense you get in some games of this ilk. They all have their own distinc look and feel.* Firefly. A lot has been made of the similarities and they are there. Mostly in the asthetic rather than the actual gameplay, but it really feels like that's the universe you are playing in. What's not to love about that!* Freedom. Choose to stay in a fast ship with high maneuverability, or spring for a lumbering dreadnought, armed to the teeth. Looks like a fish, moves like a fish, steers like a cow. There really is no perfect choice. You can switch between ships you have bought with no penalty too, which is a great touch.[CONS]* Campaign could be longer. A mid-level ship is more than sufficient to complete the whole thing, so the awesome but expensive top-tier ships don't get a proper airing. However  The campaign ends on a cliff-hanger, so a sequel or expansion might be in the works. * Navigating can get a bit irritating. You drop out of FTL travel when you get close to an asteroid, or any other obstacle and they are everywhere. This would be okay, but you can never see them coming in advance. I got used to it though, since travel times really aren't that long anyway.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
												Okay, so as I write this I am currently only at eleven hours of playtime, not a whole lot really. And in the grand scheme of things? I've barely scratched the surface of this game. You're dumped into a solar system, with a few planets and maybe ten-ish? stations to visit and get some random missions from. Cool, great, awesome. Did I mention this is only one solar system out of a galaxy? Sure it's in space, the game isn't really going to be absolutely teeming with life or a huge population, but whenever you find a landmark there's usually some miners, pirates, the Militia, or some traders that are around, and it's up to you how to interpret who is friend, who is foe, and who is prey.Can you be a pirate in this? Absolutely. Can you trade and smuggle illegal materials from different stations? Of course, just be careful of Militia patrols - they're in bigger, and meaner ships than you are to start out with, and they tend to shoot first and ask questions later if you're on the wrong side of the law. And of course you can also play the role of a bounty hunter, chasing after Pirate heads to fuel your bank account and taking up odd jobs to buy a few new guns along the way.You can also be a trader, taking supplies from one station, then going and selling them at another station to make a huge profit. There's a news-feed option in there to let you know what the latest prices are for each station, if you're patient enough. Just look out for the pirates. Or, if you're a wuss, you can just be a miner and shred through astroids with mining lasers, selling the metal ore for profit, and running the hell away from the Pirates who like your cargo, but don't like the work.As far as the combat goes, there's nothing really all that complex about it. You've got Broadside weapons, Turrets, and Secondaries. Broadsides are pretty self explanitory - they're guns mounted in the port and starboard sides of your ship (Left and Right) that are your main ship-killing weapons. What's neat is you can just spray-and-pray with them if you want, or you can charge them up, take aim, and have a well-timed barrage that leads your target so it lands right into their hull. Although if you're point blank, sometimes the spray-and-pray is better for use as a DPS race.Then you have turrets. You can have some pretty simple stuff... missile turrets, laser turrets, beam weaponry, and even some flak guns to take down those pesky fighters and bombers swarming around your poopdeck.And lastly there's Secondaries. Secondaries are essentially up to you, and effect certain places where your craft will be effective. You can put... bigger flak guns, you can put mine launchers, dumb-fire missile launchers, heat-seeker missile launchers, and so on. As far as the story goes? I haven't really gotten that far into it yet, but from what I can tell it's super simple and not really anything that you're gonna get lost on. Find some alien-tech doohickey and then go on an adventure to find out what the heck it is and what it does.Bottom line is this: If you like Starpoint Gemini, but thought the combat and world was exceptionally boring (like I found it to be...)? You'll like this. If you like pretending you're piloting Serenity or the Outlaw Star, you'll like this.You can't take the sky from me.

content:
Posted: March 2
												A 3D swashbuckling space-themed game with clear influence from Sid Meier's Pirates!.  This is not Freelancer or X3 or Privateer.  You can mine all you want, the game will let you, but you'll be broke.  You won't be building a trading empire.  The main idea is to go look for trouble with the right factions and go line up broadsides against their capital ships.  Just go through the main storyline, grind side missions between storyline missions, upgrade your ship, re-outfit it for the right role and go beat up the enemy until the credits roll.  It's a good time and a decent looking game without outrageous system requirements.The game does not take itself terribly seriously either, but it doesn't get too cartoonish.  There aren't really any RPG elements to speak of.  There is a faction reputation system, but it's nothing special.  Most people will be friendly with citizens and militia, and enemies with the various criminal factions.  The game certainly allows for play as a criminal, there are criminal-owned bases in all the systems, etc... but you're better off being friendly with the law for the storyline.  I found the combat to be incredibly fun, and the different weapons and the different classes of enemies require different strategies for effective play, so combat can be deep; not exactly oceanic, but enough to engage someone for at least the length of the storyline.  It's also self-paced, the missions give you an indication of the relative "risk" of the mission, so you can grind until the mission is "low risk" or challenge yourself by taking "high risk" missions.  There is also a warrior race of what look like giant badgers so...

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												I was on the fence about a 2D space combat game, but having played it it's a fun game.It has some problems, the control system seems to be based around a gamepad so there are a few limitations on the UI that wouldn't otherwise be there. There are also some curious design decisions like being unable to access your cargohold/factions list/tactical menu etc while docked.There is no RPGesque character development, the only limitation on what ship/equipment you can use seems to be money and to a lesser extent faction.The combat in the game is fun. There is a large variety of equipment available to outfit your ship in order to compliment your playstyle. For instance you can gear your ship up for long range sniping, close range, and even fitting special deflector shields in order to cause extra damage ramming into other ships. In general the combat seems very well thought out.On the other hand the trading and mining feel a bit lacklustre. Mining, even with the "perfect" mining setup is haphazard and rarely nets you anywhere near the amount of money combat would in the same amount of time. Trading seems too random in that it's very hard to charge what good will be worth more at any given station. I freely admit though I haven't spent a lot of time trading, so it's very possible that if I invested more time in it I'd understand the system more.I've read complaints about the save system. It's a standard autosave only game, and the autosave only takes place when you dock. This means that if you pick up 3 missions, complete 2 and then die in the 3rd one you'll lose all that progress. However, that's not necessarily a bad thing as you just weigh up the risk and dock if necessary to save.The soundtrack in the game is...interesting. I kind of liked it at first, but it becomes very repetitive after a couple of hours. However, using the launcher you can easily add your own music.In summary this game is definately worth picking up if you enjoy space action games.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												If you're looking for elitist  3D space combat with twitchy impossible combat and hardcore navigation and think it's fun to die trying to dock your ship, don't waste your money.If you want a fun game that's rewarding in small doses or good for an epic gaming weekend, this is it.  But warn your friends and family that they will be seeing less of you for a while....It's a beautifully done space combat/trading/questing game.  You can be a trader, you can be a miner, you can be a pirate, you can be a quester, or most likely you'll find yourself doing a little bit of all of it.  Or a LOT of all of it.I will suggest playing with a controller...I'm a longtime keyboard and mouse guy and I never use a controller for anything.  Thats a big part of why my Nintendo was gifted to my nephew and my xbox hasnt been plugged in for 2 years, but with this game the controller just feels right and works perfectly.Pros: *  It looks 3D, but it's mostly a 2D game, so it simplifies the navigation and combat *  Its very open.  There is a story line to progress through , but you're free to ignore it, or progress at your own pace*  You can fire it up, do a couple of quick quests, and feel like you accomplished something.  * And then a couple more, and then just one more, and then another one.....and 8 hours later you've played a quick game* It autosaves every time you visit a station.  So if your next quest goes horribly wrong, and you die a fiery death, then reload and try again. * If an objective is too hard, there are plenty of options to go make a little money, buy some better armor and weapons, and try it again.  Yet somehow it doesnt feel grindy, it's fun.* After over 30 hours, I still have the music turned on.  I saw one review call it "Cowboy butt-rock" - I'm not sure if they meant that as a compliment or an insult, but it kind of fits.  Either way, I like it.* The one time I had a problem, I posted a question on the support forum and got a response in 15 minutesCons* If you're not a fan of the "Cowboy butt-rock", turn it off.  The game is still worth it.* The game is so awesome it will inspire you to take time out to write a review, which takes time away from playing the awesome game.* I can't think of any other cons to put here* Really, why are you still reading?  Buy the game already

content:
Posted: March 2
												A 3D swashbuckling space-themed game with clear influence from Sid Meier's Pirates!.  This is not Freelancer or X3 or Privateer.  You can mine all you want, the game will let you, but you'll be broke.  You won't be building a trading empire.  The main idea is to go look for trouble with the right factions and go line up broadsides against their capital ships.  Just go through the main storyline, grind side missions between storyline missions, upgrade your ship, re-outfit it for the right role and go beat up the enemy until the credits roll.  It's a good time and a decent looking game without outrageous system requirements.The game does not take itself terribly seriously either, but it doesn't get too cartoonish.  There aren't really any RPG elements to speak of.  There is a faction reputation system, but it's nothing special.  Most people will be friendly with citizens and militia, and enemies with the various criminal factions.  The game certainly allows for play as a criminal, there are criminal-owned bases in all the systems, etc... but you're better off being friendly with the law for the storyline.  I found the combat to be incredibly fun, and the different weapons and the different classes of enemies require different strategies for effective play, so combat can be deep; not exactly oceanic, but enough to engage someone for at least the length of the storyline.  It's also self-paced, the missions give you an indication of the relative "risk" of the mission, so you can grind until the mission is "low risk" or challenge yourself by taking "high risk" missions.  There is also a warrior race of what look like giant badgers so...

												Rebel Galaxy is a lot like a shot of cheap whisky in a pretty glass, served in a grungy southern biker bar.  It looks attractive, and it gets the job done, but it has some glaring faults and limitations and can burn like hell going down.  One of the often mentioned features is the sound track, I thought it was pretty cool at first, but after 2 hours I turned down  the music to 10%.  It certainly sets the mood, and establishes Rebel Galaxy as a "Firefly inspired" space western.  however it gets repetative, and is intrusive.  After you hear the title song five or six times in a row blasting in your ears, it gets old quick. I am susceptable to ear worms, and it's going to take a few days to get this out of my brain completely.   That isn't a good thing for me. It's not that the songs are bad, by no means, the artist who wrote them is talented, and I like the sound track.  But too much of a good thing can be frustratingly iritating. Other reviewers have done a good job talking about the games features and gameplay style.   comparing it to the ship combat from black flag, and I think that is a spot on comparison.   It really feels like someone wrote a naval combat engine, and halfway through decided to make it a space game instead.  This could literally have been a WWII naval simulator or something and it would have been the same game.   Just with water and islands instead of space and planets. To put it bluntly, this is an Naval combat arcade game with a space skin.  Despite this, the game works, it works stylistically, and the gameplay is satisfying enough to keep you playing. The game is only 20$ full price (I got it for 13$ on sale), and it's worth even full price, but only if you like the genre. Buy this game if:You like the Vibe of Firefly or Serenity. Like Arcade shooters in space. Liked the naval combat of Black flag. Like the standard Trader/Bountyhunter/Pirate/miner kind of space game, and don't mind the emphasis being on combat.Like the gritty southern/blues/country soundtrack.  Like the graphics.Don't mind being locked into a 2d playing field, even when smaller ships can still fly 3d.  All around you. Want to control a whole ship using even just a console controller (works very well). You Like Single Player games. Don't buy the game if:You strongly prefer Simulators/realism to arcade style games. You prefer complex controls, and tactics (you can pretty much phone in tactics in this game). You are tired of the Trade/fight/mine paradigm of space sandbox gaming. You hate any form of country music. You Hated Firefly. You expect a long complex story with tons of twists and turns (I like it so far, and the voice acting and dialogue trees are fun... but it's not Mass Effect for example.). Think a "2d limited" space game is too immersion breaking. Prefer multiplayer. Final verdict:  If you like the genre, or can get past the burning in your throat, you will enjoy this offering.  It is a good game to unwind with, the fights satisfying the visuals pleasing. Like that cheap shot of whisky, it may not have the smooth quality of a higher priced drink, but it will still do the job, and if you drink enough of it, you won't even notice the burning in your throat anymore. Unlike that shot of whisky, this shouldn't give you a hangover, and won't ruin your marraige.  Anyway, I have no regrets, it's a fun game, worth the full price unless you fall in the "don't buy it" category. ).

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Edited and update review here. I wanted to re-review this after seeing how good/bad the game was after you finish the story. I had a very strong positive reaction to my first 15 hours playing, but after you finish the majority of the main story mode, the game is basically over. It wasn't built for a "sandbox" experience or anything, as the systems get less and less fun as you move along the main story path. I'll explain that more below, but if you want a one sentence recap: good game, worth twenty bucks for sure, but it has a few glaring problems. First off, I really like this game. Almost every aspect is fun and it isn't often you get good space games on Steam. The price is good, and I do recommend it overall. With that said, there are some major flaws. The first one being the trade and economy system. It's so poorly handled that it's hard to justify it being in the game at all. The only time you will find the market scheme useful in any way is very early in the game, in the first or second systems when you are stuggling to earn credits. The work it takes to get goods and then find the station that is buying high is just way too hard to justify when you start earning $100,000 per mission - let alone when you are getting $1mil per mission later on. The 90k you might make off trading is insignificant. Your time spent grows significantly and the gains never justify it. The whole thing could have been alleviated by having actual up-to-date pricing information available both on the main map and while in a dock, but the developers failed miserably on that. It's true they did implement a (very minimal) scheme that shows you current pricing in each station from the main map, but it only works if you've already visited the station or happen find a message transponder that gives you the information. Even then, the information is only good for a matter of minutes. The game will randomly change the goods and prices in each station, so usually by the time you get enough of the goods to matter, you will never find the right place to sell it unless you get really lucky and accidentally stop at the right station. Couple that with random events like famine, celebration, tech boom, etc., it's like a lottery except the profit is meaningless. There is no logic or reason to the system, no attempt to mimic actual markets in any logical way. The one and only way to make real credits is by doing missions, which are fine and fun, but I think they should have either cut the entire trading system or made it universal and simplified. Instead it's like they started out with a good idea, but lost it halfway through. The other huge issue is the "proximity stop" system. Basically, if you come within a certain distance of any other object in the game, you will be instantly halted out of warp. This would be fine and make sense if they tried to limit the amount of debris and roaming hostile fleets, but as the game progresses and you meet more factions, the maps stay the same size. So what you end up with are huge fields of debris from battles needing to share a shrinking amount of space with asteroid fields and huge fleets of enemies wandering around. By the fifth system or so, there are a half dozen factions on each map. Then you have merchants and traders randomly criss-crossing the place on top of it, and they have their own bodyguards with fighter ships. It all adds up to way, way too much crap on the map and fewer and fewer routes you can take just to do simple tasks, like going to turn in a mission or finish a trade.  After the 100th time you get stopped mid-warp just because a piece of debris or friendly merchant came within 400 sm (in-game unit of measurement) of your path, it gets incredibly frustrating.It's also worth noting that the "escort" missions are mostly broken at present. They might patch them again, but right now only about 75% of them work as intended. The pathing is poorly coded and there are too many random objects that only confuse the AI even more. Occasionally you will get a big piece of ship debris and it will cause the AI's ship you are escorting to start moving forwards and backwards, over and over, in a loop. You can abandon missions at any time, so when it does break, it's easy enough to just forget it and move on.So, those are my main frustrations. Otherwise this is a great game and is easily the best space game on Steam right now. It's definitely better than Elite Dangerous, plus it's only twenty bucks. I got this on sale for $13, and for that price, it's a major bargain. If you are looking for trade simulation or a long-term sandbox mode you can play in after the (approximately) 25 hour storymode is over, this might not be the best game for that. I got over 30 hours out of it and that was definitely worth $20 to me, but your mileage may vary.

												Classic Naval Broadside Cannon Combat IN SPACE!This game is a ton of fun, from the moment you start you literally can do anything you want. Whether it be bounty hunting, mining, protecting, exploring. Everything is right there, right away. It's simple with it being on a flat plane (meaning you can't fly up and down, instead you go left, right, and straight). Surprisingly it doesn't take to much away from the game. Combat is fast paced and their is a varity of ships to face, from small fighters to capital ships. Some of your weapons crush small fighters but won't even scratch the paint job against the capital ships. There is plenty of upgrades for your ships and the best part is when you buy a new ship, you don't have to rebuy everything as it swaps out the ship but keeps the equipment and automatically sells the old ship (so if you're a tad short on money it'll do an exchange where it sells your ship first then buys the new ship making it pretty seemless to purchase new things). The sounds are pretty good in the game, I really can't complain. Especially when you hit warp. The voice acting is above average for a game of this production size.All in all, if you like space, I'd have to recommend this game. I got this game when it was $9.99 and to be honest, it would be worth it at $20.00 hands down.

												There is something incredibly satisfying in aligning your ship alongside another and unleashing every single broadside cannon you have. In combination with the incredible music giving every fight you take a Wild West spin; you truly are on the lawless outskirts of space. You start with nothing and climb all the way to the top in any way you want. Trader, Miner, Mercenary, Pirate. Just be careful who you make enemies with, anything goes in this game.On the subject of trading, Rebel Galaxy contains a simple yet effective trading system with market values that will change in response to local events. Discover trade routes from station to station, capitalise on resource shortages, a station currently being blockaded will be in desperate need of supplies.When you feel strong enough, use a jump gate to travel to one of the many other systems. Make sure you are prepared though; higher risk brings higher reward but you won’t be smiling facing a Dreadnought class ship armed to the teeth. This game stands out as one of its quirks is that it is locked on a 2D plane, honestly I think this brings its benefits. You're at the helm of a capital ship, you wouldn't be doing amazing tricks. It also simplifies the controls, meaning you can focus less on keeping the ship level and more on the actual fight. Just listen to the soundtrack, it completes this game.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
												In rebel galaxy you will find yourself on the edges of civilised space, space stations placed anywhere from the hollowed out husk of a mighty asteroid to in orbit around colossal gas giants will be a sight for sore eyes as you pilot your ship into the awaiting docks, the repair bay will offer you a chance to repair the fractured hull, weapons ranging from ionised bursts of plasma to mighty missle batteries having punched through the shield and torn through the hull damaging systems as well as your own weapons, handing over an adequate sum of currency to the shipwright. You may choose to offload cargo, either acquired via the mission board (cargo needs to get around somehow), trade with a cargo vessel you pulled out of the fire as pirates attempted to 'appropriate' its cargo or from the ruined husks of the pirate vessels themselves (maybe even the trader too if you're so inclined)Maybe you're looking for a job? or perhaps to finish one, handing over the agreed upon cargo for a sum of credits, hitting up the mission board to pick out a slew of quests to keep yourself busy as you trek across the system taking on a notorious pirate here, guarding a mining outpost there or perhaps assisting the militia forces take on a pirate convoy, headed by a mighty command ship; there are no shortage of things people want done.And after all that there's the bar, where you could chat up the tender, asking for news he might be partial to, whether it be as simple as an excalation of pirate activity in the sector, or perhaps that one of the stations in the system are going through some rough times, that being said no one pays more for food than those who need it and where there is demand, there is supply, but whether or not you're the one to supply said goods is up to you.Or perhaps you're looking for bounties? Slip the barkeep a couple hunded credits and suddenly you've got the locations to a few people someone out there wants dead, and are willing to pay for it.At the bar you might also meet a merc, spend a couple thousand on a good pilot to watch your back, this section of the galaxy is after all 'mostly' lawless space.Your visit done, you return to your ship, maybe spend a few thousand credits on an enhanced engine, thicker hull plating or better weapons, maybe even a few new tools to help you along the way, making your weapons deadlier, your aim sharper and those pirate scum a little less threatening.Whether you want to take to the stars as space trader extraordinare, feared bounty hunter, humble asteroid miner or parhaps cutthroat pirate, (Perhaps a mix of all four?) Rebel Galaxy can certainly accomodate.{Serious stuff out of the way, I caught a pirate group harassing a salvage crew harvesting the wreck of a giant (at least 12 times the size of my current ship) capital vessel (which you can TOTALLY get later) caught in the midst of a minefield, I noticed a cluster of mines near the enemy vessel on and ended up taking a shot at the explosives, which like a chain reaction of epic preportions exploded (As 'explosives' tend to do) taking out the pirate in a single shot, moments like that is what this game provides, if any of this review sounds like something you'd enjoy than I wholeheartedly recommend Rebel Galaxy.}

The credit grind outside the story line can get a little tedious after a while, but if pays to have a 500k credit nest egg when you leave the first sector.  These aren't your Han Solo type of characters that you are working with in the storyline...  More like the type that Jabba feeds to the sarlaac.  Even the good guys are more of a shade of grey.  Outside of you (depending on your game play,) I have yet to encounter one white knight in the story.The chat option selected does not appear to have any bearing on the storyline.  You still go to all the same story line misisons.  (Even the AAA titles have yet to get this figured out, so I am not going to knock this game for it.)The controls are a bit different than what I am used to, but seem easy enough to adapt to.  Can't tell you how many times I have absent mindedly fired missiles when I was first starting out.  The militia don't like it when you do that.For those new to the game like I am, I suggest immediately running off the beaten path and trade between the stations.  Mining isn't all that practical, but the Mk2 Mining laser makes a great anti fighter platform.  You will need the credits for much needed upgrades.  Only buy stuff with red list prices and sell in places where the price turns green.  Taking missions off of the terminal always has a welcoming party near or at the end point waiting to kill you.  You can hire one wingman to bump up your overall firepower.  Freelancer players will take to this game very quickly.  This game rewards caution.  If you charge blindly into a situation you will get smoked.  Sure you can configure your ship to knife fight, but a handful of ships will still mug you if you are not careful.  I found upgrading your engines, booster, shields, armor, and weapons in that order was the best option at increasing your survival rate.Friendly fire isn't.  The AI ships will go after each other.  If you get between them both sides will shoot you.  If you find yourself looking at a militia destroyer parking itself between you and a pirate, stop firing at the pirate.  You will only end up shooting the militia destroyer, lose massive rep with the militia, and all the militia in the area will start shooting at you.  Your starting corvette is barely able to fight its way out of wet paper sack at the beginning of the game.  Rep plays a part in this game.  Outside the obvious rep for merchants, criminals, and militia, it is hard to tell how rep really plays out in this game.  Join a guild if you want to get your hands on unique ship hulls.  Getting the criminal factions to like you is harder than you think.  Missions from the stations are the easiest to gain rep, but even that is difficult if you are trying to avoid♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥everyone off.  (Yea, you got the criminals to like you.  Now the militia hates your guts...  and they have the strongest ships and in greater numbers in the starting sector.)Right out of the gate, I see a a couple of obvious areas needing improvement.1: The multi-function of the 'E' key can be a bit annoying at times.  You are trying to tractor an item and accidently engage the warp drive because you were out of tractor range.  Docking with stations can run into this problem as well.2: The lack of full 360 degree flight seems a bit odd in this day and age of fully capable space sims.  Those with the expectation of free flight along all axis will by put off by this.  It would be nice if they open up the y axis.  Your enemies and asteroids get to use the y axis, but you don't.  The station placement can cause problems when you leave the area.  Found myself autodocking when I just wanted to leave to the next station.  Probably my biggest gripe of the game so far.3: If you aren't aware of the tutorial help section, the pop up hints and help tend to come up in a manner of oh now you tell me.I will add to this as I rack up more playing time.  At any rate, it is a fun game for less than $20.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Fresh and simple, this game manages to create the feeling of an enormous, dynamic Freelancer-style sandbox with fantastically simple arcade-style controls.  Easily one of the most intuitive games I've ever played, and one of the prettiest (and in light of that, one of the best optimised too - running far better than games with lower requirements and looking better than some with higher requirements too).  This game feels a lot like Diablo II, perhaps unsurprisingly since those games are amongst the staggering pedigree of the team of TWO core developers.   The two games on Steam that seem closest to it in aesthetics and playstyle would be, I think, Starpoint Gemini 2 and Drifter.  I've got both and after 1 hour on Rebel Galaxy I already know I'm going to spend much more time on this than the other two.  It is far simpler to pick up and have fun with than Starpoint Gemini 2 - a real sense of instant fun and adventure - and it's significantly more polished and deep than Drifter, as well as being much prettier.My only gripe with the game is that all the action takes place in a plane as opposed to having real 3D movement.  You can't pitch your ship up or down.  Hardly game-breaking, and I suppose it's true that the vast majority of real star systems are organised in a plane, but they are far from 2-dimensional from the point of view of a human space-ship!Don't expect an X-series experience.  This game is much closer to classics like Freelancer and Tachyon: The Fringe.  It's not shallow, but it's certainly not "spreadsheets in space" either.

												I bought this in a previous 50% sale and would say that at this price it is definitely worth it, however after having now played it for 30+ hours (and finding it hard to put it down each time) I think I would have paid full price too!As many reviews have already stated this game is like the love child of Sid Meier's Pirates and Freelancer, it's neither one or the other but has emulated some of the features from both games and merged these into an interesting hybrid. The 2D naval style fighting makes it less complicated than a 3D counterpart but don\'t let that fool you that it's less of a challenge. The variety of ships, weapons and modules give it enough diversity to keep you playing for that next upgrade but without bombarding you with sheets of complicated stats. The soundtrack isn't going to be everyone\'s taste but I think it's awesome and really suits the pace of the game.Yes it's a bit clichéd, the main story is short and it's quite simplified compared to others in the genre but that's the beauty of it - it isn't trying to copy a successful franchise and then failing miserably; it has it's own spin on space rpg that's different whilst being familiar at the same time.Edit: Removed typos caused by mobile app

												Charming, if limited, arcade game written by the creator of Torchlight.Whilst it really isn't anything special, Rebel Galaxy enjoys a level of charm not often seen in the modern gaming world. From the sci-fi western setting to the naval-esque space combat, Rebel Galaxy takes a lot of smart-but-simple game mechanics and throws them together in one thoroughly enjoyable and deceptivel moreish space romp.Whilst it will feel familiar to both fans of games such as the X series as well as hardened ARPG players, both will see where the limits shine: from the limited dimensions of space combat to the under-developed item metagame, Rebel Galaxy is very much a jack of many (if not all) trades, but a master of none.

Let's get that out there in the open.  *pushes beer under his bed with his feet, all slick-like*AHEMThe game is a prettier, more entertaining version of Space Rangers. 												I really want to like this game because I love the whole Firefly thing it has going on. There are definitely things to like about it, but it ultimately is just a very boring space sim with a kinda lousy battle system IMO.Turn-ons:+Firefly!+Soundtrack is great!+NPCs are marvelous!Turn-offs:--The broadside combat. I played the game for 3+ hours and fought a fair number of battles against pirates in that time. I even upgraded to better weapons and different types of weapons. But the combat just never started to feel good. Broadside combat is great with sea vessels because they are both sea vessels. But in this game your ship is confined to a flat plane while enemy ships are flying loops over you and under you as you try to lock onto them. It's more like trying to use a sluggish wooden sailing ship to engage in broadside combat with a bunch of airplanes and submarines. I'm not saying that it's impossible or anything, but I did find it really irritating and it did not start to get better.--It is very empty and boring. It has all of the things that space sims normally have, such as trading and merc missions and ships parts that can be upgraded and so on. But I put in several hours into this game and I spent most of that time staring at the butt of a ship flying in a straight line toward a mission destination. I seriously just set the controller down on my desk, folded my hands, and watched a picture of a space ship. For minutes. MINUTES ON END. I found out that I could upgrade all of my engines and boosters etc to get some more speed out of the ship, and I was feeling very positive about that at first, but then I realized I was STILL pretty much spending most of my time staring at the butt of a ship flying in a straight line. So much yawn.--The game seems heavily skewed toward playing as muscle. If you tend to lean a little more pacifist/trader in space sims, then this game does not seem very friendly towards those types. When I first started running missions, I initially was only accepting missions that the game explicitly labeled as VERY LOW RISK, which were usually just trading missions that asked me to go pick something up and bring it back or transport some cargo from A to B. But EVERY SINGLE ONE of these missions resulted in a scripted ambush attack from multiple pirate ships. Literally every time. So there's not really any point accepting the missions that pass themselves off as the pacifist types because this game shoves you into combat literally every time. Every mission is a combat mission. Always. Without fail. Or so this was my experience.--But did I mention how incredibly boring it is? This was really the thing that made me stop playing the most. Most of my time spent playing this game I did not feel like I was playing a game. I felt like I was staring at the butt of a ship that was doing nothing.And then it occurred to me that I could be playing a game that felt like doing things. So I'm done with it.I love the whole Firefly thing, and apparently lots of people think the game is just great, but man... I could not stay awake while playing this thing.

												Rebel Galaxy is a very casual space pilot "simulator", all combat is really handled in 2D and mostly resembles sea battles (broadside artillery, all ships except fighters manouver on the same "height") so if you're looking for a serious space-sim it's not for you.Gameplay consists of main storyline broken up by (a lot) of generated sidequests which get a bit boring after a while since there's only a few types (search and destroy, delivery, defend target, pick up object). Apart from sidequests you can also play as a trader, buying low and selling high, a miner selling resources found in asteroids, pirate hunter looking for bounties or a pirate hunting civillian ships.As you progress you will upgrade your ship with new weapons, shields and additional equipment, every once in a while buying a new ship.Pros:+ Enjoyable space combat (if you dont mind the sea battles feel).+ Plenty of ships/upgrades to work towards.+ Decent voice-acting (somewhat repetetive lines from enemies).+ Multiple ways to progress.+ Great musicCons:- Requires a lot of grinding sidequests to progress.- Not much depth or variety beyond the basics.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
Rebel Galaxy: Fun but not Deep or WideShort version:Arcadey 3rd person space shooter.Simple plot with no twists or choices.Entertaining but repetitive combat system.Very basic ship customization.Context:I had just finished playing through Skyrim, a one-and-done game, and was looking for something completely different. Small scope, not fantasy, but a better role-playing experience. Because face it: trying to role play in Skyrim is just silly. What I found in Rebel Galaxy was a refreshing change of pace with no commitments.Experience:Starting out it really reminded me of Privateer crossed with Earth & Beyond. Loved the former and wanted to love the latter. I tried to role play (I wanted to be a bloodthirsty pirate) but the pirates weren't welcoming and money was tight so I went with Merchant and Mercenary after my first save game corrupted. For a little while I tried to get into the "events" and trading but the simple math of the game finally proved itself out. Upgrade, upgrade, upgrade. Kill, kill, kill. Mission, mission, mission. Click through the conversation trees because nothing they're saying matters a bit. Oh, final mission done.The music is really good at first - setting your mind in the "Firefly" wild west mentality. Then it gets a little repetitive. Rather like the same 6-8 talking heads. I never got bored enough to switch to custom music and I did find myself humming some of the tunes at work.Gameplay:For a few hours the non-combat mechanics are worth exploring. Mine some asteroids. Jump from station to station moving commodities. Shop the mercenaries. Experience the array of 6-8 mission types. It didn't take long to get a handle on deciding what's worth it in risk vs. reward - factoring in time, of course. These mechanics quickly lose relevance.Combat mechanics are pretty simple. Load your ship with the best turrets you can (in a variety that suits you), a broadside that you can maneuver well enough to bring to bear, and over-level your shields and hull first. Roll into the fight and sweep them if you can. Run away if you can't.One small gripe is the extremely shallow pool that is the ship customization. The hull I was in never really seemed special (it's just ports, turrets, and cargo space). And I felt just as effective in my tier-6 armed Destroyer as I was in my tier-6 armed Dreadnaught. But, with the system as simple as it was, I enjoyed not needing a spreadsheet or helper tool to deck out my ride.And my big gripe that kills this game for replayability: no choices. I ran a straight line from beginning to end with some grinding (a lot, really, in the early game). No impact. No changes. The galaxy just rolls along without the events making any real impact or change. The story is alright but predictable. I was relieved when I saw the end of it.One and done. Worth the $20 I dropped on it. No replayability but the once-through was fun.

Posted: June 30, 2016
												The best way to describe this game, I think, is to imagine a simplified Freelancer that doesn't take itself nearly as seriously. It has this sort of disjointed western-slash-Caribbean pirate theme to it that works brilliantly in its favor, lending a much needed injection of comic-book stylization to the genre of space trade & combat sim. The voice acting is good enough not to be grating or distracting, which is great. What's a little less great (but maybe not by a lot) is the two-dimensional flight. Again, simplified. A 6DOF shooter, this is not. If you can do naval combat, you will probably do fine here. To me, this makes the game feel a little strange, not being able to fly up or down in space. But not a deal breaker. The soundtrack is very fun and unique, but some of the tracks end up sounding a little same-y after a few hours. Gameplay pacing moves about the same as Freelancer, so if you enjoyed that title, you will probably feel justified in spending full price on this one. If you're expecting a fast-paced space shooter, maybe wait until it goes on sale.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy is a space trading and combat simulator that reminds me of Freelancer, but with bigger ships. In this game, you are a guy who gets a message from his Aunt Juno to take her old ship and fly to some station a long way from home to meet her. And guess what? She's not there. The story isn't as much the highest point of the game, but the gameplay and the galaxy you explore are phenominal. Gameplay is based around trading or fighting to upgrade or replace your ship in order to meet the increasing difficulty that comes with each new sector. While you might think you're pretty strong in your big, bada$$ ship with lasers and cannons galore that rips apart other ships like they're made of thin paper, every new sector you go to will smack you down and force you to realize that there are people out there that will eat you for breakfast, spit you out, and do it again for lunch. This spike in difficulty keeps the game fresh, as you don't get to feel like a demigod for very long, and if you want to stay feeling like a demigod, you have to actually work for it. The learning curve takes a while to get used to, but once you learn the basics, the game really opens up as you explore and fight your way through the galaxy fighting for pirates and outcasts for the good of the people, or robbing merchants and fighting the military because you can. Or, you can do what some AI who has downloaded inself into your ship's computer tells you to do and help it regain its memory.Overall, I give this a 9/10 for a extreamly challenging and sometimes punishing experience, and for bringing a fresh perspective to the world of space combat and trading sims. Now I have to go back to wondering how I will blow up that Dreadnought looming in the distance... and now I'm dead because missiles and lazers.

content:
Posted: February 18
												After careful consideration, I can't recommend this game as it stands. It has a lot of potential, but due to various bugs and imbalances it fails to live up to that potential. The system it uses to classify mission difficulties is spotty (some very high risk missions are easy, while some low risk missions are very difficult). Escort missions are extremely buggy: escorts path back and forth regularly, they have almost no armor and NPCs don't have aggro tables AFAIK, if you engage personal warp for even a moment you immediately fail the escort. Some missions have you kill another faction's ships with no warning, so it's tricky to farm faction rep when a mercenary guild mission for 15 rep might have you killing merchant guild ships and losing 30 rep with them. On top this, it's extremely grindy. Get to a system, buy modules that are ~50% stronger than the ones you entered the system with, move to the next system since all the content in that system is obsolete now. Aside from the story, it's the same missions grinded over and over. "Go here and kill these two groups of enemies" "Escort this trade prince to that station" "Take this cargo from point A to point B". Honestly, this feels like a game that someone worked long and hard on, but then 80% of the way in they decided they needed to wrap it up ASAP and filled the last 20% with hollow, paper mache content. For the first 10 hours or so it was fun, but once you realize that it's just going to be the same recycled grind over and over it leaves you with a sinking feeling of "why am I still doing this?"
