content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												Now this game is solid FUN! Period! I'm an emotional gamer so for me what makes or breaks a game is the FEELING a game emotes. It does not have to be perfect next gen graphics, or super solid gameplay, or the most original story ever. If it feels right and gives enjoyement then it's a success for me. Now obviously all previously mentioned things add up to the overall feel of a game. However they are like spice and are not the sole source of the 'magic' of a game. The cornerstone needs to be set right with a game or the whole building will start sinking crooked. For me this elusive thing in games is the feeling they magically either have or don't have. Take this game for example. It does not have award winning graphics or plot or even character development. It does not have a particularly interesting story and the game makes no pretentions of it either. This game is not trying to be serious about itself and that my friends is what made a movie called tremors such a great fun flick in it's time. Solid practical effects, avoiding tongue in cheek direction or story for that matter is what made that movie have a great FEEL to it. Same here. By looking on this game's merits on paper by all means this should be a flop, but it's completely and utterly the opposite! This is why people betting on money and calculating companies trying to bank a bazillion of whatever currency they can get a hold of, will never see the light of day how to make a good solid fun entertainment! All I can say is, try this game out if you are a person like me and care for the overall feeling of a gameplay experience. The good thing this game has on paper is it's soundtrack :D Perfect campy fun in a great way! However no game is perfect and hardly is this title here. This game is EASY to get into, but after awhile it becomes a grindtastic repetitive romp with not so good AI. Beware of these things if you are easily turned off. It did not turn me off so much because the overall easiness and feeling the game churns out kept me at it enjoying getting better ships and weaponry. I am a casual gamer and I appreciate when a game is this accessible. However of course it would be great if this game had more depth and polish into it as it progresses or the main quest line is exhausted. The devs could maybe make DLC for this title? Anyway I'm certainly looking for a sequel that tackles more with this titles shortcomings. I loved freelancer and was immediately at home with this one. Besides freelancer was not so much more complex gameplaywise as this one is. Fond memories tend to get golden in time. I liked this one, so maybe give it a cautious try if you liked freelancer..

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												This is a very well made game. An almost Freelancer style game with simple mechanics that make learning quick and fun. The missions you take can be legal or illegal - bounty hunter, merchant, smuggler, miner, thief, and so forth. Combat is satisfying and engaging, though a bit over the top at times and occasionally downright impossible until you have had further equipment upgrades. Once purchased though, the difficulty lowers.The commodity system was great! This was one of the most satisfying games for being a merchant I've ever played. Watch for starvation and run them food from an agrarian planet. Take water from one system that is rich in it to a more barren system and earn 200% or more than what you bought it for. Took a little getting use to, and I still don't understand it all, but the overall mechanic is satisfying once you get an idea of it.My only gripe is it needs more content. After the main story is over, you have the biggest Dreadnaugh, and you are fully upgraded, doing missions is a little pointless. The devs should open it up for modding. More ships, weapons, equipment, systems, etc., etc., and this game would be more than a hoot.Definitely worth the $20. The game is great and a definite recommend, even if it's for a few story runs only.

Posted: April 3, 2016
												Rebel Galaxy was initialy hard to play, the controls felt wierd and until I got my settings right the framerate wasn't great, but after fixing the settings and about two hours this became one of the best games I have ever played. Top five for sure. Basicly think of what it would be like if Empire at War's space battles weren't RTS, or if Battle Star Galactica Online wasn't for wallet warriors and wasn't unbalanced. The locked plane and broadside combat keeps the game simple and exciting and totally un-clunky, although sometimes the menus can be a bit difficult.The ship designs are great too, especially the underated Sorcerer dreadnought (my personal favorite ship, by far) although sometimes the AI targeting gets confused due to the ship's geometry, which was fixed with the sorcerer for the main part but makes the McKinley my least favorite ship so far.Aliens in this game also have good design by being Lovecraftian fish people or rad badger dudes and they all feel Star Wars inspired and combined with the hailing system also add a sort of Star Trek feel.Overall, the game is initially daunting and difficult to get used to, but after you've given it a chance it is absolutely great.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												This game likes to stretch itself out. Normally i don't mind a game that takes me a long time to complete. I like feeling as if i got my money's worth. Good games (like Witcher 3) do this by giving you hours upon hours of enjoyable content and interesting plot. Rebel Galaxy stretches itself out by creating a vast emptiness between everypoint and making your speed very very slow. I get it, it's space, there is supposed to be an emptiness, vast distances between places. So what's the point of giving me a warp drive (one that no matter how much you upgrade still seems slow as hell) if it's still going to take me two minutes to reach anywhere i want to go, and that's only if i'm lucky enough to not get stopped by a group of pirates or an asteroid field. I've spent 17 hours playing this game, the majority of it was spent in transit. All the tension this game gave me was not from space battles or plot development, but instead the worry of wether or not i would reach the next objective anytime soon.If you want to pretend to be a space trucker hauling cargo for days on end, just to afford better gear to slowly move the story forward. then this game is for you.If you're looking for fun, and excitement, look elsewhere.

number of helpful: 14 of 30 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												A game without any need for a player. You make no decisions- just follow a waypoint indicator to the next mission. You don't aim, your weapons autoaim and some of them autofire. There is no terrain, occassional asteroids dot the map but they don't effect combat much. Every set of enemies feels identical - there is no variety whatsoever. The game is played strictly on a 2d plane. The only tactic I ever had to use was kite enemies from long range if I was overwhelmed (which was very rare).  Weapon variety is low and upgrade progression is linear. The music quickly becomes dull, mostly twangy country music. Not a lot of variety. The graphics are nice and ships show damage decalls when hit. There is a big variety in ship size and appearance. It would be nice if a ship 10 times my own ship's size was intimidating at all I guess.Perhaps most telling is the components present in the game. There's a lot of opportunity here, perhaps there could be a part that doubles your speed and halves your shields. Instead all of them give marginal benefits to your ship (like a 10% increase in turning speed). These components are all expensive, requiring more than a dozen missions of farming to get. The entire game is a grind with no need for a player. Why couldn't you find something for me to do Rebel Galaxy?

Posted: November 27, 2015
												First game in 11 years on Steam that I've requested a refund.Contrary to what you may read from the starry-eyed youngsters spamming out blue thumbs, this is not a scion of Privateer.  This is a fourth generation knock-off of Privateer designed for the ADD crowd.  The combat is simplistic, mindless, and confusing.  The map scale is tiny.  The... well, if you loved Privateer, you know where I'm headed here.On the bright side, the developers do understand something that most designers of modern free-form space combat/trading games often miss entirely:  Privateer was a huge success because of its atmosphere and "you are there" feeling.  They nailed that part.  Too bad the rest of it sucks skunk sacs.Rather than spend cash on this thing, just give it to Chris Roberts to work on his latest game.  You'll get a far better return on your investment

Posted: December 24, 2015
												So I've had this game for a couple of days and have a dozen hours on it or so and my overal impression is 'meh' with a side of 'boring'.I found the start of the game very infuriating, the controls didn't work on a laptop (although they were fine when I reconfigured them). But combat is still a pain, many of the actions you can perform while flying demand the camera to be facing a certain direction and you can't steer you're ship while simultaneously aiming a broadside. But that's kind of OK, it just means that the game is aimed at beginers of this genre. It does do somethings well, like having shields and armour go down on different parts of the ship independently. Would be nice if they could also be upgraded independently.Which brings me to my biggest gripe about the game. Upgrading your ship is dull. You have only a handful of options per part, which then go from Mk1 to Mk2 to Mk3, etc... Doesn't feel like an accomplishment to have my top speed under boost increase by 10%. Add to that that every battle feels the same (unless there are some unseen possible tactics I haven't come across) and the world is bland.Basically, when ever I played this game only one thought crossed my mind "Why am I not playing X3: Terran Conflict ?". It's not a perfect game by far, but it has all the depth that Rebel Galaxy lacks. It's not that it's a bad game, it just isn't interesting enough for me to make it fun. Perhaps the plot could have rescued it, but after 10h it is also boring and repetitive

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												The vast majority of reviews are quite decieving for this game, in that they paint a picture for this game that makes it seem like more than it really is.The 2D naval combat and the camera that's way too close makes the game feel extremely small and claustrophobic and makes combat a nuisance at best, and on top of the terrible camera, the heavy amounts of aim assist make it very dull, tracking your shots hardly matters since your shots effectively home in on the target so long as you're in range and have charged your broadside shots and the turrets are literally an autolock and fire themselves when you're in broadside mode.The controls and functionality are very off-putting as well, this game was very obviously made for consoles and wasn't properly ported to PC, there are no options in game, only a settings launcher that pops up before you enter the game so if you want to change anything at all you have to restart the game before you can. Keyboard and mouse controls feel pretty slip and slide too.Finally there's all the comparisons to Freelancer I want to put to bed.I played Freelancer for hours, probably hundreds of hours, I absolutely ADORED Freelancer, it was the ideal space sim for a plebian like me, nice and simple and really pretty while still feeling like it's in space.This however is no Freelancer.The combat is way too basic, the movement is way too restricted, the world is far too claustrophobic. Everythings packed and squeezed into this tiny 2D space where the concept of up and down are alien to the player character.Sorry Freelancer fans, you're gonna have to keep going without.Overall this game's pretty naff.It should have been a Naval game.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												This game scratched an itch in me that I didn't really know was there until I played it. It isn't your traditional fare, and the game streamlines the experience of being a space captain. That said it plays like Firefly meets Pirates of the Caribbean. If you never have enjoyed playing games where you line up broadsides and enjoy the sweet victory as your enemy crumples under your withering fire...you might not like this game. If you do, and you like your universe dipped in hard whisky with plenty of grit on the side this game might be just your thing.The Good:Ship combat is fast and furious, with most engagements and missions being over in a couple of minutes. Swarms of fighters, dancing beam weapons, and volleys of missiles light up the fights; all coming at you and maybe the poor sap you hired to protect you. Meanwhile you use a deflector (timed extra shield), main shields, and your armor to protect the innards of your ship while trying to line up a broadside as your turrets pick away at your opponent's shields. Because once someone is down to armor, it doesn't take that long before they are nothing be space dust.Trading, while simple, is still deep enough to enjoy. There is also mining, bounty hunting, distress calls (and ambushes), dead drop missions, and more to enjoy. You can spend hours alone in the first system building up reputation and your ship before stepping out into the wider galaxy...and you just might.The Bad:As much fun as the combat can be, it sometimes falls a little heavily on your gear as to whether you can engage in that fight or not. Thankfully the game does a good job of tracking the threat level as to your chances of pulling off the fight or whether you need to pass or run away. Which even with a medium frigate all in top gear for the first system I'm finding I'm doing more running then fighting...yet. Mission boards also give you a threat level when you take them so you know you aren't walking into a complete curb stomp, but you will feel the sting of defeat if you don't pay attention and especially if you aren't willing to run away until your ship and equipment is more up to the task.The other issue some might take is that this is all on a 2-D plane. So you don't go up or down with your ship, however fighters and objectives such an mine-able asteroids can be go/be off this plane. Turrets can handle these threats, but only if they can fire in that arc. As I discovered in mining however, you might need more then one of the expensive mining lasers to reach an asteroid depending on the turret placement and ship. They have a decent reach and make excellent short range beam weapons, but mining can be a pain and for as much investment you have to put into your ship to set it up to do right that can lead to some frustration.The Ugly:Unfortunately the game doesn't feel like it's fleshed out ship wise. There are 21 ships you can supposedly fly over the course of the game, and about half of those will be available to you from the start, a few more unlocked by leaving the first system, and a handful unlocked by faction reputation. It would have been nice to see some heavy armored and fast gunships, or some lighter armored glass cannons. There is a class of ship called 'strike craft' which seems to drop off by the end of the first system. The fighting can also get a little formulaic over time. I find running while my turrets pick off the fighters before engaging the larger ships to be the best road to success. Trading also can be a pain until you stumble upon the transponder that allows you to see the commodities of stations across the map without having to first dock at them.Verdict:If you enjoy broadsides and want a new type of scenario for your space faring adventures, this game might be just what you are looking for. If being a captain of a capital class ship isn't your cup of tea, then you still might want to pick it up on a sale. I recommend even at full price.

												Does not start on Mac OS Mavericks. Many people who do not want to upgrade to Mac OS ElCapitan for valid reasons have reported about this problem since early October 2015 and until now, 8 months later, this is not fixed. This is really bad service, as the problem seems to be quite simple to fix from the producers' side (make their launcher start in full screen without using the most fancy ElCapitan methods to do so). It is just about the launcher, not the game itself. This should be a simple task. However, without the launcher to set the game options, the game itself starts only in not-playable configuration. A catch-22 for the end user who has paid money for playing it. So, thumbs down from my side.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												First mission, with tutorials - controls: E/Q for engines up/down, W/S for speed boost/brake, A/D for turning left/right. So how do you change your pitch? You don't. That's right, this space sim is completely 2D. Everything is in the same plane - tars, planets, stations, ships. You can't even roll your ship. That's because combat is "naval" style - with broadsides! With the freedom of 3-dimensional space and with the technological possibilities of a spacefaring civilization, the best solution is to fire your guns from the sides of your ship, in the general direction of the enemy. Like sailships.Why didn't you make an actual sailship game? If you wanted alines, you could have made it in a fantasy setting, rather than Caribean, but your battle mechanics would make sense. Here, they just suck.Also, what good is my sensor system? I can scan other ships for cargo and battle strenght, but only after I'm so close that they actually attack. So scan that ship, see that it's too powerful, take a wide detour? Not happening. This is not a space simulation. Don't know what it is and don't want to know.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												I am actually surprised that a low buget game like Rebel Galaxy can have so much content in one go. Trading, Pirating, Distress calls, Even random events that affect the local markets or station access. The world is yours to toy with but you still need to pay attention to what is going on. You dont want to slam straight into a space station where there is a invasion going down. (Unless you are planning on clearing it up of course)The combat is different that in other space oriented games. As you are flying Capital grade ships you cant fly UP or DOWN. Sounds bad but hang on. Fact is you dont need to. With some work your ship becomes a flying fortress. With plasma !BROADSIDES! and enough turrets on it to wipe out a fleet.As for valuing defense and offence its your call. Personally i like being up close so i took some fast acting cannons for close quarters. More damage, less range. The game is FULL of tradeoffs when it comes to arnament. So you need to pick your method carefully. Personally i HIGHLY recommend this game to any game progression enthusiasts with a limited budget. The game is cheap, VERY long if you want to play all the way, and there are enough tactics and explosions around for a great experience. 10 out of 10 in my book.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												This game is everything I had hoped Elite Dangerous would be. Structurally, both games are very similar: you hop round the galaxy trading, mining, exploring, bounty-hunting and doing various missions, all the while earning credits so you can upgrade your ship and equipment. The main difference being this game removes all the tedium that ED insists you go through repeatedly and infinitely. Elite's station docking was fun for an hour or two, but after the 1000th dock, you just wish they'd just remove it...Rebel Galaxy removes this and you just insta-dock! Elite's 5 minutes with absolutely NOTHING to do while you warp to another station was never fun, and RG condenses this to a 10-30 second jump where you actually have some dodging and janking to do. Design decisions like this might make RG a more casual game than ED, but for me it also makes it 1000% more playable.This brings us to the combat. Purists will frown on Rebel Galaxy for it's 2-D implementation of space versus Elite's glorious 3D, but at the end of the day the combat is arcadey in both games, and RG's combat simply manages to be much more FUN. And certainly more epic. 30+ ship battles while you blast fighters with your short range turrets, broadside their capital ships and unleash homing missiles at everything else are far more epic than anyting Elite managed to throw my way.So my final description is that Rebel Galaxy is Elite with all the tedium removed, an actual story added, way better missions, and with considerably more fun combat. Which is what I've wanted in a space game since I racked up hundreds of hours of the original Elite on my Spectrum sometime back in the 1980s.TLDR: 8/10* this game is everything Elite Dangerous should have been* I would give this game 9/10 but for one annoying feature....you cannot view the local station map while docked. This means that you cannot easily plan the best cargo to buy or the best missions to take because you cannot see the optimum routes around the sector without seeing that local map. It's a quality of life thing that proves more frustrating than it might sound. If they fix that, this is a solid 9/10.

												This is a wonderful open-world space game with a lot to offer, but my hours are low and I'm giving it a thumbs-down because I just can't get past the horrid UI.The UI for this game is very obviously designed for consoles and not for PC, but even after plugging in a controller and trying it that way, I found myself getting frustrated.  Some things that I don't like, roughly in order of most irritating:Waiting for information to cycle.  When looking at commodities, whether on the commodities screen or on the map, instead of having a scrollable list, pages/lines will cycle every 4 seconds or so.  This creates a) a lot of waiting and b) you can't stop the cycle when your item comes up and actually read it.All scrolling lists and menus move one item at a time.  You can still select something with the mouse if it's on the screen, though, assuming you can see it or figure out what it is while it's grayed out.No way to display the sector map while docked.No way to create multiple waypoints, meaning you can't plan out routes that navigate around hostiles or asteroid belts.No way to zoom your camera in/out, resulting in a lot of screen space always being occupied by your (albeit gorgeous) ship.No speed indicator on the HUD, for you or your targets.If the UI gets fixed, I'll likely dump countless hours into this game and come back and rewrite my review, but until then, I can only say that it feels like a really clunky console port.

 Interested in No Man's Sky? Dissapointed in No Man's Sky? Just get Rebel Galaxy.  It has pretty much everything that that game has, but it also has a lot more. Here's a list of features: More world types (Sand, gas, etc... Can't land on 'em though) Large battlesA jobs boardShip renaming, Distress signals, Mercenaries, Bigger ships, Exploration bonuses Unique factions Faction affiliation, Randomly generated worlds You can be a trader, mercenary, pirate, soldier, miner, etc... You can actually negotiate your way out of battles! Space looks lovely, and the lighting and sound design is epic. Battles are absolute chaos, but awesome.  And all this paired with some great music! Whilst it is singleplayer, and is on a 2D plane (with 3D models, think Assassins Creed Black Flag Ships), it is much better than this game. You can travel across multiple star systems (not a whole galaxies, sadly), and each planet is randomly generated. Each planet has their own specialities (Mining, war-like, trading, prison planet(!), etc... Some are gas planets, some are barren, etc...You can't land on them, but that is pretty much my only gripe with this game. I bought this before I heard of No Man's Sky, so I was not dissapointed. But the game is still pretty as f###Raiding a trade ship can actually ruin the prices of a planet's economy, which you can then exploit. Selling munitions at a planet that is at war can get you more profit. There are multiple factions. Pirates, civilians, the militia, the mafia/crime bosses, or just be a merc! Small note to Angry Joe: You can scan any ship you want, see their race, freight, ship name, etc... ;) Also, it's 20 F###### DOLLARS.﻿

Posted: October 21, 2015
												I understood this game wouldn't have the real kind of depth I was looking for, but felt it would be good enough as a simple time killer.  I like the 2D plane naval style battles.  What I don't like is not owning multiple ships with different setups.  Mining is really more complicated than it should be for this type of game.  If my mining laser is on the bottom of the ship, good luck hitting an asteroid above your ship.  Scanning for asteroids gives no information of what you are mining for and as far as I can tell there is no item that does.  Certain weapons seemingly fire through your ship even though vision is blocked.  Really it's not a terrible game, but it's not a particularly good one.  Galaxy On Fire has more depth than this game.  The combat is good and interesting, the story is good and even the voice acting is good.  Graphics are fine.  Some small details were missed and the game was dumbed down more than it needed to be.  If you are looking for something really simple, then this game is for you.  It's on Galaxy On Fire's level.  If you are the type who likes the X Series or was into Eve Online and you were looking for something kind of in between in the single player realm, you will be slightly disappointed.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												(Review based on preview copy provided by developers)Rebel Galaxy is a Space Opera with some pretty legendary names behind its creation, and it definitely shows. There's no question that it's worth the asking price of $20 USD - though it does have its pros and cons worth considering if it's the perfect fit for you, as well as some gameplay aspects some people will enjoy more than others.----Important Notes:- This game involves trading, mining, and most of all - combat. - Combat is based on Naval combat, not standard 6-degree space combat, you will be using broadside cannons, ramming, and turrets for your capital ship on a horizontal plane (non capital ships use the full 6 degrees of freedom, but you don't get to fly those :P). This leads to interesting, yet still very satisfying, combat.- You have access to a lot of control with your ship, a lot of choices, including what tools you employ and how your weapons behave in battle - and they definitely have an impact on how you play.-You also have the ability to toy with alliances and factions, to change the system (improving/destroying your relations with different factions changes how you play the game)- Combat, either through Bounties, Missions, or Random Encounters will be your fastest way to gather resources and progress - though Trading/Mining are definitely still somewhat viable options.----Pros:- Good visuals, with satisfying explosions, weapon fire, etc. And visible damage on your ship.- Amazing audio assets (and the ability to customize the audio if you want). Voice Acting is "good", not stellar, but the explosions, music, etc. are insanely well chosen.- Combat caters to both the casual captain and the aggressive player ( you can hang out on the fringe of battles, letting the automated turrets do the work, or you can dive in ramming/blasting with your broadsides, while ducking and dodging through swarms of bullets)- Solid story, while it won't win any awards, it's on par with Blizzard storylines ( "Okay" campaign story, Great universe )- Lots of freedom of choice... and travel. Aided by procedural generation of the sectors - so no 2 playthroughs are the same.- Fairly well optimized (sad that I have to note this, but compared to a lot of other games with similar visual fidelity lately - this one barely taxes my system at max settings)----Cons:- Can get repetative after a while (go to point a, Kill stuff, get money, repeat) - but this tends to happen after the 10-20 hour mark for me. It does follow a formula similar to Diablo/Torchlight/etc. in that regard. - Can be slow paced at times, especially when a mission spawns more than 5000-6000 sm away, there is no fast travel within a sector, and while warp is fine for medium length trips, you will sometimes run into the issue of "staring at the back of your ship twiddling your thumbs". - "Out of Game" options menu... each time you launch you have the choice of changing the options, but you can't really change them in-game - so you might be restarting a few times to find the settings perfect for you.----Works well with a controller or mouse & keyboard, despite their recommendations.

												I was hoping for Mount and Blade meets Firefly. What I got was neither. This game has so much potential, but is hugley hurt by a number of things.(If you're wondering why my play time is so low its because I plan to get a refund and because the glaring problems are obvious from the start.)Firstly the thing I noticed first that bugged me was that, you ARE LOCKED TO A SINGLE PLANE OF MOVEMENT!(sounds small but it is SO annoying) Now if this were top down, this wouldnt be a problem, but the view is thrid person, making it painfully obvious how limited you are. What makes it worse is that other ships (including those you fight) can fly freely, making combat confusing and disorienting.Second, the graphics, nice enough at first (tough not at all cutting edge) but the problem there isn't poorly done graphics, it's OVERDONE graphics, I am being entirley honest when I say that the lens flare/ lighting effects during (one dimensional)'flight' actually HURT to look at.And finally, parts of it just feel....off. Little things, like a cramped UI in stations with loads of wasted space, or dialogues with characters (which are admittedley quite nicley done) feeling far too zoomed in and with no ability to use the keyboard for dialouge choices (up, down, enter or even 1,2 and 3).It's a nice idea that wasn't done badly, but its just not quite 'right' to play. I cant honestley recommend it.

content:
Posted: April 12
												Space exploration game. It's like a super dumbed down Elite: Dangerous, which would be amazing EXCEPT combat is impossibly frustrating. Why? The whole combat system is based on side cannons, like a pirate ship in space. Only thing is, you cant move in a 3D space. Not so bad, except for your enemies can. Still not the worst, seems like it's ok, until you realize you can't aim your side cannons up or down. So the whole time, if you have unguided cannons, you're missing. You get 3 hits on a guy, deplete their shields, and then they fly below you. You can't aim at them, your turrets miss majority of the time, and by the time you can hit them again their shields are refilled. Awful combat system, making the game so frustrating that large fights become impossible.

Then it's just endless grinding. I'm not going to ever play this game again, because I'd have to start a new game, which would be a ton of grinding to get to where I was, which was a part of the game that involved grinding. I think the price is fair, but I can't say that it's actually worth all the time required to beat it. If you play it for a dozen or more hours and have a good time, just stop when you don't like it any more. It will not change or get better.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2015
												I've logged 34 hours into the game as of writing this review.The game has been nothing short of an exceptional experience. From the very moment you start the game, you get a good sense of what you're getting into. The music sets the tone to this sort of grungy, rockabilly space Western. It's full of character has a good sense of "space". All this despite playing like a sort of "World of Warships meets Elite: Dangerous" hybrid between space exploration and naval combat. I highly recommend buying this game.Pros:Full controller support (including optional Playstation layout).Tight Mouse&Keyboard controls.Very pretty graphics and effects.Visible modular ship damage.Many graphics settings in the launcher.Superb soundtrack.Optional custom soundtrack to replace OR supplement the original soundtrack.Fluid combat mechanics.More lasers than I sometimes know what to do with.Unique and lively NPC interactions.Moderate learning curve.VERY attentive and responsive developers constantly patching reported issues.Cons:Enemy dialogue is sometimes repetitive.No vertical travel (2D movement only).Objects (like Cargo) sometimes block docking or other actions.Slaves (Cargo) have no clear way to be saved other than forfeiting to Militia (-4 rep penalty).Single-player only (for now).

content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												Game is fun, but limited. This game is Sid Meier's Pirates LITE. You have no major interaction with any factions, and can not partake in major game map changing ways. It's essentially the combat of Sid Meier's in Space, with nothing close to SMP's metagame. It's the very definition of shallow. Everything will one way or another end up with a blaster in your face. You want to trade or mine? Good luck. You'll be needing a good turret.Ultimately I don't recommend this game despite the fact that I know a lot of people may enjoy it. I respect it's sea-naval intentions, but I just am TOO much of a fan of proper scifi stuff and not arcade based games to enjoy this.My ideal Scifi games are along the lines of Nexus, and Homeworld. I find this to be very simplistic, to it's own detriment because it gets CLUSMY quickly with combat. It's not hard to stay oriented, but it is HARDER than it should be. Camera + controls (really, gamepad optimal, who are you kidding) + enemies + lack of distinct options controlling your own weapons makes this game a hassle. Added on top of it, that it's a big ol'grind fest in a single player game, and you lose my interest quickly.That said, there aren't a lot of good scifi options these days, so a lot of people will find the 20$ entry fee to be acceptable for the amount of entertainment within.

												Anyone that's played (or even remembers) Escape Velocity will probably enjoy this game.Rebel Galaxy is a fun space combat/trading/mining/exploration game, giving you a lot of ways to earn money and kick♥♥♥♥♥ The ship piloting controls are on a 2d plane, which may seem frustrating to some, but it's honestly a great decision. content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												9/10Fantastic space fairing action.The trailers caught my attention with nice colourful space battles some time ago, but nothing prepared me for how fun this game was. I went in cautiously as it breaks one of main rules for space battling games, thou shall not restrict motion to a 2D plane, but I needn't have worried.  Combat is fast and tactical and full to the brim with laser beams and tracer fire and trailing missiles while surrounded by explosions, while you're led along either by your own need (to gain bigger ships and guns) or the story that lies within.The story was reasonably interesting and lifted up by some surprisingly competent voice acting but woefully under developed, but with this game's price point it would be daft to expect more than what was already crammed in, I just lamented that one of the characters in game was not pushed more to the front along side the player in a MasterChief / Cortana style relationship. Graphically the game takes its own style and runs with it, with some of the ship designs varying from interesting to inspired, though I would've liked to have seen more of the fighters and gunships. With player control being restricted to larger ships (frigates up to drednaughts) there was a missed oppurtunity for building a squadron of fighter level craft to follow you about. Perhaps that's something the developers could investigate for DLC or a sequel.This game was a surprise in terms of quality. If you want a space game in the vein of Elite that makes with the action and less with the simulation, you will find a home here for some time. The 40 hours I've spent with this title will attest to that.

												It has been a long time since I was addicted to a game like I am to this. I've played a lot of space simulator type games since I first discovered the genre in the legendary game: Freelancer - all have fallen short of my expectations. This game however is the anomaly - the one that given enough time and attention could very well rival it one day in my opinion.The biggest problem I originally had with this game is the fact you can only move on a 2d plane - I've gotten used to it and it isn't a big deal - it is part of the charm now. The other issue that I've found is with mining - it doesn't seem to be very profitable - though I've not tried it much since the starting system, I was always getting worthless materials with a few valuables mixed in. Trading was vastly more profitable and completing mission reasonably better - this means I never mine, which I find ashame as it could be interesting if it were more profitable.Sometimes I think the danger levels given in some missions is a tad "off" so to speak - doing a delivery of cargo mission with an "average" to "below average" rating and getting ambushed by what seems dozens of enemies - them ripping through my ship in seconds and dampening my engines so I can't escape or dictate the fight - after you've run a few of those types of mission, you expect it and are maneurvering and ready for it - isn't such a big deal then.On the plus side - the music, it fits so perfectly, I'd like more tracks but the ones they have are really good. I like the fact I'm not forced to go down the main story line, I'm off in different systems doing different mission and buying bigger ships - that is the freedom I expect (but sometimes don't get) in open world games. Combat is fun, the broadsides and turrets seem to be equally useful. The progression is great - though I find it a tad odd I can equip level 5 (which is what I'm up to) turrets/shields/engine etc on the smaller ships - surely they have to use more power or something? Meh doesn't really matter. All in all I'm very happy I bought this game and don't see myself stopping for awhile.

												It's good. Really, it is. It's not, however, amazing. The short: The storyline is... cursory, at best. The game would lose virtually nothing if it weren't there at all. There are some annoyances in missions and travelling, and you need to be comfortable with the need to grind for gear, but all in all it's a very enjoyable space shooter.The long:As I've seen mentioned in other reviews, there's an almost consistent misrepresentation of the mission risk. Low? It could be, then again you could also barely make it out with an inch of hull left. Other times you end up against a ship you literally do not have the damage output to even touch the shields on. High? It could be. It could also be a milk run. It just doesn't make any sense.You do learn to recognize them, though. Some mission types seem straight forward, but will always end with you having to deliver something to a station that's under siege. Skip those. Escort missions are a pain, as in pretty much all games, Fancy waiting 2-3 minutes while your ship lines itself up for the escort? Fancy doing that numerous times as the journey is interrupted along the way? How about inside an asteroid field, where your ship keeps getting stuck on rocks, adding another few minutes. At first, I learned this was a perfect time to go fetch something to drink. Or check email. Or read a page or two of a book. Later, I learned to just save my sanity and skip them. Eventually I did learn a set of mission types I could reliably predict the difficulty of, and I just stuck with those and ignored everything else.There's a fair amount of travelling required, which is to be expected. Space is big, after all. What isn't fine is how often your travels are interrupted. There are countless asteroid and junk fields littered about, and odds are you'll be pulled out of warp a handful of times on most journeys. Which means you then need to crawl along to the edge before you can get back up to speed. If you pay attention you can spot some of them and go around. Not going in a straight line from one place to the next, also seems to help. Then there are the random enemy encounters, which have the same effect of slowing you down. You can spend time fighting them (if they are ship types and numbers you can handle), for loot worth next to nothing most of the time, or turn your tail and boost out of there. In most cases that'll have you on your way again in 30 seconds or so.So why the heck am I recommending it? I guess I must really like spaceships. And lasers. I had great fun, despite the above mentioned drawbacks. Enough so that I put 40 hours into it. After finishing the story, I kept going until I had the best ship fully upgraded. I then went back in a few more times to just fly around enjoying being invincible. For entertainment value, it was a bargain for the price.

Posted: November 17, 2015
												I would highly recommend this game for anyone who loves space games, whether you like to mine some asteroids, go bounty hunting or do some trading, this game has loads of fun for you. Graphics are beautiful on my mid-2012 MacBook Pro, that music gets you going and is easily turned off if that's your thing.  The only technical issues I had was to tweak the graphics settings down a little to help frame rate, restart the game after 3+ hours of gaming to fix the sound playback issues, and some Steam achievements not unlocking properly; nothing major and easily overcome for the most part.Trading is challenging, resources are scarce and requires you to carry multiple different items to fill your cargo holds, which you will need to partially unload/load at various points to do a full trade route.  There is money to be made, although progress is slower than fighting.  If you don't like fighting, its probably the easiest path.  If you get attacked, you always have the option to jettison some cargo and be on your way; you will make good friends with the pirates too!Mining is usually relaxing and uneventful, but you still have to be on the lookout for that surprise attack.  As with trading, progress is a bit slower than fighting,Talking about fighting, its definitely a lot more about strategy and positioning that it would be about flying skills.  In large fights, you find a way to pull a few ships away from the cluster, blow them to bits and repeat.  You control the position of your ship on a large 2-d plane, there is no such thing as a barrel roll so you probably don't have to worry about getting sick.  Aiming can be challenging when controlling the turrets yourself, so you might want to man the missile launchers or side ports cannons.Comes highly recommended, just make sure you check the difficulty levels of the mission before accepting them or even progressing through the story line or you will feel the heat when your ship core explode!

												This is a great game and tkaes hours to completely play through it.For 20 bucks I would say that this game is worth the cost and should get a best value award for the content that it brings to the table for the cost.To sum the game up you are a called in by your Aunt to go to the nastiest part of the galaxy and you have to fend for yourself. You find a relic that you repair and eventually you collect parts to repair the AI's memory. The AI then decides to sacrifice itself for the greater good and that's how the storyline rolls.As for the game play you'll find yourself warping throughout space fighting all types of spaceships and different situations which I found really fun to do.The game has a high difficulty curve so be warned, this game isn't for those really really casual gamers and is geared more towards those who can think on their feet and react quickly to different situations. If you need to remember to press your scanning key which is TAB by default to freeze the game and analyze the situation.I did 2 play throughs of the game one as a good guy and one as a bad guy. Both were pretty satisfying but it is really hard to be a bad guy. The storyline gears you toward being a good guy and to earn bad guy rep to actually enter their ports takes a long time. In the meantime you have to not♥♥♥♥♥♥off the civilians otherwise you'll have no ports that you can call your home and all you'll meet there is your end. No worries though missions will help keep your rep up so that shouldn't happen unless you get reckless.The game also does not limit you in what you want to do. I skipped the storyline and worked my way towards the endgame before coming back to complete it. By the time I finished the storyline on my first run through I already had a blackgate that was decked out with MK 5 pulse turrets that decimated anything that strayed within their range of fire. On the second play through I bought a quick ship (the Icarus) and rushed towards the end game areas and did adrenaline rush dead drop missions for hundreds of thousands of credits to reach the end game faster which felt really satisfying to do.Overall I loved the graphics of the game, it has a good soundtrack which you can make your own custom soundtrack as well, and the sound quality of the game is great as well. The only thing I am waiting on now to see if they will release DLC for the game or make a second sequel to the game which I will be more than happy to buy. If you like flying spaceships then give this game a try I promise that it will be worth your money.

												Just think Firefly + Cowboy Bebop = Rebel Galaxy.Didn't know what all to expect when watching the trailers, so I thought "What the hell, I'll give it a shot." 												Rebel Galaxy is a great game that has plenty of good balance to it, though granted I had to remind myself it wasn’t Freelancer* with all its similarities. With the constant reminder that your piloting a 2 dimensional ship through 3 dimensional space that makes use of primary functions for broad fire tactic’s while combatting fighter vessels that can fly in any direction was easy to notice the uniqueness Rebel Galaxy Possess in standing out from the rest of the space games to hit the market. One thing that would keep me engaged as a Gamer is the really good work with the Music Que’s between combat and Station Menu navigation. Yes you still get the option to customize your own music to the game, but speaking as an Audio Editor, there was some really good work into allowing the music to que into the combat scene’s. The music is so good that I even had the pleasure to find the list posted by Travis Baldree on the dev’s website Sound Track List**. Granted I enjoy my gameplay and found myself wanting a bit more in the way of controls, but I constantly found the fact of the simplified combat and turret options in ship to ship combat well simplified. I partly wished I could have been able to explore the stations or board the ships that constantly threatened me to get sucked into space, so as only to just see that I could do it, but still we wouldn’t have had such a well-planned out 2 Dimensional controlled 3D Space Combat game. Pro’s:•	Short but worthwhile story•	Simplified Ship controls•	Great Music Selections•	Persistent Markets when selling commodities – even gives a history on the price of the item, and system average for the entire System you’re in.•	Great Map Design and navigation assistance though lacks a little in cross coordination with other implemented features of the game.Con’s:•	Not Exactly Merchant Friendly: Always a hassle trying to find a price for a single item between all known locations that buy and sell commodities of a certain type. Would have like an option that allowed seeing at a quick list of last known prices at all stations for a single commodity.•	Stellar Mass often times stopping warp while not even in the way of the travel.•	Not all ships are available, can’t truly pilot a fighter or gunship.•	Not able to change direction up or down to evade Stellar mass in a direct collision course•	Not able to properly map Cone of angles for the turret systems being applied to the ships. (Kinda handy when attempting to do mining to know where the laser fire can reach.)•	Limitation to the Components that can be installed on all ships.•	Not able to easily pull up the map when needing to make a quick reference to a station or asteroid mining location when getting info or finding merchandise while in space.•	Limited to a single Mercenary Hire, can’t recruit an armada of Mercenaries. Freelancer* https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freelancer_(video_game)Sound Track List** http://rebel-galaxy.com/the-rebel-galaxy-soundtrack/

Posted: October 22, 2015
												This is pretty much the space game I always wanted to play.  Not overly complicated with way too many systems to learn, just having fun flying around a beautiful galaxy, trading materials, destroying space pirates, and listening to an awesome Firely-esque soundtrack! The game takes place on a 2D plane, with an emphasis on broadside combat, but the option for other forms of attack such as turrets, lasers, mines, etc. exists.  Basically, if you've ever played Assassin's Creed IV, the game plays very similarly to the boat sailing and combat, only more responsive and more entertaining.  There are 21 ships available to purchase and fly, as well as many items for customizing them, including weapons, defense, and more!Pros:-Runs perfectly with little to no slowdown.-Beautiful graphics with plenty of options to change.-Great music, with an easy option to add your own music in a number of areas, such as battle music, ambient music, etc.-Big universe.  While not nearly as big as other space games out there, it's still plenty big.  I've played six hours so far and haven't even left the first galaxy that you start in, and there seems to be at least 10+ to explore.-Price: $18 at launch ($20 later) is a steal for this game.  It runs smoother and I haven't encountered any bugs so far, which is more than I can say for many of the AAA games that I've payed $60 for recently.-Most importantly: FUN! Cons: -One of the only cons I would say is that there doesn't seem to be much in the way of a damage model for ships.  If you ship is severely damaged, you may see a few minor explosions and fire going on around it, but you aren't missing any chunks of your ship or anything like that.  Pretty minor in the long run when compared with all the pros.-Possible con is that many of the side missions are similar, so you could get burned out after a while.  The positive is that you can do the story missions which offer a bit more variety, or take a break and play something else for a while!-Not really a con, but you can only save when you dock at a space station, which can be a bit annoying if you need to leave suddenly, but there are plenty of space stations, usually less than a minute away, and the game offers an easy option to find the nearest space station.Overall, if you're looking for a fun game with a cheap price, look no further than Rebel Galaxy.

												If your a fan of the t.v series "Firefly", you will adore this game. Space meets the wild west of america. You can pretty much play however you want to really, either as a pirate, a merc, a bounty hunter, a trader, a do-gooder, a member of the system milita or anything else that comes to mind. Factions are present in the game and you can change your relations with the vast amount of them. The milita, citizens, red devil cartel and others are the major "players". There is a lot of replay-ability in this game and each playthrough offers a lot to do. Any valuable free time?, prepare for it to simply cease existing.There are quite the variety of ships to choose form each with their own playstyle and role in combat, ranging from corvettes to huge dreadnaughts bristling with firepower. Also, RAMMING SPEED! is completley viable when you get the right deflector shield. >:DIn terms of preformance, the game is pretty well optimized and I havent experienced any FPS drops nor crashes or glitches in the game so far. The only real issue is with the set up for the graphics being done out side of the game before launch. Other than that the game has rebindable keys for those wanting to change their keyboard set up and is also usable with a game pad as well.Finally lets get some of the "meh" points out of the way: 1) such as only being a 2D plain which really isnt to much of a problem (unless your a 3D space I WANNA GO EVERYWHERE fanatic) but a 3D plain would be nice but the game still works great with just 2D, and 2) being only a singleplayer experience which is great but the concept of playing with friends in co-op or being in a large server with many others effecting the world of rebel galaxy together. The possabilites are pretty big. Think player made factions and guilds fighting wars for resources or player made pirate groups raiding player escorted relief convoys that will effect economys in the game and the major factions relations and standing in the world.Overall I would very much recomend this game to anybody who is a fan of si-fi and or western drama with its beautiful world and fun gameplay with a large choice of options and intense ship on ship combat.I hope to see you all out there in this mad galaxy my fellow starship captains! for profit! for reputation! and for being the greatest badasses that this galaxy's ever seen!

												Needs polish but I can forgive its sins since it was only $20.  Great space cowboy soundtrack, graphics, gameplay.  Yadda yadda.What rustles my jimmies though is that it suffers from escort mission hell; something I'd hoped gaming had put behind it a long time ago.  Escort quests are quite simply, broken.  Slow, tedious and prone to utter disfunction.  Escorts will charge the nearest enemy capital ship and hump its broadside.  To proceed, you must endure the synchronized lumbering of both ships as they sluggishly array themselves for a joint warp jump constantly broken by dozens of random junk gravity wells and meaningless random hostile encounters.  More synchronized lumbering, jump, stop, fight/lumber some more, ad infinitum.  THEN you might not EVER reach your destination anyway as the pathing seems to bug out; I had one escort mission start/stop over 15 times before it broke entirely, seperating me from the escort mid jump and causing a mission failure on what felt like a half hour pain test.  A shame that the broken escort quest system was pushed out the door.  The whole sync-jump thing needs to go.  Have the damn escort follow YOU, not the other way around.And upon first installation I had some random crash-your-pc bug going on.  A suggestion from the dev to turn on the vsync and swith the render engine to dx9 seemed to fix it though.  Kudos to the dev for quickly helping people in the forums with tech problems.If it was a $60 game, I'd be angry.  I'm more forgiving of a budget title, especially since the rest of the game really is very nice, even the characters in the space stations and voice work.  Found amusement in just listening to the wierd animated alien jabber they came up with for some species rather than just clicking through it.  Despite my griping I have truly enjoyed my time with Rebel Galaxy and look forward to finishing it.  Better than many $60 titles I've picked up in my time.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												A fantastic title if you're looking for a robust starship sim. You select your craft from a wealth of options that range from a speedy corvette-class vessel to a dreadnought bristling with a dozen turrets. Combat is reminiscent of naval warfare, where you try to position yourself to blast your foes with powerful broadside weaponry and the options for arming yourself are truly staggering. You can arm your ship with particle beams, mines, flak cannons, missiles, anti-matter cannons, pulse turrets... there's an option for every playstyle and you can sink hours into perfecting your unique ship.There's a wealth of content to be had but the downside is that a lot of it can grow repetitive. Upgrades for your ship don't come cheap and as difficulty spikes can be quite jarring you'll find yourself doing a lot of the same basic missions over and over again to get yourself up to snuff. The mechanics themselves are a joy, though, which really helps to ease this shortcoming and the moment to moment opportunities for profit allow you to choose between piracy, mercenary activity or just plain honest trade.All in all, if you're looking for a space sim that will spoil you for choice, Rebel Galaxy is the game for you.

												Okay, so I just finished the main quest and feel like I'm ready to give my 2 cents. First impressions are good! Great soundtrack, the early space battles have a nice intuitive rock-scissor-paper-feel (probably got them in the wrong order). Mid-game, I'm kind of grinding for credits. I need so and so many million to reach tier 6-weapons and to maybe fight the big battles and come out on top. I don't know if I made it too easy, but I went for the fast "Barracuda" so I could out-maneuver and out-run my enemies and then pick the fighters of off in bite-size chunks and move in to the "blind spots" of the capital ships and just wear them down with ma lazers..  Where was I.. yes the grind! It came to a point where my strategy was sound, but I still didn't feel ready to further the main quest. Lots of grinding later I had my weapons and went in to the much to short late-game and now I'm the hero. And still don't feel like I care about my aunt! I mean, for a game that has the plot-hook, that I want to find my aunt and help her, then they should have focused more on the story-line and flesh out the characters of the game. Most of the missions where fun the first 25 times I did them, except for the escort missions, they NEVER became any fun. While you're in the middle of fighting capital ships and fighters, your escort-buddy up and killed himself. Poor form! The funniest side mission was when a discreet gentleman needed my assistance to reacquire lost items. When I get to the pick up, the cargo is pin-up monthly magazines! The gentleman was shipping dirty magazines and suddenly I understand why I was under oath not to tell his wife. Those kind of quirky side-missions makes me smile. I don't know who that man is, but I instantly like both him and his wife and I'm curious about their relationship and his business enterprise. It's like the developers have good story-writers but they are put on writing up side-missions instead of making sure the follow-through for the main story is solid. If you want 10+ hours of fun, go get it! If you another 10 hours of grind look no further! It's good enough game and I give it my dubious thumbs up. =)

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												Negatives:- Lack of innovation. This is a copy of the (working) Wing Commander Privateer formula, albeit in two dimensions.- Balance issues when it comes to weapon choice.- Minor progression spiking issues. For example, there are times when you find one salvage item that is worth more than your next 10 entire missions.- Lack of end game. Basically once you have Mark 6 shields and pulse turrets the game is over.- The decision to make this a 2D game makes little sense to me. It takes away from the astrobatics experience and simplifies gameplay.- Some tedious game mechanics with warp travel. Finding an asteroid belt with some salvage seems meant to be a nice surprise, but in reality it's just annoying because it drops you out of warp and the only salvages (as far as I know) which give high-credit equipment rather than commodities are the ones you take off of ships. The number of times I had to veer just to the right or left of an asteroid and use thrusters to get back into a safe state to use warp drive was far too many.Positives:- Provides good value for $20, especially if you are a huge fan of the series' that it takes from (Privateer, Dark Star One).- Stable. No real performance issues.I know the negatives list is longer than the positives, but I would still recommend the game if you are a space exploration fan just looking for a remake of Privateer without the daunting depth of X3.

												9/10Fantastic space fairing action.The trailers caught my attention with nice colourful space battles some time ago, but nothing prepared me for how fun this game was. I went in cautiously as it breaks one of main rules for space battling games, thou shall not restrict motion to a 2D plane, but I needn't have worried.  Combat is fast and tactical and full to the brim with laser beams and tracer fire and trailing missiles while surrounded by explosions, while you're led along either by your own need (to gain bigger ships and guns) or the story that lies within.The story was reasonably interesting and lifted up by some surprisingly competent voice acting but woefully under developed, but with this game's price point it would be daft to expect more than what was already crammed in, I just lamented that one of the characters in game was not pushed more to the front along side the player in a MasterChief / Cortana style relationship. Graphically the game takes its own style and runs with it, with some of the ship designs varying from interesting to inspired, though I would've liked to have seen more of the fighters and gunships. With player control being restricted to larger ships (frigates up to drednaughts) there was a missed oppurtunity for building a squadron of fighter level craft to follow you about. Perhaps that's something the developers could investigate for DLC or a sequel.This game was a surprise in terms of quality. If you want a space game in the vein of Elite that makes with the action and less with the simulation, you will find a home here for some time. The 40 hours I've spent with this title will attest to that.

												I have long been a fan of Freelancer to the point I have spent years lementing the fact that my system no longer supports it. I have played more games then I can honestly count, here I have found some thing of that long lost love. This game gives yopu a huge freedom of movement and choice, an interesting story where you actually effect some of the outcomes, not to mention addicting combat. One of the best parts is taking on random jobs as a no-name Merc trying to build up your ship and reputation. Just when you think your ship is bad♥♥♥♥♥ and your a king of the stars you find out that the Galaxy is a much bigger place then you first realized and that you are little more then a fly in space. Don't be discouraged because this is part of what makes this game amazing, it evolves, it challanges you, it makes you work for what you want without just coddling you like so many games. The learning curve isn't too extreme but starting out you will find sooner then later that you need to make money if you want to survive and it gives you a number of options to achieve this ranging from saving beligured stations, rescue Merchants who are on the short end of luck, There are also the Merchant and Mercenary guilds that give you a huge oppurtunity to expand your reach with jobs, equipment and ships. All the while you have to decide which side of the law you are on. Are you a Pirate? Smuggler? A devil may care merc, or a hero, or are you some kind of mix between. If you want a game that is strangely addicting, well made, with a good sound track (honestly the best I have ever heard) It is like Firefly meets Freelancer. If that doesn't impress you then you have no soul, if it does, strap in for one hell of an inter-stellar ride.

												Okay, this is a great game, ive got a fair few hours into it and am far from being bored. However, the game has a lot of things which need to be fixed:- The difficulty system, please oh please fix the difficulty system. For those of you that don't know, when you accept a mission the game tells you how difficult it is based on your ship, which is great. Except it's horrifically broken right now, i have absolutely dominated "hard difficulty" missions and been absolutely rekt on easy difficulty missions, the system, to put it plainly, is pointless in it's current state-Fighter class ships, they are supposed to be these little craft which acompany larger ships to help them in fights. However some missions you get only fighter class ships, and they are hilariously overpowered. In a fight of me vs 7 normal sized ships(roughly my own ships size) i can win if i use tactics, a bit of luck and a lot of guns. But in a me vs 7 fighter class ships? Heck no, i get dominated like a david and goliath fight. Let's not forget that these are supposed to be small, relatively weak ships which fight you AS WELL AS regular ship, it makes some parts of the game completely impossible, such as a mission i went on recently. The mission was simple- destroy a chrono relay and any response squad you encounter. The relay was easy, the response squad? 30 fighter ships surrounding my ships on every single direction. They closed in and there was no way to get through them without ramming through one part of the blockgade they had formed, which i did and i was unsurprised to find my shields and hull drop faster than call of duty's sales. 												I believe I've put enough time into this game to warrant a fair review. On a personal note, this is the only game in my library where I've had to think really hard about giving it a thumbs up or down.What is it: imagine a sid meiers pirates in space. Its open world, with emphasis on combat. You fly into two dimensional space combat and shoot your broadside cannons into your opponent. I'm not praising or condemning this mechanic, its just the way it is. You can trade, but in the most simple sense of the word, the game tells you which resources are too highly priced/ lowly priced in each station. If you cannot complete the next required story mission, the only thing you can do is to go grind for more credits to upgrade until you can.Pros- SimpleCons- Too simpleThe lightspeed travelling is really annoying, I've spent probably more than half my ingame time travelling from A to B and you automatically drop out of "warp" if you encounter something. So you have to sit there listening to a very limited soundtrack waiting an average of about a minute till you reach your destination, trying to avoid asteroid fields etc. Longest warp time has been around 2 minutes, you get where you need to go, blow someone up and spend 2 minutes warping back.I didnt make it past the second world by the time I decided to stop playing (so I can only give information relevant up to that point in the game). Your main source of damage against big ships are your broadsides and missiles, this requires no planning or skill. Fire as much and as fast as you can and hope they blow up first. If you blow up first, dont retry, you will die again, there is no strategy to change. Upgrade one module on your ship (shield, broadside, turret) go back and you'll win. Rinse and repeat. Dont get me wrong the first hour is a blast but when you realise that you've experienced 90% of the game already, its pretty demoralising - and I'm not one to sit there to finish grinding it through till the end just for the sake of completion (though it took me a while to come to that conclusion).

												I had a really great time playing this game. It seems strange at first and I thought there's something wrong with my set up because I couldn't pitch forward or pull up. I investigated and realized that the game only plays like a battleship in space. You turn left and right but you don't pull up or pitch forward. I almost decided to ask for my money back but I decided to give it a few more minutes of playtime and realized I was really having a lot of fun. The graphics are awesome and the battles are great. You have main broadside cannons that are forward and rearward 90° from the side of your ship, and then small cannons mounted in various places that automatically fire at fighters. You can take control of the small cannons but you have so much going on it's better just to control the broadside cannons to take out the big ships you're fighting while you let the small cannons work independently on the fighters.There is definitely strategy that you need to use in this game. You'll find yourself suddenly surrounded and if you don't get out fast you'll be pounded to space junk. I recommend the long burning sub light thrusters. They managed to get me out of most tight spots. Make sure you always buy the newest shields, broadsides, and thrusters that are being offered as fast as you can.To sum it up, whenever I spend $17.99 and get 80 hours worth of fun, I figure I'm doing pretty dang good! It's totally worth the money!

												Needs polish but I can forgive its sins since it was only $20.  Great space cowboy soundtrack, graphics, gameplay.  Yadda yadda.What rustles my jimmies though is that it suffers from escort mission hell; something I'd hoped gaming had put behind it a long time ago.  Escort quests are quite simply, broken.  Slow, tedious and prone to utter disfunction.  Escorts will charge the nearest enemy capital ship and hump its broadside.  To proceed, you must endure the synchronized lumbering of both ships as they sluggishly array themselves for a joint warp jump constantly broken by dozens of random junk gravity wells and meaningless random hostile encounters.  More synchronized lumbering, jump, stop, fight/lumber some more, ad infinitum.  THEN you might not EVER reach your destination anyway as the pathing seems to bug out; I had one escort mission start/stop over 15 times before it broke entirely, seperating me from the escort mid jump and causing a mission failure on what felt like a half hour pain test.  A shame that the broken escort quest system was pushed out the door.  The whole sync-jump thing needs to go.  Have the damn escort follow YOU, not the other way around.And upon first installation I had some random crash-your-pc bug going on.  A suggestion from the dev to turn on the vsync and swith the render engine to dx9 seemed to fix it though.  Kudos to the dev for quickly helping people in the forums with tech problems.If it was a $60 game, I'd be angry.  I'm more forgiving of a budget title, especially since the rest of the game really is very nice, even the characters in the space stations and voice work.  Found amusement in just listening to the wierd animated alien jabber they came up with for some species rather than just clicking through it.  Despite my griping I have truly enjoyed my time with Rebel Galaxy and look forward to finishing it.  Better than many $60 titles I've picked up in my time.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												It's good. Really, it is. It's not, however, amazing. The short: The storyline is... cursory, at best. The game would lose virtually nothing if it weren't there at all. There are some annoyances in missions and travelling, and you need to be comfortable with the need to grind for gear, but all in all it's a very enjoyable space shooter.The long:As I've seen mentioned in other reviews, there's an almost consistent misrepresentation of the mission risk. Low? It could be, then again you could also barely make it out with an inch of hull left. Other times you end up against a ship you literally do not have the damage output to even touch the shields on. High? It could be. It could also be a milk run. It just doesn't make any sense.You do learn to recognize them, though. Some mission types seem straight forward, but will always end with you having to deliver something to a station that's under siege. Skip those. Escort missions are a pain, as in pretty much all games, Fancy waiting 2-3 minutes while your ship lines itself up for the escort? Fancy doing that numerous times as the journey is interrupted along the way? How about inside an asteroid field, where your ship keeps getting stuck on rocks, adding another few minutes. At first, I learned this was a perfect time to go fetch something to drink. Or check email. Or read a page or two of a book. Later, I learned to just save my sanity and skip them. Eventually I did learn a set of mission types I could reliably predict the difficulty of, and I just stuck with those and ignored everything else.There's a fair amount of travelling required, which is to be expected. Space is big, after all. What isn't fine is how often your travels are interrupted. There are countless asteroid and junk fields littered about, and odds are you'll be pulled out of warp a handful of times on most journeys. Which means you then need to crawl along to the edge before you can get back up to speed. If you pay attention you can spot some of them and go around. Not going in a straight line from one place to the next, also seems to help. Then there are the random enemy encounters, which have the same effect of slowing you down. You can spend time fighting them (if they are ship types and numbers you can handle), for loot worth next to nothing most of the time, or turn your tail and boost out of there. In most cases that'll have you on your way again in 30 seconds or so.So why the heck am I recommending it? I guess I must really like spaceships. And lasers. I had great fun, despite the above mentioned drawbacks. Enough so that I put 40 hours into it. After finishing the story, I kept going until I had the best ship fully upgraded. I then went back in a few more times to just fly around enjoying being invincible. For entertainment value, it was a bargain for the price.

												It's good. Really, it is. It's not, however, amazing. The short: The storyline is... cursory, at best. The game would lose virtually nothing if it weren't there at all. There are some annoyances in missions and travelling, and you need to be comfortable with the need to grind for gear, but all in all it's a very enjoyable space shooter.The long:As I've seen mentioned in other reviews, there's an almost consistent misrepresentation of the mission risk. Low? It could be, then again you could also barely make it out with an inch of hull left. Other times you end up against a ship you literally do not have the damage output to even touch the shields on. High? It could be. It could also be a milk run. It just doesn't make any sense.You do learn to recognize them, though. Some mission types seem straight forward, but will always end with you having to deliver something to a station that's under siege. Skip those. Escort missions are a pain, as in pretty much all games, Fancy waiting 2-3 minutes while your ship lines itself up for the escort? Fancy doing that numerous times as the journey is interrupted along the way? How about inside an asteroid field, where your ship keeps getting stuck on rocks, adding another few minutes. At first, I learned this was a perfect time to go fetch something to drink. Or check email. Or read a page or two of a book. Later, I learned to just save my sanity and skip them. Eventually I did learn a set of mission types I could reliably predict the difficulty of, and I just stuck with those and ignored everything else.There's a fair amount of travelling required, which is to be expected. Space is big, after all. What isn't fine is how often your travels are interrupted. There are countless asteroid and junk fields littered about, and odds are you'll be pulled out of warp a handful of times on most journeys. Which means you then need to crawl along to the edge before you can get back up to speed. If you pay attention you can spot some of them and go around. Not going in a straight line from one place to the next, also seems to help. Then there are the random enemy encounters, which have the same effect of slowing you down. You can spend time fighting them (if they are ship types and numbers you can handle), for loot worth next to nothing most of the time, or turn your tail and boost out of there. In most cases that'll have you on your way again in 30 seconds or so.So why the heck am I recommending it? I guess I must really like spaceships. And lasers. I had great fun, despite the above mentioned drawbacks. Enough so that I put 40 hours into it. After finishing the story, I kept going until I had the best ship fully upgraded. I then went back in a few more times to just fly around enjoying being invincible. For entertainment value, it was a bargain for the price.
