content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												As I look back fondly at Freelancer and how I could spend nights hunting pirates and trading illegal goods in the edges of the galaxy, I noticed Rebel Galaxy hit steam and thought, wonder if this is going to be one of those “trying to hard” games or actually good.Well it’s actually good.Now I’m not going to call it a masterpiece, but I will say it is very entertaining in this day and age where everyone is trying to do something new and innovative. I suppose the kinda new thing is how the combat works, closest example is probably world of warships, but in space and even that comparison is not giving it justice.--Movement and Combat.--The ship that you pilot is on a horizontal axis so you can only move back, forwards and sideways, this makes it easier to pilot the ship and aim your guns to your target. Targeting is automatic in a sense that the target you are directly aiming at is your primary target.The ships you pilot have broadside ports on both sides of the ship and the number of them varies on the ship you pilot, The Broadside is your primary weapon as you can’t set it to automatically fire.Your ship also has turret spots, however your turrets can be set to automatically fire at set targets and you can choose the primary target for each individual turret. You also have access to a secondary armament slot that can be outfitted with different armaments ranging from flak fighter/rocket countermeasures to mines and missiles.--Ships and components.--As you would imagine, you can buy and outfit a wide array of different ships, each with their own unique specialities. This also means some ships are more heavily armored than others, or boast more potential firepower.Most things on the ships can be upgraded to a better variant, like more armor plating, better shields, thrusters, engines, bigger cargo hold and so on, you get the general idea.--Stations and trading.--Each solar system that you can enter and explore has stations and these stations, mostly, can be used as a hub to repair, refill and outfit your ship to your liking. However, that is not all you can do. You can visit the bar to get the latest news from the news board that gives you an idea what is going on in your solar system, this is an ever changing system, some stations might have a tech boom that bumps up the price of technological trade goods, making it more lucrative for traders to sell their goods to that particular station, this mostly means you.You can also pick up different missions from the mission board, that all range from, go and kill this dood, defend this dood from being killed by this dood, pick up this thing that this dood lost and so on, you get the general idea.As you would imagine, one of the easiest ways to earn money is to work the market. Buy a bulk of trade goods for cheap from a back end station and take it to a prime trade port to get the most out of your goods, rinse and repeat.I remember making convoluted trade routes in Freelancer to earn millions in a few hours simply by working the market, flying from system to system, buy goods that are cheap in that system, fly to the nearest highest bidder and sell the goods and repeat the same thing. I can imagine this tactic would work here and even slightly better because of the ability to steer your ship during warp.Like I mentioned earlier, stations are not solely for trading however. Some stations are designated as guild bases, like for example the first system you start in houses a merchants guild that offers unique ships and components unique to that faction.--Interaction.--What I mean with interaction is just the general interaction with other pilots that you come across while flying around in space. Your choices matter, not much, but they matter. The same goes for your story missions, like for example, one mission in the beginning you have the chance to bribe a pirate to make themselves disappear or just kill him like you’re asked to. These sorta decisions keep popping up all along your adventures and even in random encounters while exploring, like for example, you just saved a trader from pirates and scanned his cargo hold to find some very expensive materials, do you kill the guy or let him go?--Verdict.--I would imagine that Rebel Galaxy is very good for what it is trying to do, it’s deep enough to keep people of different moralities happy. Sure it’s not the most beautiful looking game out there, but it’s not a game you want to put a paper bag over either. Combat is nice and simple and offers variety of what weapons you can and want to use, same goes for ships and other components. For people looking for a slightly more casual space sim, Rebel Galaxy is your game.And let’s not forget the bloody music, oh my gawd the music. So Firefly, So Firefly.

Another way to describe this game is, its like FTL but you dont see through your ship and in order to jump, you best run like hell to reach a safe warp (jump) point!To summerize:Pros:Easy to play and get to the action (and die lol)Thank god its in 2D because handling a 3rd direction would probably make me sick and be overwhelmed (may be a con for some)Very good graphics to the point where it looks great and is playable on lower end systems.It still plays beautifully and perfectly smooth at 4k with a 980 Ti.  Simple but robust upgrade options.  Targeting is pretty easy, the AI can manage some of your guns as well.The universe is alive, even if you did nothing but fly around you run into stuff and/or cool planets with bases.Theres a story at the very least.Awesome sounds and an upbeat sound track.  Your ship makes most of those cool sounds you want to hear when you change directions or power up your warp drives.Great Value/Price makes this hard to beat!Cons:Limited view options (may not be a con but locking the view closer or further would be nice).Just to add in case a developer reads this, if there was a cockpit view I may have to change my pants every time I play.  That would be amazing and with using the broadsides, having the camera switch to whichever side you're moving your view stick to would be an idea.Unable to paint or color your ship.There are a lot of ship choices but I wish there was a variety of each class (not a big deal).While there is a story its not the most elaborate story or intriguing.  Something more along the lines of a mysterious cosmic disturbance was felt among the universe and a new alien race or super weapon is rumored to be the cause.  Among the warring factions and those at peace, spontaneous attacks from a new enemy emerge and along with your journey between the factions in space, do you suddenly run into unexpected encounters from this new weapon or race.  . . . . just my thoughts, some pulled form mass effect which was great up until they ruined it.  There is just more there to be desired but I'm happy to at least have a story.No multiplayer...not a big deal but would be fun to do missions or visit solar systems with a buddy.  Doubling the enemies per additional player would seem sufficient.Final Thoughts:  If the developers are still paying attention (hoping their sales numbers are great or better than expected), this is a great game and starting point that so many others try to achieve and simply fail at.There is a lot of potential here and simply adding more star systems with harder difficulty and additional story would hopefully not be too much trouble if DLC becomes a future ambition.  I was bored or at least overwhelmed with EVE and it really wasn't enjoyable having to basically learn how complex the game was...especially when you only have a few hours to play periodically.  This game strikes a great balance and at the limit of 2D movement however, I think it was a perfect choice because you can focus on battles! and Blowing stuff up!I am very pleased with this purchase and with so much room to add on or improve (even when it is already done so well already) I think it is something worth expanding on.None the less, you will have a blast if you go into this game expecting a space game with simple controls a little travelling here and there (typically no more than 1 minute in the first map), and small battles that grow to epic as the game progresses.Considering fast indoor go karting costs 20 bucks for 10 minutes.... this gives you a whole lot more with some speakers and a subwoofer .... you will be the next Han Solo in your SS Pea Shooter as I named my ship.Enjoy!

												Lovely little game, I thoroughly recommend it if you're looking for a simplified space game with minimal sim elements. The story is about as believable as Freelancer (by that I mean ludicrously cheesy but in a good way), it has an excellent soundtrack and is something you can mostly relax while playing. Well, until you go to a distress call and get jumped by 4 frigates, a command ship and more fighters than you can count! Ouch?I'd suggest taking a more patient approach rather than rushing through the story, the difficulty ramps up a lot between the first two systems so you'll probably want about a million credits to upgrade systems to be on a par with the NPC factions. Some of the best weapons also appear to be looted rather than bought (Viridian Beam? Oh aye! 3.8 k range and rips through shields like nobody's business!)Physics is out of the window, they never heard of Newton as you can stop dead then turn on the spot before almost immediately being up to max speed again. The weapon types seem a little limited but they do the job and fill the required niches, they just get upgraded to a new mark as far as I've seen but I'm currently playing the legit route, different factions appear to have some slightly diferent hardware available which you might be able to loot.Overall it's just good fun with a space/wild west theme that doesn't take itself too seriously.

												CLICK BUY RIGHT NOW!  Rebel Galaxy is a VERY good game.  Fun to play, surprising in its depth, and overall a great value for the money.Gameplay is pretty simple, the story is there and some of the fights can be very tough.The only negatrive thing I've seen so far relates to the mercenary guild.  The mercenary guild (which has a station in each system after the first) gives out random kill/protect contracts - just as the merchant guild does.  After playing through several of these to rank up my standing with the mercs so I could buy a new ship, I noticed that I get a lot of missions that pit me up against system militia and other 'good guy' factions, with no warning in the briefing whatsoever.  On one mission in particular in the second system, the enemies generated for my mission were also mercenary's guild - which resulted in a huge net loss for faction for completing an assignment from that guild.  This makes ranking up the mercenary faction very difficult and frustrating - after tweeting the devs on this, I heard back that it's working as intended, and the only option to get around this is to abandon the mission, fly all the way back to the source, and get another one - which may or may not present the same problems.So I would wholeheartedly recommend Rebel Galaxy - but with the caveat that if you do pick it up, save yourself the frustration of trying to rank up with the mercs and just go with regular civilian or merchant class ships instead.

												This game is a little odd to place for me, its sort of like an arcade version of eve online... something like a sci fi biker story set on a space frontier. It took me a little while to get used to how the game wanted me to do things but once I did I really started to enjoy it. I think I sort of cheated myself out of the full experience though. I found a story mission early on that I was getting my♥♥♥♥♥kicked on several times.. i would go in and fight a bunch of stuff nearly die so I would run away... didn't realize that each time I did I was just building up a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of cargo floating around the combat area near the mission. When I finally did beat it I looked at my map and it was literally covered with loot from my previous attempts.. some of it quite valuable. I went from having sub 100k credits to having several million.Naturally I picked it all up and sold it and went and bought the biggest, baddest ship I could and mounted it with the best guns and equipment I could. I then ended up just coasting through the remainder of the game completely decimating it. The missions just keep giving higher and higher rewards and I was so far ahead of the natural equipment curve that no matter what I came across I was 1-3 shotting even the super dreadnaughts and destroyers I was coming across. I decided to just keep plowing forward fully expecting to get to a point where my gear would finally just be barely enough.. but then the final mission of the game happened and it was a cake walk.Naturally there is still a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of game left and according to the map there are SEVERAL places I could still go that are marked as very high risk and such. But still.. i completed the "main story" in just under 4 hours because of what I guess is a flaw in the loot mechanics in the game letting my 5 or 6 failed attempts at a big fight just stack up loot that was somehow on the higher end of value on the trade market in the region giving me massive profits.Due to the procedural nature of the game I suppose the market prices are a part of that as well and I just got lucky. I am not sure how much more time I will spend with this game but I feel I probably could of easily of gotten 15 or 20 hours out of the main story had that not of happened to me. I might still go back and try to finish up the achievement list but I am not sure.. lots of other stuff coming out soon.Another thing this game does very well is its soundtrack.. something about biker road music set in space is quite appealing and it matches up perfectly with the combat they have going on here. Anyways its a cheap game with fun fight mechanics and some pretty damn deep ship customization when it comes to gear and weapons. Easily worth the money they are asking for it and a nice little diversion for a few days while we are waiting some of the bigger titles to come out in the upcoming weeks... I am looking at you fallout 4....

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												Its Firefly meets Cowboy Bebop meets Battlestar Galactica. Rebel Galaxy is a good-looking and fun space action game with a kickass soundtrack. It plays more of an arcade game rather than a space sim so for those looking for the latter might want to look somewhere else. What this game has is a procedurally-generated, sandbox solar systems set on a 2D plane where the player can explore right from the start.For starters, the player's ship can't roll, pitch, or yaw (sorry, no Crazy Ivan manuevers here) - only forward movement, and left/right turns. This is because the game’s combat is designed around the broadside naval engagements similar to Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag. Basically, you line up your ship (think of it as a space boat) against the enemy ship for a firing solution, and then unload your armaments to see some fireworks. It might sound easy but it has its share of tactical positioning and maneuvering - each side of your ship (front, rear, port, and starboard) has a hull and shield rating. After you eat through a ship’s shield face, you start hitting its hull to do some serious damage. You can spin that damaged side out of the line of fire to regenerate your shields and retaliate or simply retreat and fight another day.The game has a decent selection of weaponry, ships, and ship upgrades. You can also choose to align with different factions but sadly, they have no personalities to speak of outside of the nicely animated talking avatars they have.There is a main quest you can follow, or ignore it and set out in any direction you want and be a trader, a miner, a bounty hunter, or space pirate. You can get missions from space stations that can earn you currency to buy ships/weapons/ship upgrades, as well as alignment points to factions. The said missions can get pretty repetitive after a while, but the gloriously huge space battles keep me coming back for more. Exploration in this game is fun and is rarely dull. It has the same relaxing feel as doing cross country delivery jobs in Euro Truck Simulator 2. There are asteroid fields, floating space junk from the ruins of some old battle (which may contain some sweet loot and military grade weaponry), nebulae of different swirling colors, planets, moons, and of course, stars. It will take a few minutes to fly from point A to point B, but there’s usually some unidentified signal, a distress call, or just a random fleet of space bandits to keep things interesting. The game’s soundtrack is really good. It exudes the same vibe as Firefly with its guitar heavy tracks with twangs. The devs also included the most phenomenal custom music support I have ever seen in a game. There’s nothing like Want It All Back from Cowboy Bebop kicking in as I enter combat. I have Cage the Elephant, Clutch, Johnny Cash, Darren Korb (Bastion OST), Queens of the Stone Age, Yoko Kanno (Cowboy Bebop), Vitaminless (Cowboy Bebop), and Bear McCreary (Battlestar Galactica) on my custom playlist. You can sort and assign them as combat, idle, or title music. Your custom music can also be merged with the game soundtrack for more variety.I definitely recommend this game.

												Great music! Good concept. Good graphics. Crucially flawed gameplay. The key problem is the mouse interface. Whenever you touch the mouse (I tried several), to do things like aim in a firefight, it automatically zooms in to a top down view of the ship, so you can get a closeup of your ship taking damage and do nothing useful to change things. To get the view up, you must scoot the mouse about four feet with max sensitivity to see who is attacking you and keep scooting the mouse to aim or get a glimpse of the object you're about to run into. It's basically a FPS where it defaults to looking down at your feet and you have to scoot like mad to glance at the enemies.  I can't believe they actually released a game where the mechanics of gameplay fundamentally don't work.Addendum: I'm on a Mac. The fix to the mouse control largely fixed the issue. Broadside aiming is still quite difficult because the camera still pans down automatically, although it is much, much easier to compensate for and the ship still often obscures the view of the target. 												This is pretty much the space game I always wanted to play.  Not overly complicated with way too many systems to learn, just having fun flying around a beautiful galaxy, trading materials, destroying space pirates, and listening to an awesome Firely-esque soundtrack! The game takes place on a 2D plane, with an emphasis on broadside combat, but the option for other forms of attack such as turrets, lasers, mines, etc. exists.  Basically, if you've ever played Assassin's Creed IV, the game plays very similarly to the boat sailing and combat, only more responsive and more entertaining.  There are 21 ships available to purchase and fly, as well as many items for customizing them, including weapons, defense, and more!Pros:-Runs perfectly with little to no slowdown.-Beautiful graphics with plenty of options to change.-Great music, with an easy option to add your own music in a number of areas, such as battle music, ambient music, etc.-Big universe.  While not nearly as big as other space games out there, it's still plenty big.  I've played six hours so far and haven't even left the first galaxy that you start in, and there seems to be at least 10+ to explore.-Price: $18 at launch ($20 later) is a steal for this game.  It runs smoother and I haven't encountered any bugs so far, which is more than I can say for many of the AAA games that I've payed $60 for recently.-Most importantly: FUN! Cons: -One of the only cons I would say is that there doesn't seem to be much in the way of a damage model for ships.  If you ship is severely damaged, you may see a few minor explosions and fire going on around it, but you aren't missing any chunks of your ship or anything like that.  Pretty minor in the long run when compared with all the pros.-Possible con is that many of the side missions are similar, so you could get burned out after a while.  The positive is that you can do the story missions which offer a bit more variety, or take a break and play something else for a while!-Not really a con, but you can only save when you dock at a space station, which can be a bit annoying if you need to leave suddenly, but there are plenty of space stations, usually less than a minute away, and the game offers an easy option to find the nearest space station.Overall, if you're looking for a fun game with a cheap price, look no further than Rebel Galaxy.

												A fun arcadey space trucking game. Starts slow, but really opens up after you leave the first system, with lots of equipment and ship classes to grind for. Though I'm not sure $18 is a fair price for the amount of content you get, I'd recommend waiting for sales.I do have some problems with its game design, though.1. Escort missions simply don't work. Warp pairing just boosts the chances to break warp from proximity to objects tenfold, and since escortees can't navigate space for♥♥♥♥♥♥and just fly in straight line, if you're lunky enough to get some asteroid field or nebula in a way, have fun waiting 5 minutes for NPC ship to slowly fly through it. Not only that, paired warp speed is also extremely slow compared to how you normally travel by yourself.2. Warp mechanics in general are hit and miss. For example, there should've been different ranges that trigger warp break for different types of objects. There's absolutely no reason why some asteroid or piece of junk should stop the warp unless you're REALLY close to it, it's not an enemy dreadnought that pose any threat. Jumpgates on the other hand are extremely easy to miss.3. Not only the UI is pretty ugly thanks to huge prompt icons, it also suffers from many problems. Why do loot and small ships have the same color on radar? When I use gamepad, I sit a bit further away from the monitor and it's impossible to tell what's a small square and what's a small circle on the radar. Why doesn't mission board show location of the objective on the map? Why can't you wave traders goodbye right after trading with them and instead have to go through all dialogue screens again? Why can't you just use B to go back in dialogue? Why can't you use starmap to check available equipment/ships on stations you visited? Why can't you see where jumpgates lead if there's a mission marker on them?4. Its's another game that treats you like a r-e-t-a-r-d and constantly gives you tips how to return to broadside mode, use scanner, etc. I don't need to see these tutorials a hundred times, nor am I dumb enough to forget which button does what. These things just clutter UI and get on my nerves, there always must be an option to turn those off.5. Systems lack hand-crafted environments and originality. Every nebula and asteroid belt is just a copy-paste of another one, all of the same size, there are no really unique formations and places to visit. Every system is the same, just with differently colored star and background. It's true even for the blocked-off alien world you get to visit in the end of the game. When you have only a dozen systems to offer, you could at least try to make them feel original and interesting in some way. 6. Holding A activates tractor beam, docking, warp and opens dialogue if you're receiving a call. Want to quickly warp out but some pirate is calling you? Need to enter the station with full cargo but there's a bunch of illegal materials floating about? Tough luck.I mean, it's good fun, but these amateurish and obvious problems really keep the game from being as enjoyable as it should be.

												Lovely little game, I thoroughly recommend it if you're looking for a simplified space game with minimal sim elements. The story is about as believable as Freelancer (by that I mean ludicrously cheesy but in a good way), it has an excellent soundtrack and is something you can mostly relax while playing. The weapon types seem a little limited but they do the job and fill the required niches, they just get upgraded to a new mark as far as I've seen but I'm currently playing the legit route, different factions appear to have some slightly diferent hardware available which you might be able to loot.Overall it's just good fun with a space/wild west theme that doesn't take itself too seriously.

Ultimately, its a "blonde" version of Starsector: pretty and fun, but, in the end, a shallow experience.

												First review, mostly because I'm all about some space sims these days and I think this is an interesting game that needs some clarification.So first of all it's not that deep.  It does get grindy.  The missions, while there are a few variations, do find pilots (captains?  Do you pilot a Dreadnaught or captain it? Whatever.) doing basically the same few things repeatedly.  You can't get out of your ship, you can't walk around your ship, you can't go down to planets, etc. etc.  You can't even fly up or down.  Yeah, true.  But you won't really notice after an hour, I promise.What you CAN do is blow stuff up.  A lot.  And it's pretty damn fun about it, too.  You can also put in your own music that plays in game, which is better than just having a music player on in the background because the in game music fades when you need it too, and if you have a large list of music added you get moments when the perfect song plays for the perfect fight, and it's awesome.  So I recommend this game, especially at the 17-ish bucks I bought it for.  It's pretty,  the combat is quick paced and fun, and if you're like me and waiting for even the beta of Star Citizen or for Elite Dangerous to actually have sand to go in its massive sandbox (Right now Rebel has more variation and more fun moments than Elite, but Rebel is not getting expanded for the next 10 years, so), this will scratch the pew pew itch.  Not going to be spending months and months on Rebel, but it's a fun game that might warrant a couple play throughs if you want to try going through with different factions.Almost forgot:  This is not a starfighter type of game.  You fly naval style big ships with broadside cannons and auto turrets (you can control them, too) that you angle in and open fire.  And when you unload full broadside and watch that other ship explode...I gotta say it feels good.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												Rebel Galaxy is not a simulation, nothing like Elite Dangerous or Starpoint Gemini 2 (both great space-sims); if you want to compare it you best go with Freelancer. The story, tone and visual presentation are very different from Freelancer; where the good old piece of gaming history served a more serious tone and a sci-fi-thriller plot Rebel Galxy offers more upbeat space-western; mysterie and discovery are still here but it feels nothing like what Freelancer showed.Yet Rebel Galaxy is very coherent; no matter if it`s the main storyline or the world your traveling in it all breathes Firefly.Visual presentation is top notch and despite what images and movies might suggest not very demanding, i`m running the game on an older rig and it looks and runs like charm. The whole galaxy your exploring, ships, effects, planets, stations, etc. are just filled to the rim with detail, colors and a unique art-style. Sound-design and music are some of the best i`ve ever seen, the soundtrack (western, space-rock) just hits the nail on the head, voicework is fitting, weapons, ship engines sound impressive. Just like Freelancer you`r free to do what you want (with more options); -explore and find valuable cargo, minerals, equipment-pirate trade-convoys (including a news-flash in stations giving you hints)-trade-bounty hunt-do countless randomly generated missions for various factions (tons of different missions types: escorts, deadrop pickups, breaching blockades, getting certain trade-good and the list goes on)and than there`s a mainplot which starts of rather boring but gets traction very fast and serves the space-western picture perfectly.the game offers tons and tons of different ships to fly, gear to put in your loadout (weapons, shields, engines, subsystems and and and), mercenaries to hire (one at a time) and as a unique twist: your flying the "big ships"; starting with corvettes, frigates you soon hit capital ships like destroyers, etc. .the game is not centered around smaller fighter/bomber craft vessel dog-fights, but on you sitting in a massive turret filled capital class ship ditching out broad-sides (similiar to naval combat) while turrets and your mercenary do the busy work).....and it feels and plays amazing!the games does not offer the whole 3D space, but a 2D plane your flying in, which takes some time gettin used to, but it enhances the arcady gameplay by alot.controls and interface are very very slick and tight, especialy with a gamepad the whole UI and control-scheme feels spot on; it`s hard to describe, but every simple action (from hailing other ships, docking, pulse-scanning, scaning, operating different weapon-systems, to shield managment, etc.) goes just natural. Rebel Galaxy is a very polished, colorfull, space-western, sporting freedom and content...great visuals, amazing music and very non-simulation fun gameplay. the price is very misleading, this in no way feels like a low-budget, indie game, but more like a big-release tripple A game offered for a real bargain.

												This game is just great. you wanna be a "cop" do it, you want to be a pirate do it, you want to be kinda in the mid ♥♥♥♥ing do it.now into the game the controls for keyboard and mouse are great you dont have to stretch your hand around to do anything so the default controls are fine and you dont have to worry about them right off the bat you can go right into learning the game. the gameplay is really fun, in the first star system your fights wont be that long they will be over kinda fast wether you die or not but when you get past there and start getting 150k missions and start running into dreadnoughts some fights can go on for what seems like a long time. for story i cant say to much im not far into it at all but from what i have seen the story is fun it will prob get alot more serious along the way. and they dont feel repetative your side missions do to a point. note at the time of me wrighting this i have only played 21hrsif i would have to rate the game off what i have seen so far i would put it at an 8 or 8.5/10

												Fantastic! This is a must buy for anyone who loves space games. The atmosphere is fantastic! The music is a huge differentiator. I would have paid $50 easy for this title! Very happy with my purchase and will be playing for a long time! Other Developers take note Rebel Galaxy is how you make a solid space game! I've been waiting a long time for a game that gave the same feel as Freelancer did back in the day, and even though this is cap ships it still perfectly scratches that itch, which as space game vets and coneseurs know that is high praise. Kudos Double Damage and thank you for making the game we've all been asking/waiting for. Also huge bonus points for launching a fully functional product. On a final note the ship designs are fantastic and all effects have a feeling of substance. So satisfying! 9.8/109.8 is for wanting more ships to play with! Open up mod tools or make DLCs with more ships!

I had no problems downloading, installing, saving, or loading the game whatsoever usually that is where STEAM totally screws its customers. For the price this is a terrific value and highly recommended.
